revision.text:
[[File:Ohrid Lake Ship Sinking 09.09.2009.jpg|right|thumb|Approximate location of sinking in [[Lake Ohrid]]]] [[File:Ilinden Boat.jpg|right|thumb|''Ilinden'', the boat]] {{coord|41.083|20.75|display=title}} On 5 September 2009, the ''Ilinden'' [[passenger vessel|sightseeing boat]] with a group of 57 foreign tourists on board, of which 55 were [[Bulgaria]]n, sank in [[Lake Ohrid]], southwestern [[Republic of Macedonia]]. Fifteen people died.<ref name="bbc"> *{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8239659.stm|title=Macedonia boat sinking 'kills 15' |date=2009-09-05|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2009-09-05}} *{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/europe/09/05/macedonia.boat/index.html|title=15 dead as Macedonian tour boat sinks|date=2009-09-05|publisher=CNN|accessdate=2009-09-05}}</ref><ref>http://www.nsd.se/nyheter/artikel.aspx?ArticleID=4855239</ref> The sinking of the ''Ilinden'' was the deadliest boat accident in the history of the Republic of Macedonia.<ref name="a1-1">{{cite news|url=http://www.a1.com.mk/vesti/default.aspx?VestID=113363|title=Најголема бродска несреќа во Македонија|date=2009-09-05|publisher=A1|language=Macedonian|accessdate=2009-09-05}}</ref>
Lake Ohrid is the deepest lake in the [[Balkans]], with maximum depth of {{convert|288|m|ft}}.<ref name="novinite">{{cite news|url=http://www.novinite.com/view_news.php?id=107541|title=PM: 15 Bulgarians Dead as Boat Sinks in Macedonia Lake|date=2009-09-05|publisher=Sofia News Agency|accessdate=2009-09-05}}</ref> The ''Ilinden'' boat was taking tourists to the [[Sveti Naum|Saint Naum Monastery]]. The boat, built in 1924,<ref name="a1">{{cite news|url=http://www.a1.com.mk/vesti/default.aspx?vestID=113380|title= "Илинден" произведен 1924 година|date=2009-09-05|publisher=A1|language=Macedonian|accessdate=2009-09-05}}</ref> had a maximum capacity of 45 passengers.<ref name="bbc"/> It sank within four minutes, some {{convert|200|m|-2}} from the shore, in shallow waters. The boat is said to have sunk around 11:00 AM local time,<ref name="bbc"/> in the vicinity of the Elešec camping site. Two other boats, the ''Alexandria'' and the ''Kristina'', were nearby and were able to assist the passengers of the ''Ilinden''. Most of the tourists on board were senior citizens, many of whom were unable to swim. Victims were from [[Pirdop]], [[Zlatitsa]], [[Chelopech]] and particularly [[Anton, Bulgaria|Anton]].<ref name="newsbg">{{cite news|url=http://news.ibox.bg/news/id_410944344|title= Кораб с българи потъна в Охридското езеро|last=Виткова|first=Нора|author2=Ралица Йорданова|date=2009-09-05|publisher=News.bg|language=Bulgarian|accessdate=2009-09-05}}</ref>
The Republic of Macedonia's top officials visited the place of the accident. [[Prime Minister of Bulgaria]] [[Boyko Borisov]] ordered that a Bulgarian government aeroplane bring the surviving Bulgarians back home.<ref name="bbc"/> Another aeroplane, a [[Bulgarian Air Force]] [[C-27J Spartan]], transported the corpses of Bulgarian victims.<ref name="newsbg"/> The Minister of Transportation and Communications of the Republic of Macedonia [[Mile Janakievski]] offered his resignation over the accident due to moral reasons,<ref>[http://www.makfax.com.mk/en-us/Details.aspx?itemID=8646 Minister of Transport and Communication resigned]</ref> which was not accepted by Prime Minister [[Nikola Gruevski]].<ref>[http://www.setimes.com/cocoon/setimes/xhtml/en_GB/features/setimes/newsbriefs/2009/09/10/nb-03 Macedonian government refuses to accept Janakievski's resignation]. SETimes.com, 10 September 2009. Accessed 2009-09-27. [https://www.webcitation.org/5kAtFdp6v?url=http://www.setimes.com/cocoon/setimes/xhtml/en_GB/features/setimes/newsbriefs/2009/09/10/nb-03 Archived] 2009-09-30.</ref>
6 September was declared a [[national day of mourning]] in the Republic of Macedonia. Similarly, 7 September was declared a national day of mourning in Bulgaria and all official events related to the celebration of the [[Bulgarian unification]] on 6 September were cancelled.<ref name="novinite"/><ref name="newsbg"/> A minute of silence was observed before Macedonia and Bulgaria's [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] qualifiers later on 5 September and against Scotland and Montenegro.
A nongovernmental organization, the [[Bulgarian Cultural Club – Skopje]] proposed to Mayor Aleksandar Petreski of Ohrid the erection of a monument commemorating both the victims of the accident and those whose help saved many lives.<ref> *[http://vesti.alfatv.com.mk/default.aspx?mId=-1&eventId=12896&egId=1 Further delay for the sunken ''Ilinden'']. ALFA TV, 17 September 2009. (in Macedonian) *[http://macedonie.startpagina.nl/nieuws/ NGO proposes monument to be erected in memory of Ohrid Lake victims] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081119193526/http://macedonie.startpagina.nl/nieuws/ |date=2008-11-19 }}. Startpagina.nl, 26 September 2009. *[http://forum.com.mk/_tools/article/9246/view Monument for the drowned Bulgarians in Ohrid]. Forum Biweekly, 26 September 2009. (in Macedonian). Accessed 2009-09-27. [https://www.webcitation.org/5kAtNSotT?url=http://forum.com.mk/_tools/article/9246/view Archived] 2009-09-30.</ref>
[[File:Ilinden2016.jpg|thumb|The Ilinden still unused (2016)]]
==References== {{wikinews|At least 15 die after boat sinks in Macedonian lake}} {{reflist}} {{2009 shipwrecks}}
[[Category:Maritime incidents in 2009|Lake Ohrid boat accident]] [[Category:2009 in the Republic of Macedonia|Boat accident]] [[Category:2009 in Bulgaria|Boat accident]] [[Category:Ohrid|Boat accident]] [[Category:Boating accident deaths]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in the Republic of Macedonia]] [[Category:September 2009 events]]

{{For|abbreviations|AAD (disambiguation){{!}}AAD}} '''Aad''' is a [[Dutch language|Dutch]] short version of the given name [[Adrianus]]/[[Adriaan (disambiguation)|Adriaan]] . It is also a less common Norwegian given name. People with this name include:
*[[Aad Bak]] (1926–2009), Dutch footballer *[[Aad de Bruyn]] (1910–1991), Dutch throwing athlete *[[Aad de Graaf]] (1939–1995), Dutch track cyclist *[[Aad Knutsson Gjelle]] (1768–1840), Norwegian cartographer *[[Aad van den Hoek]] (born 1951), Dutch cyclist *[[Adrianus de Hoop|Aad de Hoop]] (born 1927), Dutch physicist and mathematician *[[Aad Jacobs]] (born 1936), Dutch businessman *[[Aad de Jong]] (1921–2003), Dutch footballer *[[Aad Kosto]] (born 1938), Dutch politician *[[Aad Mansveld]] (1944–1991), Dutch footballer *[[Aad van Mil]] (born 1957), Dutch water polo player *[[Aad de Mos]] (born 1947), Dutch football coach *[[Aad Nuis]] (1933–2007), Dutch political scientist *[[Aad Oudt]] (born 1946), Dutch swimmer *[[Aad Steylen]] (born 1935), Dutch long-distance runner *[[Aad van Toor]] (born 1942), Dutch circus performer *[[Aad van der Vaart]] (born 1959), Dutch mathematician *[[Aad J. Vinje]] (1857–1929), Norwegian-born American justice *[[Aad Wagenaar]] (born 1940), Dutch politician *[[Aad van Wijngaarden]] (1916–1987), Dutch mathematician *[[Aad Zaanen]] (1913–2000), Dutch mathematician
==See also== * [[‘Ad]], also Aad, great-grandson of Shem, son of Noah * [[ʿĀd]], also Aad, ancient Arab tribe, mentioned in Quran
{{given name}} [[Category:Dutch masculine given names]]

{{Infobox saint |name=Abramios the Recluse |birth_date=290 |death_date=360 |feast_day=11 November |venerated_in=[[Eastern Orthodox Church]]es |image=SvAvramijeZatvornik.jpg |imagesize=50 |caption=Saint Abramios the Recluse |birth_place=[[Edessa, Mesopotamia|Edessa]] |death_place=[[Lampsacus]] |titles=Saint |beatified_date= |beatified_place= |beatified_by= |canonized_date= |canonized_place= |canonized_by= |attributes= |patronage= |major_shrine= |suppressed_date= |issues= |prayer= |prayer_attrib= }} '''Saint Abramios the Recluse''' (290–360) was an early Christian hermit and ascetic from [[Edessa, Mesopotamia|Edessa]].
==Biography== Abramios was born in 290 AD in [[Edessa]] (modern-day [[Şanlıurfa]], [[Turkey]]). On the day of his wedding, he left his fiancée and went to the coast of the [[Sea of Marmara]], near [[Lampsacus]] (modern-day [[Lapseki]]). There, he lived in a cave and left it only two times: first, when he was ordered to baptise a pagan village; and second, to free his niece Maria from sin. He achieved perfection in hermetic life and was devoted to the God and praying. When his parents died and left him large fortune, he distributed his possessions among the poor. <ref>[http://www.johnsanidopoulos.com/2010/10/saint-abramius-recluse-and-his-niece.html/ Saint Abramios the Recluse and his niece, blessed Mary] Retrieved on 15 Mar 2018</ref>
He died in 360 AD. His feast day is on October 29 (November 11 in Gregorian calendar).<ref>[http://nycathedral.org/readings.php?dy=2461343/ Thursday of the 22nd week after Pentecost] Retrieved on 15 Mar 2018</ref>
==See also== *[[Hermit]] *[[Lampsakos]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * [[Nikolaj Velimirović]] : "The Prologue of Ohrid" * {{cite book |last= Miller|first=Timothy S. ||date=2003 |title= The Orphans of Byzantium: Child Welfare in the Christian Empire|url=https://books.google.gr/books?id=7Tuq6u7jVv4C&lpg=PA94&ots=5ENGDKxgUY&dq=Abramios%20the%20Recluse&hl=ru&pg=PA94#v=onepage&q=Abramios%20the%20Recluse&f=false | page=94|publisher=The Catholic University of America |location=Washington, DC}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Abramios the Recluse}} [[Category:Hermits]] [[Category:290 births]] [[Category:360 deaths]]
{{saint-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Anna Rasmussen.jpg|thumb|250x250px|Anna Rasmussen]]
'''Anna Melloni Rasmussen''' (1898-1983) was a Danish spiritualist [[Mediumship|medium]].<ref name="Kragh 2003">Kragh, Jesper Vaczy. ''Danish Spiritualism, 1853-2012''. In Christopher M. Moreman. ''The Spiritualist Movement: Speaking with the Dead in America and Around the World''. ''Volume 1: American Origins and Global Proliferation''. [[Greenwood Publishing Group|Praeger]]. pp. 77-78. {{ISBN|978-0-313-39947-3}}</ref>
==Career==
Rasmussen was alleged to have produced [[Psychokinesis|psychokinetic]] phenomena, such as moving [[pendulum]]s in sealed glass cases.<ref>Anderson, Rodger. (2006). ''Psychics, Sensitives and Somnambules: A Biographical Dictionary with Bibliographies''. [[McFarland & Company|McFarland]]. p. 118. {{ISBN|0-7864-2770-1}}</ref> She was endorsed as genuine by the psychical researcher [[Harry Price]].<ref>Tabori, Paul. (1966). ''Harry Price: The Biography of a Ghosthunter''. Living Books. p. 219 (Republished in 1974 by Sphere Books) {{ISBN|0-7221-8326-7}}</ref> Christian Winther (1873-1968) of the Danish [[Society for Psychical Research]] investigated her mediumship, producing a favourable report in 1930.<ref name="Kragh 2003"/> The report was later disputed as new experiments from researchers at the [[University of Copenhagen]] in 1945 suggested all her phenomena could be explained by physical causes. In 1950, Rasmussen was exposed as a fraud as a secret camera had caught her using fraudulent methods to produce spiritualist phenomena.<ref name="Kragh 2003"/> The exposure made headlines in Danish newspapers, seriously damaging the spiritualist community in [[Denmark]].<ref name="Kragh 2003"/><ref>[http://www.skepticreport.com/sr/?p=97 "The Rise & Fall of the Third Society"] SkepticReport.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Spiritualism and spiritism}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rasmussen, Anna}} [[Category:1898 births]] [[Category:1983 deaths]] [[Category:Psychokineticists]] [[Category:Spiritual mediums]] [[Category:Spiritualists]]

{{Expand Spanish|Antonio José de Sucre|topic=hist|date=February 2011}} {{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{spanish name|Sucre|Alcalá}} {{Infobox officeholder | nationality = [[Venezuela]]n | name = Antonio José de Sucre | image = Martin Tovar y Tovar 12.JPG | caption = Portrait by [[Martín Tovar y Tovar]] | order = 2nd [[President of Bolivia]] | term_start = 29 December 1825 | term_end = 18 April 1828 | predecessor = [[Simón Bolívar]] | successor = [[José María Pérez de Urdininea]] | order2 = 4th [[List of Presidents of Peru|President of Perú]] | term_start2 = 23 June 1823 | term_end2 = 17 July 1823 | predecessor2 = [[José de la Riva Agüero]] | successor2 = [[José Bernardo de Tagle]] | birth_name=Antonio José de Sucre y Alcalá | birth_date = {{Birth date|1795|2|3|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Cumaná]], [[Captaincy General of Venezuela]] (in present-day [[Venezuela]]) | death_date = {{Death date and age|1830|6|4|1795|2|3|mf=y}} | death_place = Outside [[Pasto]], [[Republic of New Granada]] (in present-day [[Arboleda]], [[Colombia]]) | restingplace = [[Cathedral of Quito]] | spouse = [[Mariana Carcelén|Maríana de Carcelén y Larrea, Marquise of Solanda]] | children = Teresa Sucre y Carcelén | blank1 = Honorary title | data1 = ''Gran Mariscal de Ayacucho'' | signature = Antonio José de Sucre Signature.svg }} '''Antonio José de Sucre y Alcalá''' ({{IPA-es|anˈtonjo xoˈse ðe ˈsukɾe j alkaˈla|lang}}; 1795–1830), known as the "'''Gran Mariscal de Ayacucho'''" ({{lang-en|"Grand [[Marshal]] of [[Ayacucho]]"}}), was a [[Venezuelan people|Venezuelan]] independence leader who served as the fourth [[President of Peru]] and the second [[President of Bolivia|President]] of [[Bolivia]]. Sucre was one of [[Simón Bolívar]]'s closest friends, generals and statesmen. The city of [[Sucre]], Bolivia's capital, is named for him, as is a [[Sucre state|state of Venezuela]] and a [[Sucre Department|department of Colombia]]. Both the [[Old Mariscal Sucre International Airport|old]] and [[Mariscal Sucre International Airport|new]] airports of [[Ecuador]]'s capital [[Quito]] are also named after him. ==Biography== {{Unreferenced-section|date=July 2015}} ===Family=== The aristocratic Sucre family traces its roots back to origins in [[Flanders]]. It arrived in Venezuela through Charles de Sucre y Franco Perez, a Flemish nobleman, son of Charles Adrian de Sucre, Marquess of Peru and Buenaventura Carolina Isabel Garrido y Pardo, a Spanish noblewoman. Charles de Sucre y Pardo served as a soldier in [[Catalonia]] in 1698 and was later named Governor of [[Cartagena de Indias]] and Captain General of [[Cuba]]. On December 22, 1779, Charles de Sucre y Pardo arrived in [[Cumaná]], Venezuela, having been named Governor of [[New Andalusia Province|New Andalucia]], which includes present-day [[Sucre State]]. ===Military career=== In 1814, Antonio José de Sucre joined the fight for South America independence from Spain. The [[Battle of Pichincha]] took place on May 24, 1822, on the slopes of the [[Pichincha Volcano|Pichincha volcano]], near [[Quito]] in what is now [[Ecuador]]. The encounter, fought in the context of the [[Spanish American wars of independence]], pitted a [[Patriot (Spanish American Revolution)|Patriot]] army under Sucre against a Royalist army commanded by Field Marshal [[Melchor Aymerich]]. The defeat of the Royalist forces brought about the liberation of Quito and secured the independence of the provinces belonging to the ''[[Royal Audience of Quito|Real Audiencia de Quito]]'', or ''Presidencia de Quito'', the Spanish colonial administrative jurisdiction from which the [[Republic of Ecuador]] would eventually emerge. As of late 1824, [[Royalist (Spanish American Revolution)|Royalist]]s still had control of most of southern [[Peru]] as well as [[Real Felipe]] Fort in the port of [[Callao]]. On December 9, 1824, the [[Battle of Ayacucho]] took place at Pampa de La Quinua, near the town of [[Quinua, Peru|Quinua]], between Royalist and Patriot forces. Sucre, as [[Simón Bolívar]]'s lieutenant, led the Patriot forces to victory over the [[Viceroy]] [[José de la Serna]], who was wounded. After the battle, second commander-in-chief [[José de Canterac]] signed the final capitulation of the Royalist army on his behalf. As a result, he was promoted, at the request of the Peruvian Congress, to [[Marshal]] and as [[General in Chief]] by the Colombian legislature. [[File:Capitulación de Ayacucho1.jpg|thumb|250px|left|''Surrender at Ayacucho'' ([[Daniel Hernández (painter)|Daniel Hernández]]).]] After the victory at Ayacucho, following precise orders from Bolívar, Sucre, nominated as Ayacucho's Grand Marshal, entered [[Upper Peru]] (known today as [[Bolivia]]) territory on February 25, 1825. Besides having orders of installing an immediately independent administration, his role was limited to giving an appearance of legality to the process that Upper Peruvians themselves had begun already. Royalist general [[Pedro Antonio Olañeta]] stayed in [[Potosí]], where he received by January the "Union" Infantry Battalion coming from [[Puno]] under the command of colonel [[José María Valdez]]. Olañeta then summoned a War Council, which agreed to continue the resistance in the name of Ferdinand VII. Next, Olañeta distributed his troops between [[Cotagaita]] fortress with the "Chichas" Battalion. in charge of colonel Medinacelli, while Valdez was sent to [[Sucre|Chuquisaca]] with the "Union" Infantry Battalion and loyalist militias, and Olañeta himself marched toward [[Vitichi]], with 60,000 pieces of gold from the Coin House in Potosí. But for the Spanish military personnel in Upper Peru, it was too little too late, as since 1821 all out guerilla warfare had raged in this part of the continent. However, in [[Cochabamba]] the First Battalion of the Infantry Regiment "Ferdinand VII", led by colonel José Martínez, rebelled and side with the independence movement, only to be followed later by the Second Battalion, "Ferdinand VII" Infantry Regiment in [[Vallegrande]], resulting in the forced resignation of Brigadier Francisco Aguilera on February 12. Royalist colonel José Manuel Mercado occupied [[Santa Cruz de la Sierra]] on February 14, as [[Chayanta Municipality|Chayanta]] stayed in the hands of lieutenant colonel Pedro Arraya, with the cavalry squadrons "Santa Victoria" (Holy Victory) and "Dragones Americanos" (American Dragoons), and in Chuquisaca the cavalry squadron "Dragones de la Frontera"(Frontier Dragoons) under colonel Francisco López claimed victory for the independence forces on February 22. At this point, the majority of royalist troops of Upper Peru refused to continue fighting against the powerful army of Sucre and switched allegiances. Colonel Medinacelli with 300 soldiers also revolted against Olañeta, and on April 2 of 1825 they faced each other in the [[Battle of Tumusla]], which ended with the death of Olañeta. A few days later, on April 7, general José Mario Valdez surrendered in [[Chequelte]] to general Urdininea, putting an end to the war in Upper Peru and signalling victory to the local independence movement which had been active since 1811. === Role in the foundation of Bolivia === [[File:Indepedence treaty of Bolivia.jpg|thumbnail|''Bolivian Independence Act'' at ''[[Casa de la Libertad]]'', [[Sucre]].]] After the Constituent Assembly in Chuquisaca was reconvened by Marshal Sucre, on July 8 of 1825, and then later concluded, it was determined the complete independence of Upper Peru under the republican form. Finally, the Assembly president José Mariano Serrano, together with a commission, wrote down the "Independence Act of the Upper Peruvian Departments" which carries the date of August 6, 1825, in honor of the Battle of Junín won by Bolivar. Independence was declared by 7 representatives from Charcas, 14 from Potosí, 12 from [[La Paz]], 13 from Cochabamba and 2 from [[Santa Cruz de la Sierra|Santa Cruz]]. The act of Independence, wrote by the president of the Congress, Serrano, states in its expositive part: {{cita|"''The world knows that the land of Upper Peru has been, in the American continent, the altar where the free people shed the first blood, and the land where the last of the tyrants’ tombs finally lays. Today, the Upper Peruvian departments protest in the face of the whole Earth its irrevocable resolution to be governed by themselves.''"}} Through a decree it was determined that the new state in Upper Peru would carry the name of [[República Bolívar]], in honor of the liberator, who was designated as "Father of the Republic and Supreme Chief of State". Bolívar thanked them for these honors, but declined the presidency of the Republic, a duty he gave instead to the victor of Ayacucho, Grand Marshal Sucre, who would later be sworn in the same day as the first [[President of Bolivia]]. After some time, the subject of the name of the Young nation arose again, and a Potosian deputy named [[Manuel Martín Cruz]] offered a solution, suggesting that in the same manner which from [[Romulus]] comes Rome, from Bolívar ought to come the new nation of [[Bolivia]]. {{cita|"''If from Romulus, Rome; from Bolívar, it is Bolivia''".}} By the time Bolívar got the news of the decision, he felt flattered by the young nation, but until then he hadn’t accepted willingly Upper Peru's because he was worried about its future, due to Bolivia's location in the center of South America; this, according to Bolivar, would create a nation that would face many future wars, which curiously did happen. Bolivar wished that Bolivia would become part of another nation, preferably Peru (given the fact that it had been part of [[Viceroyalty del Perú]] for centuries), or Argentina (since during the last decades of colonial domain it had been part of [[Viceroyalty del Río de la Plata]]), but what deeply convinced him otherwise was the attitude of the people. On August 18, upon his arrival to La Paz, there was a manifestation of popular rejoicing. The same scene repeated when the Liberator arrived to [[Oruro, Bolivia|Oruro]], then to Potosí and finally to Chuquisaca. Such a fervent demonstration by the people touched Bolívar, who called the new nation his "Predilect Daughter", and was called by the peoples of the new republic their "Favorite Son". After the foundation of Bolivia, he became also the commander in chief of the [[Armed Forces of Bolivia]], which he created the following day on the basis of the guerrilla forces and active Patriot armies stationed at the time of the declaration. He gave the young republic its first Constitution in 1828. === Battle of Tarqui === In the [[Battle of Tarqui]], fought on February 27, 1829, heavily outnumbered two to one, Sucre defeated a Peruvian invasion force led by third President and General of Peru [[José de La Mar]], whose intentions had been to annex [[Guayaquil]] and the rest of Ecuador to Peru. ===Post-independence=== When a strong movement arose against Bolívar, his followers, and the Bolivian constitution in 1828, Sucre resigned. ===Assassination=== Sucre was killed on June 4, 1830.{{cite web |last=Monroy |first=Ramón Rocha |url=http://www.bolpress.com/art.php?Cod=2009060501 |title=Ultimas cartas de Sucre |publisher=Bolpress |date=June 5, 2009 |language=Spanish}} General Juan José Flores wanted to separate the southern departments (Quito, Guayaquil, and Azuay), called the District of Ecuador, from the Gran Colombia so as to form an independent country and become its first President. General Flores foresaw that if Antonio José de Sucre arrived in Quito from Bogota, he could thwart his plans, since Sucre was very popular due to his reputation as hero and leader in the Battles of Pichincha, Tarqui and Ayacucho. General Juan José Flores put himself in contact with the anti-Bolívar and anti-Sucre leader Brigadier-General and the Commanding General of Cauca, José María Obando, who was not present at Sucre's death but who delegated this criminal act to the Venezuelan Colonel Apolinar Morillo. Commander Juan Gregorio Sarria (who later confessed he had been paid by Obando), José Erazo (a highway bandit and guerrilla fighter), and three peons as accomplices. The plan was to ambush José Antonio de Sucre on the morning of June 4, 1830, in the cold and bleak forested district of Berruecos, along a narrow path that was perennially covered with fog. The five assassins were hiding behind trees along the part of the trail known as La Jacoba waiting for Sucre's party, which would be passing the area single file. Sucre's retinue comprised seven persons: two muleteers with the baggage, two sergeants, one being the Marshal's orderly, a representative to the Congress from Cuenca, and his{{clarify|date=November 2013}} servant, and finally Sucre himself. When Sucre approached La Jacoba, he was struck by three bullets, two inflicting superficial wounds to his head and one piercing his heart. He fell from his horse, which had been shot in the neck, and died almost instantly. His body remained there for twenty-four hours, as his companions, fearful of a similar fate, had fled in panic. Later, Juan Gregorio Sarria and Colonel Apolinar Morillo confessed that it was Obando who had convinced them to assassinate Sucre. Commander Juan Gregorio Sarria also confessed that Obando had paid him to kill Sucre, since there were anti-Bolivar politicians and officers in Bogota that wanted to see both Bolívar and Sucre eliminated. The ringleader of the anti-Bolívar faction in Bogota was Santander, who was Obando's friend and who had failed in his attempt to assassinate Bolivar {{citation needed|date=October 2015}}. The three peons who were part of the Sucre assassination party were poisoned by Apolinar Morillo to prevent them from testifying about Sucre's murder. In the end, Colonel Apolinar Morillo was convicted and shot in the main square of Bogota for the murder of Sucre on November 30, 1842, and José Erazo died in prison that same year. José Maria Obando was granted immunity due to the fact that he was too powerful in the [[Cauca Department (Gran Colombia)|Cauca Department]]. [[Francisco de Paula Santander]], although indirectly involved with Sucre's death, was directly involved with Bolívar's attempted assassination and was exiled {{citation needed|date=October 2015}}. [[File:Muerte de Sucre en Berruecos 1895 by Arturo Michelena.JPG|thumb|left|300px|Death of Antonio José de Sucre by [[Arturo Michelena]].]] ====Burial and aftermath==== [[File:Plaza de Armas Sucre Decembre 2007 - Monument à Sucre.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Monument to Antonio José de Sucre in the constitutional capital of Bolivia, Sucre]] The following day Sucre's orderly, a sergeant named Lorenzo Caicedo, with some help from others, buried the body and marked the makeshift grave with a cross formed of branches. When the widow received news of the assassination, she promptly brought Sucre's remains from Berruecos to Quito, where they were interred in secret in the oratory of the chapel of "El Dean" on one of her haciendas. Subsequently, she had the remains transferred, also in secret, to the Carmen Bajo Convent in Quito, where they were placed facing the main altar of the church. Seventy years later, in April 1900, Sucre's remains were discovered and, their authenticity scrupulously verified, transferred to the Quito Cathedral on June 4, 1900, in a sumptuous parade led by the Executive and his Ministers, the high dignitaries of the Church, and the diplomatic corps. At the time, the government ordered the building of a crypt, but it was not inaugurated until thirty-two years later, on August 4, 1932. This mausoleum consisted of a nine-ton monolith of granite from the quarries of the Pichincha volcano. Its cover, on which a cross is carved in high relief, was so heavy that thirty persons were required to move it into place. According to the December 19, 1830 ''Gaceta de Colombia'', Issue No. 495, a power-hungry, ambitious General Obando paid an assassin to kill Sucre by falsely informing the assassin that Sucre was a traitor and had to be stopped because Sucre's intentions were to go to Quito and separate the Department of Cauca and the three southern departments of Colombia and unite them with Peru. In reality, Sucre, a protégé of Bolívar, was going to Quito to stop the separation of the District of Ecuador from the Gran Colombia and to retire as soon as possible in Quito to live a quiet life with his wife. Some have argued that Sucre was ordered assassinated by General Obando so as to leave no clear successor to Bolívar in the Gran Colombia. Before his death, Bolívar believed Sucre to be the only man who could have reunited the Gran Colombia; however, Bolívar's generals and the majority of the politicians running the separate departments of the Gran Colombia had other selfish and ambitious plans. Sucre represented, according to historian Tomás Polanco Alcántara, "the indispensable complement to Simón Bolívar". Upon hearing the news of Sucre's death, Bolívar said, "Se ha derramado, Dios excelso, la sangre del inocente Abel..." ("The blood of the innocent Abel has been spilled, oh God almighty..."). Bolívar later wrote (''Gaceta de Colombia'', July 4, 1830): {{cquote|If he had breathed his spirit upon the theater of victory, with his last breath he would have given thanks to heaven for having given him a glorious death; but cowardly murdered in a dark mountain, he leaves his fatherland the duty of prosecuting this crime and of adopting measures that will curb new scandals and the repetition of scenes as lamentable and painful as this.}} Sucre is buried in the [[Cathedral of Quito]], [[Ecuador]], as he had said, "I want my bones to be forever in Quito", where his wife, [[Mariana Carcelén|Mariana de Carcelén y Larrea, Marquise of Solanda]], was from. ==Legacy== [[file:2018 Bogotá Antonio José de Sucre Monumento.jpg|thumb|Statue in [[Bogota]]]] *Some of his [[Sucre family|descendants]] in [[Venezuela]], [[Ecuador]], and the [[United States]] have followed in his military and political footsteps.{{citation needed|date=May 2013}}

*A Venezuelan Remote Sensing Satellite Launched in 2017 was named after him see [[VRSS-2]]. ==Further reading== *{{Cite book | last = Sherwell| first = Guillermo A.| title = Antonio José de Sucre (Gran Mariscal de Ayacucho): Hero and Martyr of American Independence| publisher = Byron S. Adams| year = 1924| location = Washington, D.C.}} [http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Gazetteer/People/Antonio_Jose_de_Sucre/SHEAJS/home.html Biography, 236pp., online.] *Higgins, James (editor). ''The Emancipation of Peru: British Eyewitness Accounts'', 2014. [https://sites.google.com/site/jhemanperu Online.] ==References== ==External links== {{Commons+cat|Antonio José de Sucre}} *{{es icon}} Historic document: [https://web.archive.org/web/20110817222744/http://historia.web.officelive.com/default.aspx Memoria a la asamblea del Alto Perú en el día de su instalación]. {{S-start}} {{s-off}} {{Succession box|before=[[Simón Bolívar]] |title = [[List of presidents of Bolivia|President of Bolivia]] |years=December 29, 1825 – April 18, 1828 |after=[[José María Pérez de Urdininea]]}} {{Succession box|before=[[José de la Riva Agüero]] |title=[[List of Presidents of Peru|President of Peru]] |years=June 23, 1823 – July 17, 1823 |after=[[José Bernardo de Tagle]]}} {{S-end}} {{Presidents of Peru}} {{Presidents of Bolivia}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sucre, Antonio Jose De}} [[Category:1795 births]] [[Category:1830 deaths]] [[Category:People from Cumaná]] [[Category:Assassinated Venezuelan politicians]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Colombia]] [[Category:People of the Spanish American wars of independence]] [[Category:People of the Peruvian War of Independence]] [[Category:People of the Venezuelan War of Independence]] [[Category:Presidents of Bolivia]] [[Category:Presidents of Peru]] [[Category:Sucre]] [[Category:Venezuelan generals]] [[Category:Venezuelan soldiers]] [[Category:Venezuelan Freemasons]] [[Category:Venezuelan people of French descent]] [[Category:Venezuelan people of German descent]] [[Category:Viceroyalty of New Granada people]] [[Category:Venezuelan people murdered abroad]] [[Category:Venezuelan revolutionaries]] [[Category:People murdered in Colombia]] [[Category:People of the Latin American wars of independence]] [[Category:Marshals of Peru]] [[Category:Independence activists]]

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = [[His Holiness]] | name = Atiśa Dīpaṃkara Śrījñāna | native_name = অতীশ দীপংকর শ্রীজ্ঞান | other_names = Adinatha Chandragarbha; Otish Diponkar Shrignan | image = Atisha.jpg | birth_date = 980 AD | image_size = 200px | caption = This distinctive portrait of Atiśa originated from a [[Kadam (Tibetan Buddhism)|Kadam]] monastery in [[Tibet]] and was gifted to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York in 1933 by The Kronos Collections. In this graphic depiction, Atiśa holds a long, thin palm-leaf manuscript with his left hand, which probably symbolizes one of the many important texts he wrote, and he makes the gesture of teaching with his right hand.{{cite web |url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/tibu/ho_1993.479.htm |title=Portrait of Atiśa [Tibet (a Kadampa monastery)] (1993.479) |accessdate=2008-01-11 |date=October 2006 |work=Timeline of Art History |publisher=New York: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2000– }} | birth_place = [[Bikrampur]], [[Pala Empire]]
(now in Bangladesh) | death_date = 1054 AD | death_place = [[Nyêtang]], Tibet
(now in China) | known = The major figure in the establishment of the [[Sarma (Tibetan Buddhism)|Sarma]] lineages in [[Tibet]]. | occupation = [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] teacher | spouse = | parents = | mother = Prabhabati Devi | father = Srikalyan | children = | }} {{buddhism}} {{Tibetan Buddhism}} '''{{IAST|Atīśa Dīpaṃkara Śrījñāna}}''' ({{lang-bn|অতীশ দীপংকর শ্রীজ্ঞান|translit=otish dipônkor sriggan}}; {{lang-bo|ཇོ་བོ་རྗེ་དཔལ་ལྡན་ཨ་ཏི་ཤ།}}; {{zh|c=燃燈吉祥智|p=Rándēng Jíxiángzhì}}) (982 - 1054 CE) was a [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] [[Bengalis|Bengali]] religious leader and [[Master (college)|master]] from the [[Indian subcontinent]].{{cite web|title=Reincarnation|url=http://www.dalailama.com/messages/statement-of-his-holiness-the-fourteenth-dalai-lama-tenzin-gyatso-on-the-issue-of-his-reincarnation|website=Dalailama|publisher=The Dalai Lama|accessdate=20 May 2015}} He was one of the major figures in the spread of 11th-century [[Mahayana]] and [[Vajrayana]] Buddhism in Asia and inspired Buddhist thought from [[Tibet]] to [[Sumatra]]. In 1013 CE, he traveled to the [[Srivijaya]] kingdom and stayed there for 12 years and came back to India. He is recognised as one of the greatest figures of classical Buddhism, and Atisa's chief disciple [[Dromtön]] was the founder of the [[Kadam (Tibetan Buddhism)|Kadam School]],{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/pov/myreincarnation/tibetan-buddhism-glossary.php|title=Tibetan Buddhism from A to Z - My Reincarnation - POV - PBS|first=|last=POV|publisher=}} one of the [[Sarma (Tibetan Buddhism)|New Translation]] schools of [[Tibetan Buddhism]]. In 2004, Atiśa was ranked number 18 in BBC's poll of the [[Greatest Bengali of all time]].{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/3623345.stm|title=Listeners name 'greatest Bengali'|date=2004-04-14|access-date=2018-02-24|language=en-GB}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/2004/04/17/stories/2004041703001700.htm|title=The Hindu : International : Mujib, Tagore, Bose among `greatest Bengalis of all time'|website=www.thehindu.com|access-date=2018-02-24}}{{Cite web|url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/2004/04/16/d4041601066.htm|title=The Daily Star Web Edition Vol. 4 Num 313|last=|first=|date=|website=archive.thedailystar.net|access-date=2018-02-24}} ==Early life== === Palace life === [[Bikrampur]], the most probable place for Atiśa's birthplace, was the capital of the [[Pala Empire]] as it had been of the ancient kingdoms of southeast Bengal. Though the city's exact location is not certain, it presently lies in the [[Munshiganj District]] of Bangladesh, and continues to be celebrated as an early center of Buddhist cultural, academic, and political life. Similar to [[Gautama Buddha]], Atiśa was born into royalty.[[Maha Bodhi Society]], ''The Maha Bodhi'', Volume 90, p. 238. His father was a king known as Kalyana Shri and his mother was Shri Prabhavati. One of three royal brothers, Atiśa went by the name of Candragarbha during the first part of his life. In fact, it was not until he traveled to [[Guge]] and encountered King Jangchup Ö ({{bo|w=byang chub 'od}}, 984–1078) that he was given the name Atiśa. Atisá's Birthplace is still known as the Homestead of an atheist scholar because as Buddhism is non theistic, people in Bangladesh often refer him as an atheist scholar. ==Studies== According to Tibetan sources, Atiśa was ordained into the [[Mahāsāṃghika]] lineage at the age of twenty-eight by the Abbot Śīlarakṣita and studied almost all Buddhist and non-Buddhist schools of his time, including teachings from [[Vaishnavism]], [[Shaivism]], Tantric Hinduism and other practices. He also studied the sixty-four kinds of art, the art of music and the art of logic and accomplished these studies until the age of twenty-two. Among the many Buddhist lineages he studied, practiced and transmitted the three main lineages were the ''Lineage of the Profound Action'' transmitted by [[Asanga|Asaṅga]] and [[Vasubandhu]], the ''Lineage of Profound View'' transmitted by [[Nagarjuna]] and [[Candrakīrti]], and the ''Lineage of Profound Experience'' transmitted by [[Tilopa]] and [[Naropa]].Great Kagyu Masters: The Golden Lineage Treasury by Khenpo Konchog Gyaltsen, Snow Lion Publications, pages 154-186 It is said that Atiśa had more than 150 teachers, but one key one was [[Dharmakīrtiśrī]].{{Sfn|Buswell|2014|p=247}} ==Preaching in Sumatra and Tibet== [[File:Mural of Atisha at Ralung Gompa, 1993.jpg|thumb|280px|{{Other Information}}Mural of Atiśa at [[Ralung Monastery]], 1993.]] Tibetan sources assert that Atisa spent 12 years in [[Sumatra]] of the [[Srivijaya]] empire and he returned to India in 1025 CE which was also the same year when [[Rajendra Chola I]] of the [[Chola dynasty]] invaded Sumatra.Atisa and Tibet: Life and Works of Dipamkara Srijnana by Alaka Chattopadhyaya p.91 Atiśa returned to India. Once back, the increasingly knowledgeable monk received much attention for his teachings and skills in debate and philosophy. On three separate occasions, the monk Atiśa was acclaimed for defeating non-Buddhist extremists in debate. When he came into contact with what he perceived to be a misled or deteriorating form of Buddhism he would quickly and effectively implement reforms. Soon enough he was appointed to the position of steward, or abbot, at [[Vikramashila]] established by [[Dharmapala (emperor)|Emperor Dharmapala]]. Atiśa's return from [[Suvarnabhumi]], where he had been studying with Dharmakīrtiśrī, and his rise to prominence in India coincided with a flourishing of Buddhist culture and the practice of Buddhism in the region, and in many ways Atiśa's influence contributed to these developments. According to traditional narratives, King [[Langdarma]] had suppressed Buddhism's teachings and persecuted its followers for over seventy years. According to the ''[[Blue Annals]]'', a new king of [[Guge]] by the name of [[Yeshe-Ö]] sent his academic followers to learn and translate some of the Sanskrit Buddhist texts.{{cite book|ref=harv|author=bstan pa'i mgon po|title=Blue Annals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3DuVrgEACAAJ|year=1974|publisher=Lokesh Chandra}} Among these academics was Nagtso, who was eventually sent to [[Vikramashila]] to study Sanskrit and plead with Atiśa to come teach the Dharma in his homeland. At [[Ngari Prefecture|Ngari]], he was very impressed with the king's request for "a teaching of the people […] had [Atiśa] been asked for advanced empowerments into tantric deity systems […] he would have been far less pleased".{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} It was during the three years Atiśa spent in this town that he compiled his teachings into his most influential scholarly work, ''[[Bodhipathapradīpa]]'', and encountered the disciple forecast by Tārā, [[Dromtön]]. It was this disciple who furthered Atiśa's work after he died. According to [[Jamgon Kongtrul]], when Atiśa discovered the store of Sanskrit texts at Pekar Kordzoling, the library of [[Samye]], "he said that the degree to which the Vajrayana had spread in Tibet was unparalleled, even in India. After saying this, he reverently folded his hands and praised the great dharma kings, translators, and panditas of the previous centuries."{{Sfn|Tulku|Helm|2006|p=74}} == Writings == Following are his most notable books: :*''[[Bodhipathapradīpa]]'' ({{bo|w=byang chub lam gyi sgron ma}}) :*Bodhipathapradhipapanjikanama (his own commentary of {{bo|w=byang chub lam gyi sgron ma}}) :*''Charyasamgrahapradipa'' contains some [[kirtan]] verses composed by Atiśa. :*''Satyadvayavatara'' :*''Bodhisattvamanyavali'' :*''Madhyamakaratnapradipa'' :*''Mahayanapathasadhanasangraha'' :*''Shiksasamuccaya Abhisamya'' :*''Prajnaparamitapindarthapradipa'' :*''Ekavirasadhana'' :*''Vimalaratnalekha'', a Sanskrit letter to Nayapala, king of [[Magadha]]. == See also == * [[Nyethang Drolma Temple]] * [[Bikrampur Vihara]] {{Portal|Bangladesh|Buddhism}} == References == {{reflist|2}} ===Bibliography=== * {{cite book|last=Buswell|first=Robert Jr.|authorlink=Robert Buswell Jr.|title=Princeton Dictionary of Buddhism|year=2014|publisher=Princeton University Press|location=Princeton, NJ|isbn=9780691157863|ref=harv}} * Khenpo Konchog Gyaltsen, ''Great Kagyu Masters: The Golden Lineage Treasury'', Snow Lion Publications * Geshe Sonam Rinchen, ''Atiśa's Lamp for the Path to Enlightenment'', Snow Lion Publications * {{cite book |last=Khyentse |first=Dilgo |author-link=Dilgo Khyentse |date=1993 |title='Enlightened Courage |location=Ithaca, New York |publisher=[[ Snow Lion Publications]] |isbn=1-55939-023-9}} * {{cite book |last1=Tulku |first1=Ringu |last2=Helm |first2=Ann |date=2006 |title=The Ri-Me Philosophy of Jamgon Kongtrul the Great: A Study of the Buddhist Lineages of Tibet |location=Boston |publisher=[[Shambhala Publications]] |isbn=1-59030-286-9 |ref=harv}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Atisha}} * {{Internet Archive author|name=Atiśa}} * {{Internet Archive author|name=Atisha}} * [http://faculty.washington.edu/kpotter/ckeyt/txt3.htm Bibliography of Atisha's works, Item 596], Karl Potter, University of Washington * [http://kadampa.org/en/buddhism/advice-from-atisha Advice from Atiśa's Heart] * [http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Dipankar_Srijnan,_Atish Atiśa Dipamkara] on Banglapedia * [http://studybuddhism.com/en/tibetan-buddhism/original-texts/sutra-texts/lamp-for-the-path-to-enlightenment English Translation of Lamp to the Path of Enlightenment] (by Dr. Alexander Berzin) {{redirect|Munnich|the Bavarian capital|Munich}} {{for|other people named Münnich|Münnich|Mönnich}} {{refimprove|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox military person |name=Burkhard Christoph von Münnich |honorific_prefix='''[[Graf]]''' |birth_date= {{birth date|1683|5|9|df=yes}} |death_date= {{death date and age|1767|10|16|1683|5|9|df=yes}} |birth_place=[[Berne, Germany|Neuenhuntorf]], [[Duchy of Oldenburg]], [[Holy Roman Empire]] |death_place=[[Tartu|Dorpat]], [[Governorate of Livonia]], [[Russian Empire]] |placeofburial=Private estate |image=Munnich GIM end of 18th century.jpg |image_size=245px |caption=Count Burkhard Christoph von Münnich. |nickname= |allegiance = {{flag|Kingdom of France}}
{{flag|Holy Roman Empire}}
{{flag|Russian Empire}} |branch = [[French Army]]
Army of [[Landgraviate of Hesse-Darmstadt|Hesse]]
Army of [[Electorate of Saxony|Saxony]]
[[Russian Imperial Army]] |serviceyears=1700–1762 |rank=[[Field marshal]] |commands=[[Russian Imperial Army]] |battles=[[War of the Spanish Succession]]
[[Siege of Danzig (1734)|Siege of Danzig]]
[[Russo-Austrian-Turkish War (1735–1739)|Russo-Ottoman War]] |laterwork= }} '''Burkhard Christoph Graf{{German title Graf}} von Münnich''' ({{lang|ru|Христофо́р Анто́нович Миних}}, [[Romanization of Russian|tr.]] {{transl|ru|Khristofor Antonovich Minikh}}; 9 May 1683 – 16 October 1767) was a [[Holy Roman Empire|German]] general who became a [[field marshal]] and [[political figure]] in the [[Russian Empire]]. He was the major Russian Army reformer and founder of several elite military formations during the reign of [[Anna of Russia]]. As a statesman, he is regarded as the founder of Russian [[Philhellenism]]. Münnich also was a hereditary engineer and a specialist in [[hydrotechnology]]. He had the grade of count of the [[Holy Roman Empire]] of the German Nation. ==Early career== Münnich was born at [[Berne, Germany|Neuenhuntorf]] in the Grand [[Duchy of Oldenburg]] in the military family of Anton Günther Mönnich (since 1688 ''von Münnich'', an east-Frisian nobility). Beside the knowledge of the native [[Low German language]] he also learned the [[Latin]] and [[French language]]s. He entered the French service at 17. Thence he transferred successively to the armies of [[Landgraviate of Hesse-Darmstadt|Hesse-Darmstadt]] and of [[Electorate of Saxony|Saxony]] where he earned the rank of a [[colonel]] and later [[Major General]].{{sfn|Chisholm|1911}} In 1721, he was invited by the Russian ambassador in [[Warsaw]] [[Grigoriy Dolgorukov]] for engineering projects of the newly acquired northern territories. Around that time his father has died. Upon arrival to Russia he presented [[Peter I of Russia|Peter I]] plans for the fortification of [[Kronstadt]] fortress, with which pleasantly surprised the Russian emperor, and the [[Annenkrone]] fortification in [[Vyborg]]. He was promoted to the [[Lieutenant General]] in 1722. Among his first undertakings was the completion of the costly [[Ladoga Canal]], which had been under construction for more than a decade. For his engineering and military-engineering achievements he was promoted to the rank of the [[General-in-Chief]] in 1726 by [[Catherine I]], and awarded the [[Order of St. Alexander Nevsky]]. In 1727, Münnich was appointed the Governor of [[Saint Petersburg]] city while the Imperial court was temporarily transferred to Moscow by [[Peter II of Russia|Peter II]]. From 1728 to 1734 he was a General-Governor of [[Ingria]], [[Karelia]], and Finland as well as was awarded the title of a [[count]]. During his governorship Münnich improved the local ports, reinforced the newly established [[Peter and Paul Fortress]] (1703), and was thinking of building a bridge towards [[Stockholm]]. ==Russian army reformer== Upon the coronation of [[Anna of Russia]] (1730), he was instructed to prepare the city for the return of Imperial court. After successfully accomplishing that Münnich was promoted to a [[List of Russian field marshals|General-Fieldmarshal]], was appointed to the position of president of Russian [[War Collegiate]] in 1732 as well as given an order to re-organize the [[Imperial Russian Army|Russian army]]. Münnich became a founder of the [[Leib-Guard Cavalry Regiment]], the [[Izmaylovsky Regiment]], and the Shlyakhetskiy [[Cadet Corps (Russia)|Cadet Corps]] which was destined to supply the future generations of officers. {{sfn|Chisholm|1911}} Münnich also reformed numerous other military formations as well as the War Collegiate itself. He established a new formation for the Russian army at that time, the Corps which consisted of 12 regiments [[Cuirassier]] Cavalry as well as the first [[Hussar]] regiments. Münnich revised the table of ranks and evened the salary of the Russian officers with the invited foreign military specialists. He was the first to introduce the [[sapper]] regiments to the Russian army as well as founded the Engineer School for Officers. During his administration some 50 other fortresses were erected which substantially improved the well-being of the Russian Armed Forces at that time. Due to the [[Andrey Osterman]] affairs, he was released of his duties. ==Ottoman campaign of 1734-1739== In 1734, by the reference of [[Ernst Johann von Biron]] he was sent to take the city of Danzig ([[Gdańsk]]) and after [[Siege of Danzig (1734)|a prolonged siege]] and evasion of [[Stanisław Leszczyński]] was heavily reproached. However, after that in 1733, the [[Russian Empire]] was able to install [[Augustus III of Poland]] as the King of Poland (ratified in 1736). In 1736, as the Commander of the Russian army he headed the [[Russo-Turkish Wars|Turkish campaigns]] besieging the important ports of [[Azov|Azak]] and [[Ochakov|Özi]]. On 21 May 1735 he stormed and sacked [[Perekop|Or Qapı]] penetrating into the [[Crimean Peninsula|Crimea]] peninsula. Münnich destroyed the important Tatar cities of [[Kezlev]], [[Simferopol|Aqmescit]], and [[Bakhchisaray]]. He was forced out of the peninsula due to poor logistics and battle fatigue of his formations, while another General, Count [[Peter Lacy|Peter von Lacy]], took [[Azov|Azak]] earning himself a rank of the [[General-Fieldmarshal]]. Münnich refused to resume the campaign the very next year, but he returned to the lower [[Dnieper]] steppes in 1737, and on 2 July took the fortress of [[Ochakov|Özi]] with the help of the Russian artillery. During the sack of Özi, he manually raised the regimental banner of the Izmailovsky Regiment on one of the towers of fortress after a successful attack. The siege of Özi was also later mentioned in the humorous stories about [[Baron Munchausen]], based on the adventures of the [[page (servant)|page]] to [[Duke Anthony Ulrich of Brunswick]], Hieronymus von Münchhausen. Due to the heavy losses, the campaign was paused again while conducting negotiations in [[Nemyriv|Nemirov]] ([[Podolie]]) without much result. In 1739, Münnich won the [[Battle of Stavuchany]], took [[Khotyn]] two days later, and established himself firmly in [[Moldavia]]. His victory in this campaign was later mentioned in one of the Lomonosov's odes, considered to be the first poem of Russian literature. Threatening to burn down the capital of [[Moldavia]], the city of [[Iași]], he forced the Moldavian boyars to sign the annexation of Moldavia. After the Ottoman war he was awarded the [[Order of St. Andrew]] and the Golden Weapon for Courage. Due to military losses of the [[Habsburg monarchy]] and worsening of the relationship with the [[Russo-Swedish War (1741–1743)|Swedish Hats]], the [[Russian Empire]] had to sign the [[Treaty of Niš (1739)|Treaty of Niš]] by which it had to return the newly acquired Nogai steppes while keeping the fortress of Azak. Marshal Münnich now began to take an active part in political affairs, the particular tone of which was given by his rivalry with [[Ernst Johann von Biron|Biron]], [[duke]] of [[Courland]]. Münnich's activity was brought to a close by the [[Elizabeth of Russia|revolution of 1741]]; he was arrested on his way to the border, and condemned to death. Brought out for execution, and withdrawn from the [[Gallows|scaffold]], he was later sent to [[Pelym, Garinsky District, Sverdlovsk Oblast|Pelym]], [[Siberia]], where he remained for several years, until the accession of [[Peter III of Russia|Peter III]] brought about his release in 1762. {{sfn|Chisholm|1911}} [[Catherine II of Russia|Catherine II]], who soon displaced Peter, employed the old field marshal as director-general of the [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]] ports. Münnich died four years later in [[Tartu]] and was buried at his estate nearby, where his grave was damaged{{citation needed|reason=The desecration/damage should be sourced, presented without contradictions, and the approximate time given, at at least one of the places it is mentioned; cf the talk page|date=May 2015}} by the Soviets. The Russian [[37th Dragoons Regiment (Russia)|37th Dragoons Regiment]] used to bear his name.{{sfn|Chisholm|1911}} ==Heritage== * [[Christine Lucretia von Witzleben]] (1685–1727), his wife. * [[Barbara Juliana, Baroness von Krüdener]] was his great granddaughter. * Count Johann Ernst Munnich (Sergei Khristoforovich Minikh) (1707–1788), his son, Russian statesman, diplomat, writer, studied jurisprudence, languages, and philosophy. ==Further reading== *{{ru icon}} Burkhard Christoph von Münnich. (1874) [http://new.runivers.ru/lib/book4482/53779/ Notes of Field Marshal Count Münnich] (Записки фельдмаршала графа Миниха) at [[Runivers.ru]] in [[DjVu]] and [[PDF]] formats ==References== {{reflist}} ;Attribution * {{EB1911|wstitle=Münnich, Burkhard Christoph}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Muennich, Burkhard Christoph Von}} [[Category:1683 births]] [[Category:1767 deaths]] [[Category:17th-century German people]] [[Category:18th-century German people]] [[Category:17th-century Russian military personnel]] [[Category:18th-century Russian military personnel]] [[Category:18th-century Estonian people]] [[Category:18th-century German military personnel]] [[Category:Imperial Russian military leaders]] [[Category:Field marshals of Russia]] [[Category:Russian military personnel of the War of the Polish Succession]] [[category:German military personnel of the War of the Polish Succession]] [[Category:Governors of Saint Petersburg]] [[Category:Philhellenes]] [[Category:Lower Saxon nobility]] [[Category:Russian nobility]] [[Category:Estonian nobility]] [[Category:German emigrants to the Russian Empire]] [[Category:Estonian people of German descent]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of St. Andrew]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of St. Alexander Nevsky]] [[Category:People from Oldenburg (state)]] [[Category:People from Wesermarsch]] [[Category:Russian municipal police chiefs]] [[Category:Commissioners of the Saint Petersburg Police]] [[Category:Cabinet ministers of the Russian Empire]]

revision.text:
'''Charles Rufus Baxter''' (November 4, 1929 – March 10, 2005) was an American medical doctor. Baxter was one of the [[Physician|doctors]] who unsuccessfully tried to save U.S. President [[John F. Kennedy]] after he [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|was shot]] in [[Dallas]], Texas, in 1963.
==Biography== Born in [[Paris, Texas]], Baxter graduated from the [[University of Texas at Austin]] in 1950. He then attended the [[University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center]] at Dallas where he received his medical degree in 1954.<ref name="Post">{{cite news | title=Chales Baxter Obituary | work=Washington Post | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A30370-2005Mar12.html | accessdate=2006-03-16 | date=2005-03-13}}</ref>
Baxter was the emergency room director at [[Parkland Memorial Hospital]] when Kennedy was shot, and famously said of the event in 1988:
{{quote|As soon as we realized we had nothing medical to do, we all backed off from the man with a reverence that one has for one's president, and we did not continue to be doctors from that point on. We became citizens again, and there were probably more tears shed in that room than in the surrounding hundred miles.<ref name="NYT">{{cite news | title=Chales Baxter Obituary | work=New York Times | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/03/15/obituaries/15baxter.html?ex=1142658000&en=3fe3040c38969b4a&ei=5070 | accessdate=2006-03-16 | date=2005-03-15}}</ref>}}
He also operated on Texas Governor [[John Connally]], who had been wounded in the attack.<ref name="NYT"/>
Baxter made advances in the treatment of burn victims, and founded the burn unit{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} and a skin-graft bank at Parkland.<ref name="NYT"/>
He died in Dallas, Texas, on March 10, 2005, of [[pneumonia]], aged 75.<ref name="Post"/>
==See also== *[[Parkland formula]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Find a Grave|49864829|Charles Rufus Baxter}}

Kennedy]] [[Category:People from Paris, Texas]] [[Category:University of Texas at Austin alumni]] [[Category:University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center alumni]]

{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{short description|American singer, songwriter, actress, and television personality}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Christina Aguilera | nickname = | image = Christina Aguilera at the premiere of Burlesque (2010).jpg | caption = Aguilera at the London premiere of ''[[Burlesque (2010 American film)|Burlesque]]'' in 2010 | birth_name = Christina María Aguilera | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1980|12|18}} | birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Staten Island]], [[New York City]], U.S.}}<!--As per WP:LINKDIRECT and Template:infobox person, birthplace indicates CITY, state, then country. No need to spell out "United States; 'U.S.' is fine.--> | residence = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. | home_town = {{plain list| * [[Rochester, Pennsylvania]], U.S. * [[Wexford, Pennsylvania]], U.S. }} | occupation = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|actress|television personality}} | spouse = {{marriage|Jordan Bartman|2005|2011|reason=divorced}} | partner = Matthew Rutler (2010–present; engaged) | children = 2 | years_active = 1993–present | net_worth = <!-- Do NOT add info from "Celebrity Net Worth" as it is unreliable --> | website = {{URL|christinaaguilera.com}} | module = {{Infobox musical artist|embed=yes | background = solo_singer | instrument = Vocals | Genre = {{flatlist| * [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] * [[Pop music|pop]] * [[Soul music|soul]]}} | label = [[RCA Records|RCA]] | associated_acts = }}<!-- Do NOT add any other artist unless he/she has collaborated with Aguilera on MULTIPLE occasions. Thanks. --> }} <!-- NOTE: Please do not remove sources in the lead as some information must be verified. Thanks! --> '''Christina María Aguilera''' ({{IPA-es|aɡiˈleɾa|lang}};<ref>{{cite AV media |people=W magazine |date=May 16, 2018 |title=Christina Aguilera Breaks Down Her Most Iconic Music Video Looks |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=doXqDkzFEkQ |time=0:01}}</ref> born December 18, 1980) is an American singer, songwriter, actress and television personality.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Caramanica |first1=Jon |title=How Christina Aguilera Changed Judging of Reality TV Music |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/18/arts/music/how-christina-aguilera-changed-judging-of-reality-tv-music.html |accessdate=28 October 2018 |date=September 17, 2012 |language=en}}</ref> Her work has earned her five [[Grammy Award]]s, one [[Latin Grammy Award]], and a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]. She has sold more than 75 million records worldwide, making her one of the world's [[List of best-selling music artists|best-selling music artists]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.atlanticcityweekly.com/nightlife/christina-aguilera/article_2ed79842-d3dd-5b1a-a569-5725c5ef985a.html|title=hard Rock to get 'Dirrty' with Christina Aguilera|first= |last=|work=[[Atlantic City Weekly]] |date=September 23, 2016 |accessdate=September 24, 2018}}</ref> In 2009, she ranked at number 58 on ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s list of 100 Greatest Singers of All Time, thereby becoming the youngest and the only artist under 30 to be named.<ref name="RS"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rcarecords.com/news/christina-aguilera-perform-american-music-awards|title=Christina Aguilera to Perform at American Music Awards|date=October 21, 2010|publisher=[[RCA Records]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151121223307/http://www.rcarecords.com/news/christina-aguilera-perform-american-music-awards|archivedate=November 21, 2015 }}</ref> ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' recognized her as the 20th most successful artist of the 2000s, and in 2013, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' included Aguilera on their annual list of the [[Time 100|100 most influential people in the world]].<ref name="BB_2000s">{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111114051540/http://www.billboard.com/features/artist-of-the-decade-page-two-1004053061.story |url=http://www.billboard.com/features/artist-of-the-decade-page-two-1004053061.story |title=Artist of the Decade |work=Billboard |archivedate=November 14, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="Influential"/>
Born in [[Staten Island, New York]] and raised in [[Pennsylvania]], she appeared on the television series ''[[Star Search]]'' and ''[[The Mickey Mouse Club]]'' in her early years. After recording "[[Reflection (song)|Reflection]]", the theme for [[Walt Disney Pictures|Disney]]'s 1998 film ''[[Mulan (1998 film)|Mulan]]'', Aguilera signed with [[RCA Records]]. Aguilera has been recognized as a pop icon and earned the title [[Honorific nicknames in popular music|"Pop Princess"]] in her early years.<ref name="princess_pop">{{cite book|first1=Lee|last1= Bollinger |first2=Carole|last2= O'Neill|title= Women in Media Careers: Success Despite the Odds |publisher=[[University Press of America]]|year= 2008|page= 147|isbn=978-0-761841-33-3}}</ref><ref name="abcnews">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/2020/story?id=123689&page=1|title=How Christina Aguilera Got 'Dirty'|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]]|accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref>
Aguilera earned two number-one albums on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] with her [[Christina Aguilera (album)|self-titled debut album]] in 1999 and ''[[Back to Basics (Christina Aguilera album)|Back to Basics]]'' in 2006. Her albums ''[[Stripped (Christina Aguilera album)|Stripped]]'' (2002), ''[[Bionic (Christina Aguilera album)|Bionic]]'' (2010), ''[[Lotus (Christina Aguilera album)|Lotus]]'' (2012), and ''[[Liberation (Christina Aguilera album)|Liberation]]'' (2018) all reached the top-ten in the United States. Furthermore, her Spanish-language album ''[[Mi Reflejo]]'' and the holiday album ''[[My Kind of Christmas]]'' each topped ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' component charts in 2000. Several of Aguilera's songs have experienced international success, including "[[Genie in a Bottle]]", "[[What a Girl Wants (Christina Aguilera song)|What a Girl Wants]]", and "[[Come On Over Baby (All I Want Is You)]]" from her self-titled debut, which each topped the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], "[[Dirrty]]", "[[Beautiful (Christina Aguilera song)|Beautiful]]", and "[[Fighter (song)|Fighter]]" from ''Stripped'', "[[Ain't No Other Man]]" and "[[Hurt (Christina Aguilera song)|Hurt]]" from ''Back to Basics'', and the collaborations "[[Lady Marmalade#Moulin Rouge! cover|Lady Marmalade]]", "[[Moves like Jagger]]", "[[Feel This Moment]]", and "[[Say Something (A Great Big World song)|Say Something]]".
Beyond her music career, Aguilera starred in the film ''[[Burlesque (2010 American film)|Burlesque]]'' (2010) and has been featured as a coach on six seasons of the reality competition television series ''[[The Voice (U.S. TV series)|The Voice]]'' since 2011. Aside from her work in the entertainment industry, Aguilera is involved in charitable activities through her work as a [[United Nation|UN]] ambassador for the [[World Food Programme]].
==Life and career== ===1980–1998: Early life and career beginnings=== Christina María Aguilera was born in the [[Staten Island|Staten Island borough]] of [[New York City]], on December 18, 1980, to Shelly Loraine Kearns (née Fidler), a musician, and Fausto Xavier Aguilera, a [[United States Army]] soldier.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wang|first1=Julia|title=Christina Aguilera Biography|url=http://www.people.com/people/christina_aguilera/biography/|website=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=September 28, 2014}}</ref> Her father is Ecuadorian, while her mother has German, Irish, Welsh, and Dutch ancestry.<ref>{{cite book|last=Dominguez|first=Pier |authorlink=|title=Christina Aguilera: A Star is Made: The Unauthorized Biography|publisher=Amber Communications Group, Inc.|date=December 10, 2002|location=|page=2|isbn=0970222459}}</ref><ref name="Early life">{{cite journal|last1=Gregory|first1=Sophfronia Scott|last2=Ferguson|first2=Hayes |title=Uncorking the Genie|journal=People|date=September 27, 1999|volume=52|issue=12|pages=75–76 |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20129327,00.html|accessdate=September 28, 2014|issn=0093-7673}}</ref> Her family moved frequently because of her father's military service, and lived in places including New Jersey, Texas, New York, and Japan.<ref name="WashingtonPost">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/WPcap/2000-02/13/003r-021300-idx.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6NBFEkA2w?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/WPcap/2000-02/13/003r-021300-idx.html |title=Christina Aguilera's Fast Track |last=Harrington |first=Richard |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=February 13, 2000 |archivedate=February 6, 2014 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Aguilera and her mother alleged that her father was physically and emotionally [[child abuse|abusive]],<ref name="mtv3">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/bands/a/aguilera_christina/news_feature_080906/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140805022136/http://www.mtv.com/bands/a/aguilera_christina/news_feature_080906/|archivedate=August 5, 2014 |title=Christina Aguilera's Old Soul|publisher=[[MTV Networks]]|first=Jennifer|last=Vineyard |accessdate=July 21, 2013}}</ref> claims which he denied; Aguilera used music as a form of escape from her turbulent household.<ref name="WMagazine"/> Following her parents' divorce when she was six years old,<ref name="Early life"/> Aguilera, her younger sister Rachel, and her mother (who later remarried<ref>{{cite journal|last=Helligar|first=Jeremy|last2=Majewski|first2=Lori |date=February 3, 2003|title=Christina's World|journal=[[Us Weekly]]}}</ref> Jim Kearns and gave birth to one more child, Michael 'Mikey' Kearns),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://starschanges.com/christina-aguilera-family/|title=Christina Aguilera family: siblings, parents, children, husband |website=starschanges.com|accessdate=June 21, 2018}}</ref> moved into her grandmother's home in the [[Pittsburgh]] suburb of [[Rochester, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="Early life"/> After several years of being estranged, Aguilera expressed interest in reconciling with her father in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://b96.cbslocal.com/2012/02/09/christina-aguilera-wants-to-reconcile-with-estranged-father/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140730035712/http://b96.cbslocal.com/2012/02/09/christina-aguilera-wants-to-reconcile-with-estranged-father/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 30, 2014|title=Christina Aguilera Wants To Reconcile With Estranged Father |publisher=[[CBS Local Media]]|date=February 9, 2012|accessdate=July 29, 2014}}</ref>
Growing up, Aguilera, known locally as "the little girl with the big voice",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/christina-aguilera-comes-age-112341|title=Christina Aguilera Comes of Age|last=Ali|first=Lorraine|date=July 30, 2006|work=[[Newsweek]]|accessdate=July 29, 2014}}</ref> aspired to be a singer, singing in local talent shows and competitions. She won her first talent show at the age of 8, in which she performed [[Whitney Houston]]'s "[[I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)]]".<ref name="WashingtonPost"/> In 1990, she appeared on ''[[Star Search]]'' singing "[[A Sunday Kind of Love]]", and was eliminated during the semi-final rounds.<ref name="WMagazine">{{cite web|url=http://www.wmagazine.com/people/celebrities/2011/07/christina-aguilera-cover-story|title=From the Vaults: The Fall & Rise of Christina Aguilera |last=Hirschberg|first=Lynn|work=[[W (magazine)|W]]|date=July 2011|accessdate=July 29, 2014}}</ref> She later performed the same song during an appearance on Pittsburgh's [[KDKA-TV]]'s ''Wake Up with [[Larry Richert]]''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kimpel|first=Dan|title=How They Made It: True Stories of How Music's Biggest Stars Went from Start to Stardom|page=2|year=2006 |isbn=9780634076428|publisher=[[Hal Leonard Corporation]]}}</ref> Throughout her youth in Pittsburgh, Aguilera sang "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]" before [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] hockey, [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] football, and [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] baseball games, in addition to the [[1992 Stanley Cup Finals]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://triblive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/sports/penguins/s_623827.html#axzz2iBMUrf9N |title=Anthem singer fires up Mellon crowd |last=Grupp|first=John |newspaper=[[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]]|date=May 6, 2009 |accessdate=February 5, 2010}}</ref> She attended [[Rochester Area School District]] in Rochester and [[Marshall Middle School (Pittsburgh)|Marshall Middle School]] near Wexford, and briefly attended [[North Allegheny Intermediate High School]] before being homeschooled due to bullying.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ca.movies.yahoo.com/person/christina-aguilera/biography.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812193158/https://ca.movies.yahoo.com/person/christina-aguilera/biography.html|archivedate=August 12, 2014|title=Christina Aguilera Biography |publisher=[[Yahoo! Movies]]|accessdate=July 29, 2014}}</ref>
In 1991, Aguilera auditioned for a position on ''[[The Mickey Mouse Club#1990s revival, The All-New Mickey Mouse Club (MMC)|The Mickey Mouse Club]]'', although she did not meet its age requirements. She joined the television series two years later, where she performed musical numbers and [[sketch comedy]] until its cancellation in 1994.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/read/interview/12043048|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070401032341/http://music.yahoo.com/read/interview/12043048|title=Dreaming of Genie|last=Goldstein|first=Rob|publisher=[[Yahoo! Music]]|date=May 15, 1999|archivedate=April 1, 2007 }}</ref> Her co-stars included [[Ryan Gosling]], [[Keri Russell]], [[Britney Spears]], and [[Justin Timberlake]].<ref name="AguileraBiographyPeople">{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/christina_aguilera|title=Christina Aguilera Biography|work=People|accessdate=December 8, 2010}}</ref> When she was fourteen, Aguilera recorded her first song, the duet "All I Wanna Do" with Japanese singer Keizo Nakanishi.<ref>{{harvnb|Louise Golden|2000|page=14}}</ref> She later sent her [[cover version]] of Houston's "[[Run to You (Whitney Houston song)|Run to You]]" to [[Walt Disney Pictures]] in hopes of being selected to record the theme song "[[Reflection (song)|Reflection]]" for their animated film ''[[Mulan (1998 film)|Mulan]]'' (1998).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,84715,00.html |title=Club Kid |last=Willman |first=Chris |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=October 11, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150103052149/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C84715%2C00.html |archivedate=January 3, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> "Reflection" peaked at number 19 on the U.S. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Adult Contemporary (chart)|Adult Contemporary Chart]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/299251/Christina%20Aguilera/chart?f=341|title=Adult Contemporary for Christina Aguilera|work=Billboard|accessdate=February 23, 2015}}</ref>
===1999–2001: ''Christina Aguilera'', ''Mi Reflejo'', and ''My Kind of Christmas''=== After the recording of "Reflection", Aguilera attracted attention of [[RCA Records]] A&R [[Ron Fair]] and was signed with the label quickly afterwards.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/the-christina-aguilera-story-so-far-19991028|title=The Christina Aguilera Story (So Far)|first=Anthony|last=Bozza|work=Rolling Stone|date=October 28, 1999|accessdate=January 19, 2018}}</ref> The label then started presenting Aguilera with tracks to record and laid foundation for her debut album.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Andy|title=One talented teen|work=[[The Providence Journal]]|date=August 15, 1998}}</ref> While initially catering to making Aguilera's debut a "wonder introduction of a singer" like [[Barbra Streisand]], RCA was pressurized by contemporary [[teen pop]] craze involving Aguilera's peers including Britney Spears, leading to the label rushing the production process and aligning Aguilera to be part of the teen pop trend.<ref name="Dominguez">{{harvnb|Dominguez|2003|p=45}}</ref> They decided the lead single off the album would be "[[Genie in a Bottle]]", a trendy [[pop music|pop]] and [[contemporary R&B|R&B]] track released in June 1999.<ref name="Dominguez"/> The single was a major commercial success, peaking atop the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and record charts of 20 other countries.<ref name="GeniePeak21">{{cite journal|title=Portrait of an Artist: Christina Aguilera|work=Billboard|date=January 20, 2000|volume=112|issue=5|pages=6–7}}</ref> It has sold over 7 million copies, becoming one of the [[List of best-selling singles|best-selling singles]] worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chartsinfrance.net/Christina-Aguilera/news-93194.html|title=L'histoire d'un tube : 'Genie in a Bottle' de Christina Aguilera fête ses 15 ans|publisher=Charts in France|language=fra|date=August 17, 2014|accessdate=January 20, 2018}}</ref>
Following the success of the single, [[Christina Aguilera (album)|Aguilera's eponymous debut album]] was released in August to commercial success, peaking at number one on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and was certified [[RIAA certification|eight times platinum]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA).<ref name="Washington">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/WPcap/2000-02/13/003r-021300-idx.html|title=Christina Aguilera's Fast Track|work=The Washington Post|date=February 13, 2000|first=Richard|last=Harrington|accessdate=November 20, 2015}}</ref><ref name="RIAA"/> It moved 14 million copies worldwide,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/christina-aguilera|title=Christina Aguilera Biography|work=[[Contact Music]]|accessdate=August 26, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170707135806/http://www.contactmusic.com/christina-aguilera|archivedate=July 7, 2017}}</ref> and produced three singles, including two ''Billboard'' Hot 100 number ones "[[What a Girl Wants (Christina Aguilera song)|What a Girl Wants]]" and "[[Come On Over Baby (All I Want Is You)]]", and an [[All-4-One]] cover of "[[I Turn to You (All-4-One song)#Christina Aguilera cover|I Turn to You]]".<ref name="AguileraBBCharts">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/299251/Christina+Aguilera/chart?f=379|title=Chart history for Christina Aguilera|work=Billboard|accessdate=June 20, 2014}}</ref> The album helped Aguilera win the [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist]] at the [[42nd Annual Grammy Awards|2000 ceremony]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/read/story/12051721|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080528131603/http://music.yahoo.com/read/story/12051721|title=Christina Aguilera Wins Best New Artist|last=Rosen|first=Craig|publisher=Yahoo! Music|date=February 24, 2000|archivedate=May 28, 2008}}</ref> Aguiera's two following studio albums ''[[Mi Reflejo]]'' and ''[[My Kind of Christmas]]'' were subsequently released in the end of 2000.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Charts and retail notas|journal=Billboard|volume=112|issue=45|page=47|date=November 4, 2000|first=Leila|last=Cobo}}</ref> The former topped the [[Billboard Top Latin Albums|''Billboard'' Top Latin Albums]] for nineteen consecutive weeks and was certified six times platinum in the [[Latin music|Latin]] field by the RIAA.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726142412/http://www.billboard.com/charts/2001-02-03/latin-albums|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/2001-02-03/latin-albums|title=Top Latin Albums: February 3, 2001|work=Billboard|archivedate=July 26, 2014}}</ref><ref name="RIAA">{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=Christina+Aguilera |title=Gold & Platinum – Christina Aguilera|publisher=Recording Industry Association of America |accessdate= January 20, 2018}}</ref> It won the [[Latin Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Album]] at the [[2nd Annual Latin Grammy Awards|2001 ceremony]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/christina-wins-latin-grammy-20011030|title=Christina Wins Latin Grammy|last=Saraceno|first=Christina|work=Rolling Stone|date=October 30, 2001|accessdate=December 4, 2012}}</ref>
In support of her albums, Aguilera embarked on her first concert tour [[Christina Aguilera in Concert]] from mid-2000 to early 2001, visiting North America, Europe, South America, and Japan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1424807/aguilera-to-play-prom-in-augusta-georgia/|title=Aguilera To Play Prom In Augusta, Georgia|first=David|last=Basham|publisher=MTV News|date=August 21, 2000|accessdate=July 6, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010330211536/http://www.christina-a.com/christinainjapan.html|url=http://www.christina-a.com/christinainjapan.html|title=Christina Aguilera Live in Japan|publisher=Christina Aguilera website|date=February 9, 2001|archivedate=March 30, 2001}}</ref> Thanks to her success throughout 2000, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' recognized Aguilera as the Top Female Pop Act of the Year.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Year in Music 2000|journal=Billboard|page=58|date=December 30, 2000|volume=112|issue=53}}</ref> Despite her early success, Aguilera was displeased with the music and image her management Steve Kurtz had aligned her to, feeling unable to control her own image.<ref name="NotYourPuppet">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/bands/a/aguilera_christina/news_feature_feb_02/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090305024500/http://www.mtv.com/bands/a/aguilera_christina/news_feature_feb_02/|archivedate=March 5, 2009|title=Christina Aguilera: Not Your Puppet|last=Stitzel|first=Kim|publisher=MTV News|date=February 2002|accessdate=January 29, 2009}}</ref> Aguilera's views of Kurtz's influence in matters of her creative direction, the role of being her exclusive personal manager, and over-scheduling had in part caused her to seek legal means of terminating their management contract. In October 2000, Aguilera filed a breach of [[fiduciary duty]] lawsuit against Kurtz for improper, undue and inappropriate influence over her professional activities, as well as fraud. After terminating Kurtz's services, [[Irving Azoff]] was hired as her new manager.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=114375&page=1|title=Aguilera's Ex-Manager Fires Back|publisher=ABC News|date=October 19, 2000|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref>
Aguilera's first take on more artistic control was expressed in the 2001 ''[[Moulin Rouge! Music from Baz Luhrmann's Film|Moulin Rouge!]]'' cover of [[Labelle]]'s "[[Lady Marmalade]]", which also saw the contribution of [[Pink (singer)|Pink]], [[Mya (singer)|Mya]] and [[Lil Kim]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/christina-aguilera-comes-age-112379|title=Christina Aguilera comes of age|work=[[Newsweek]]|date=July 30, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180120135330/http://www.newsweek.com/christina-aguilera-comes-age-112379|archivedate=January 20, 2018}}</ref> Originally opposed by RCA executives for being "too [[urban music|urban]]" and "too [[Rockwilder]] and [[Missy Elliott|Missy]]", Aguilera insisted on recording the song.<ref name="NotYourPuppet"/> "Lady Marmalade" topped the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 for five weeks based on airplay alone, becoming the first airplay-only track in history to remain on the chart's top spot for more than one week.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/lady-marmalade-mw0000424595|title=Lady Marmalade – Song Review|publisher=AllMusic|first=Jose|last=Promis|accessdate=January 20, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Hot 100 Spotlight|work=Billboard|date=June 2, 2001|first=Silvio|last=Pietroluongo|page=123|volume=113|issue=22}}</ref> It earned a [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals]] at the [[44th Annual Grammy Awards|2002 ceremony]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/The-2002-Grammy-winners-2868670.php|title=The 2002 Grammy winners|work=San Francisco Chronicle|date=February 28, 2002|accessdate=July 7, 2014}}</ref> Later in 2001, an album titled ''[[Just Be Free]]'' containing demo tracks recorded by Aguilera in 1994 and 1995 was released by [[Warlock Records]] without Aguilera's permission.
