She subsequently filed a suit against Warlock Records and the album's producers to stop the release.<ref>{{harvnb|Dominguez|2003|page=34}}</ref> The two parties came to a confidential settlement to release the album, in which Aguilera lent out her name, likeness, and image for an unspecified amount of damages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/A/Aguilera_Christina/2001/07/03/pf-742790.html|title=Disputed Aguilera album to be released|last=McGrath|first=Stephanie|publisher=[[Jam!]]|date=July 3, 2001|accessdate=May 25, 2007}}</ref>
===2002–2003: ''Stripped''=== [[File:Stripped Tour CH - cropped.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Aguilera performing on [[The Stripped Tour]] in 2003]]
When planning her fourth studio album, Aguilera leaned towards a new artistic direction that she felt had more musical and lyrical depth.<ref name="USAToday">{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2002-10-23-christina-aguilera_x.htm |title=Aguilera's image is 'Stripped' |last=Gardner |first=Elysa |newspaper=USA Today |date=October 24, 2002 |accessdate=October 19, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160301144224/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2002-10-23-christina-aguilera_x.htm |archivedate=March 1, 2016 |df= }}</ref> She named the album ''[[Stripped (Christina Aguilera album)|Stripped]]'' and explained that the title represented "a new beginning, a re-introduction of [herself] as a new artist in a way".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1458433/christina-stands-up-for-the-ladies-discusses-fathers-abuse/|title=Christina Stands Up For The Ladies, Discusses Father's Abuse|first=Jennifer|last=Vineyard|publisher=MTV News|date=October 30, 2002|accessdate=July 7, 2014}}</ref> For the album, Aguilera served as [[executive producer]] and co-wrote most of the songs.<ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=[[Stripped (Christina Aguilera album)|Stripped]]|others=Christina Aguilera|year=2002|format=CD liner notes|publisher=[[RCA Records]]}}</ref><ref name="Vice_Stripped">{{cite web|url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_ca/article/d3dpby/christina-aguilera-stripped-gender-equality-15-anniversary|title=15 Years After Christina Aguilera's 'Stripped,' We're Still Nowhere Near Gender Equality|first=Sophie|last=Willkinson|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|date=October 27, 2017|accessdate=January 20, 2018}}</ref> The album was preceded by the single "[[Dirrty]]", which was released to shed Aguilera's teen pop image and express her sexuality and aggression.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/28/arts/28iht-chris.2322180.html|title=Aguilera Aims for Edgy, bur Richer, Sound|work=[[The New York Times]]|first=Lola|last=Ogunnaike|date=July 28, 2006|accessdate=January 20, 2018}}</ref> Its accompanying music video generated controversy for depicting various sexual fetishes and concepts.<ref>{{cite web|last=Edwards|first=Tanya L|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1458275/20021022/aguilera_christina.jhtml|title=How Dirty Is 'Dirrty'? X-posing The Kinks In X-tina's Video|publisher=MTV News|date=October 23, 2002|accessdate=June 16, 2007}}</ref> Aguilera's new image presented in the video started to overshadow her music,<ref>{{cite news|last=Tryangiel |first=Josh |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1376243-1,00.html |title=Welcome to my Bubble |work=Time |date=August 27, 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012211218/http://time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C1376243-1%2C00.html |archivedate=October 12, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> generating widespread criticism from both her peers including [[Shakira]] and [[Jessica Simpson]] and the public.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dark |first=Jane |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2002-11-12/music/siren-wailing/ |title=Siren Wailing |work=[[The Village Voice]] |date=November 11, 2002 |accessdate=June 18, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041209030356/http://www.villagevoice.com/issues/0246/dark.php |archivedate=December 9, 2004 |df= }}</ref><ref name="blender">{{cite web|last=Duerden |first=Nick |url=http://www.blender.com/guide/67285/good-bad-dirrty.html |title=The Good, the Bad and the Dirrty |work=[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]] |date=November 15, 2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090807060733/http://www.blender.com/guide/67285/good-bad-dirrty.html |archivedate=August 7, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Aguilera defended her new image, explaining that "I'm in the power position, in complete command of everything and everybody around me. To be totally balls-out like that is, for me, the measure of a true artist."<ref name="blender"/>
The final cut of ''Stripped'' incorporated various genres from [[flamenco]] and [[contemporary R&B|R&B]] to [[rock music|rock]] and lyrically revolved around the theme of [[self-esteem]] while also discussing [[sex]] and [[gender equality]].<ref name="rs_Stripped"/><ref name="Vice_Stripped"/> It was released in October 2002 to mixed critical reviews;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/stripped/christina-aguilera/critic-reviews|title=Critic Reviews for Stripped|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=January 20, 2018}}</ref> [[Jancee Dunn]] from the ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' praised Aguilera's vocals yet panned the album for its lack of musical concentration.<ref name="rs_Stripped">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/stripped-20021105|title=Stripped|work=Rolling Stone|first=Jancee|last=Dunn|authorlink=Jancee Dunn|date=November 6, 2002|accessdate=January 20, 2018}}</ref> The album was nonetheless a commercial success, peaking at number two on the ''Billboard'' 200 and has sold over 4.3 million copies in the United States.<ref name="AskBillboardCareer"/> It was a major success in the United Kingdom, having sold 2 million copies and became the second highest-selling album by a female US artist of the 2000s decade, behind [[Norah Jones]] with ''[[Come Away with Me]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/official-charts-flashback-2002-christina-aguilera-reinvents-herself-with-dirrty-at-number-1__21081/|title=Official Charts Flashback 2002: Christina Aguilera reinvents herself with Dirrty at Number 1|date=November 23, 2017|accessdate=January 20, 2018|publisher=[[Official Charts Company]]|first=Rob|last=Copsey}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media |date=December 28, 2009 |title=Best-Selling of the Noughties |medium=radio news |publisher=[[BBC Radio 1]]/Official Charts Company}}</ref> ''Stripped'' has sold over 12 million copies worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/10699242/scott_storchs_outrageous_fortune/print|title=Scott Storch's Outrageous Fortune|work=Rolling Stone|author=Touré|date=June 29, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080419055040/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/10699242/scott_storchs_outrageous_fortune/print|archivedate=April 19, 2008}}</ref> The album was followed by four singles, "[[Beautiful (Christina Aguilera song)|Beautiful]]", "[[Fighter (Christina Aguilera song)|Fighter]]", "[[Can't Hold Us Down]]", and "[[The Voice Within]]". "Beautiful" received universal acclaim for positive portrayal of the [[LGBT community]] and was the album's most commercially successful single, peaking at number two on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050418084316/http://www.glaad.org/media/release_detail.php?id=3359|url=http://www.glaad.org/media/release_detail.php?id=3359|title=Eric McCormack, Todd Haynes, Christina Aguilera, The Hours, Six Feet Under Honored at 14th Annual GLAAD Media Awards Presented by Absolut Vodka in Los Angeles|date=April 26, 2003|publisher=[[GLAAD]]|archivedate=April 18, 2005}}</ref> It earned Aguilera a [[Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Performance]] at the [[46th Annual Grammy Awards|2004 ceremony]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/09/arts/the-grammy-award-winners-of-2004.html|title=The Grammy Award Winners of 2004|work=The New York Times|date=February 9, 2004|accessdate=October 20, 2013}}</ref> The song was later listed at number 52 among the 100 Best Songs of the 2000s by the ''Rolling Stone'' in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-best-songs-of-the-aughts-20110617/christina-aguilera-beautiful-20110617|title=Christina Aguilera, 'Beautiful'|work=Rolling Stone|date=June 17, 2011|accessdate=January 21, 2018}}</ref>
During the promotion of ''Stripped'', Aguilera cultivated a new image by adopting the [[alter ego]] Xtina, dyeing her hair black, and debuting several tattoos and piercings.<ref name="CareerBiggest"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/christina_aguilera/0,,,00.html|title=Christina Aguilera: Five Fun Facts|work=People|accessdate=October 19, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022140434/http://www.people.com/people/christina_aguilera/0,,,00.html|archivedate=October 22, 2013}}</ref> She co-headlined the [[Justified and Stripped Tour]] alongside [[Justin Timberlake]] from June to September 2003 in support of ''Stripped'' and Timberlake's album ''[[Justified (album)|Justified]]'', before embarking on her solo [[The Stripped Tour]] until December.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/justin-timberlake-and-christina-aguilera-double-trouble-20030626|title=Justin Timberlake and Christina Aguilera: Double Trouble|first=Jancee|last=Dunn|work=Rolling Stone|date=June 26, 2003|accessdate=October 20, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.frontiertouring.com/index.php?action=retail&form_name=view_retail&merchant_id=595&sectionID=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325202833/http://www.frontiertouring.com/index.php?action=retail&form_name=view_retail&merchant_id=595&sectionID=|title=Frontier Touring: The Stripped Tour|publisher=Frontier Touring|archivedate=March 25, 2012}}</ref> Aguilera garnered media attention after attending the [[2003 MTV Video Music Awards]] in August, where she and [[Britney Spears]] kissed [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] during their performance of "[[Like a Virgin (song)|Like a Virgin]]" and "[[Hollywood (Madonna song)|Hollywood]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/madonna-magic-at-mtv-awards/|title=Madonna Magic At MTV Awards|last=Moody|first=Nekesa Mumbi|publisher=CBS News|date=August 29, 2003|accessdate=February 22, 2013}}</ref> Later that year, she was the host of the [[2003 MTV Europe Music Awards]], where she won an award for [[MTV Europe Music Award for Best Female|Best Female]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1480240/its-justins-night-as-christina-kelly-osbourne-fight-at-mtv-europe-awards/|title=It's Justin's Night As Christina, Kelly Osbourne Fight At MTV Europe Awards|first=Jon|last=Wiederhorn|publisher=MTV News|date=November 6, 2003|accessdate=October 20, 2013}}</ref> ''Billboard'' also announced Aguilera as the Top Female Pop Act of 2003.<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Year in Music 2003|journal=Billboard|page=68|volume=115|issue=52|date=December 27, 2003}}</ref>
===2004–2009: ''Back to Basics''=== [[File:Christina Aguilera Sanremo.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Aguilera performing at the [[Sanremo Music Festival]] in 2006]]
In 2004, Aguilera recorded a [[Car Wash (song)#Christina Aguilera and Missy Elliott version|revised version]] of [[Rose Royce]]'s "[[Car Wash (song)|Car Wash]]" with Missy Elliott for the animated film ''[[Shark Tale]]'', in which she was also a voice actress.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1491393/christina-aguilera-is-poisonous-in-video-with-missy-elliott/|title=Christina Aguilera Is Poisonous In Video With Missy Elliott|first=Jennifer|last=Vineyard|publisher=MTV News|date=September 24, 2004|accessdate=October 21, 2013}}</ref> Later that year, she and [[Nelly]] performed "[[Tilt Ya Head Back]]" at the [[2004 MTV Video Music Awards]];<ref name="EW2004">{{cite web|url=http://ew.com/article/2004/08/30/highlights-2004-mtv-video-music-awards/|title=Highlights of the 2004 MTV Video Music Awards|first=Brian|last=Hiatt|date=August 30, 2004|accessdate=January 22, 2018}}</ref> the song was subsequently released as a single from Nelly's album ''[[Sweat (Nelly album)|Sweat]]''.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Singles: Essential Reviews|first=Michael|last=Paoletta|work=Billboard|date=September 25, 2004|volume=116|issue=39|page=55}}</ref> Aguilera also contributed vocals to [[Herbie Hancock]]'s 2005 cover of [[Leon Russell]]'s "[[A Song for You]]", which was nominated for a Grammy Award in the category of [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals|Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals]] at the [[48th Annual Grammy Awards|48th ceremony]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/music/bal-grammys-winners0209-htmlstory.html|title=Complete list of 2006 Grammy winners|newspaper=The Baltimore Sun|date=February 9, 2006|accessdate=July 7, 2014}}</ref> During this time, Aguilera started working on her follow-up studio album while embracing an image inspired by public figures of the "[[Golden Age of Hollywood|Old Hollywood glam era]]" including [[Marilyn Monroe]], [[Marlene Dietrich]], and [[Mary Pickford]], debuting blonde curly hair and retro-styled makeup.<ref name="EW2004"/><ref name="HelloMag">{{cite web|url=http://www.hellomagazine.com/music/2004/10/20/christinaaguliera/|title=Christina turns Hollywood pin-up in latest shoot|work=Hello!|date=October 20, 2004|accessdate=October 20, 2013}}</ref>
Aguilera's fifth studio album ''[[Back to Basics (Christina Aguilera album)|Back to Basics]]'' was released in August 2006. The [[double album]], according to Aguilera, was "a throwback to the 20s, 30s, and 40s-style [[jazz]], [[blues]], and feel-good [[soul music]], but with a modern twist".<ref name="B2BMusic">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1533622/christina-makes-her-comeback-twice-as-nice-by-expanding-basics-into-double-lp/ |title=Christina Makes Her Comeback Twice As Nice By Expanding Basics Into Double LP |first1=Corey |last1=Moss |first2=Jeff |last2=Cornell |publisher=MTV News |date=June 6, 2006 |accessdate=October 22, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141012115058/http://www.mtv.com/news/1533622/christina-makes-her-comeback-twice-as-nice-by-expanding-basics-into-double-lp/ |archivedate=October 12, 2014 |df= }}</ref> During the recording process, Aguilera was much inspired by works of classic blues and soul singers including [[Otis Redding]], [[Millie Jackson]], and [[Nina Simone]], which she described as "music that really had heart".<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JhYEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA26|title=Old School|first=Melinda|last=Newman|work=Billboard|page=26|volume=118|issue=30|date=July 29, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2018}}</ref> The album was released to generally positive critical feedback, with compliments regarding its retro-oriented styles and Aguilera's vocals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/back-to-basics/christina-aguilera/critic-reviews|title=Critic Reviews for Back to Basics|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=January 22, 2018}}</ref> It debuted atop the ''Billboard'' 200 and has sold over 5 million copies worldwide,<ref>{{harvnb|Davis|2013|page=496}}</ref> of which 1.7 million copies were sold in the United States.<ref name="AskBillboardCareer"/> The album was preceded by "[[Ain't No Other Man]]", which reached number 6 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 and has sold 1.7 million digital copies in the United States.<ref name="AskBillboardCareer"/> The song's music video saw Aguilera portraying her new alter ego Baby Jane.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1534591/aint-no-other-man-video-has-christina-singing-the-blues/|title='Ain't No Other Man' Video Has Christina Aguilera Singing the Blues|publisher=MTV News|first=Jennifer|last=Vineyard|date=June 19, 2006|accessdate=January 22, 2018}}</ref> The single won Best Female Pop Vocal Performance at the [[49th Annual Grammy Awards]], where Aguilera performed a rendition of "[[It's a Man's Man's Man's World]]" in tribute of [[James Brown]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/SHOWBIZ/Music/02/11/grammy.awards/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021075431/http://edition.cnn.com/2007/SHOWBIZ/Music/02/11/grammy.awards/|title=A 'Nice' night for the Dixie Chicks|first=Todd|last=Leopold|publisher=CNN|date=February 12, 2007|archivedate=October 21, 2012}}</ref>
''Back to Basics'' was succeeded by two singles, "[[Hurt (Christina Aguilera song)|Hurt]]" and "[[Candyman (Christina Aguilera song)|Candyman]]". "[[Slow Down Baby]]" was released exclusively in Australia as the fourth single,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sonybmg.com.au/news/details.do?newsId=20030829004728|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070904081540/http://sonybmg.com.au/news/details.do?newsId=20030829004728|title=Christina Aguilera Arrives In Town This Week!|publisher=Sony Music Australia|date=July 12, 2007|archivedate=September 4, 2007}}</ref> while "[[Oh Mother]]" was the fourth in Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radioandrecords.com/formats/charts/euro/Switzerland.asp|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013015718/http://www.radioandrecords.com/formats/charts/euro/Switzerland.asp|title=Radio & Records: Swiss Top 20 Chart|work=Radio & Records|date=September 21, 2007|archivedate=October 13, 2007}}</ref> In support of ''Back to Basics'', Aguilera embarked on the [[Back to Basics Tour]], commencing in November 2006 in Europe, visiting North America, Asia, and Oceania, and ending in October 2008 in the United Arab Emirates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1540564/christina-aguilera-reveals-european-tour-next-up-us-clubs/|title=Christina Aguilera Reveals European Tour — Next Up, U.S. Clubs|first=Jennifer|last=Vineyard|publisher=MTV News|date=September 11, 2006|accessdate=October 23, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/art/2008/11/145_5365.html|title=Christina Aguilera Shows Off Impressive Vocals|first=Cathy|last=Garcia|work=[[The Korea Times]]|date=June 25, 2007|accessdate=June 11, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.take40.com/news/12441/christina-to-tour!- |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223032338/http://www.take40.com/news/12441/christina-to-tour%21- |archivedate=February 23, 2014 |title=Christina To Tour! |publisher=Take 40 Australia |date=April 16, 2007 |accessdate=June 11, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/uae-news/aguilera-set-for-middle-east-debut|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810070829/http://www.thenational.ae/news/uae-news/aguilera-set-for-middle-east-debut|title=Aguilera set for Middle East debut|work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]]|first=Melanie|last=Swan|location=Abu Dhabi|date=October 23, 2008|archivedate=August 10, 2011}}</ref> ''Billboard'' Boxscore announced the Back to Basic Tour as the highest-grossing solo female tour of 2007, with US$48.1M grossed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1047044/the-police-score-top-grossing-tour-of-07|title=The Police Score Top-Grossing Tour Of '07|date=December 13, 2007|work=Billboard|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141007050948/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1047044/the-police-score-top-grossing-tour-of-07|archivedate=October 7, 2014}}</ref> ''[[Forbes]]'' recognized Aguilera as the nineteenth-richest woman in entertainment as of January 2007, with a net worth of US$60 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/2007/01/17/richest-women-entertainment-tech-media-cz_lg_richwomen07_0118womenstars_slide_20.html?thisSpeed=undefined |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QuiSpxdE?url=http://www.forbes.com/2007/01/17/richest-women-entertainment-tech-media-cz_lg_richwomen07_0118womenstars_slide_20.html?thisSpeed=undefined |title=In Pictures: The 20 Richest Women In Entertainment |last1=Goldman |first1=Lea |last2=Blakeley |first2=Kiri |work=Forbes |date=January 18, 2007 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
Later that year, she appeared in the [[Martin Scorsese]] documentary ''[[Shine a Light (film)|Shine a Light]]'' chronicling a two-day [[The Rolling Stones|Rolling Stones]] concert in New York City's [[Beacon Theatre (New York City)|Beacon Theatre]], in which Aguilera performs "[[Live with Me]]" alongside the band's lead vocalist [[Mick Jagger]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/filmreviews/3672481/Film-reviews-Shine-a-Light-and-21.html|title=Film reviews: Shine a Light and 21|first=David|last=Gritten|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=April 11, 2008|accessdate=August 28, 2013}}</ref> In commemoration of a decade-long career in the music industry, Aguilera released a [[greatest hits album]] titled ''[[Keeps Gettin' Better: A Decade of Hits]]'' exclusively through [[Target Corporation|Target]] on November 11, 2008, in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1044276/target-scores-aguilera-hits-album-exclusive |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Quho1Gxr?url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1044276/target-scores-aguilera-hits-album-exclusive |title=Target Scores Aguilera Hits Album Exclusive |first=Katie |last=Hasty |work=Billboard |date=September 3, 2008 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no }}</ref> In addition to previous singles, it included four newly-recorded [[electropop]]-oriented songs, two of which are remade versions of two previous singles.<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707142741/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/christina-aguilera/albumguide|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/christina-aguilera/albumguide|title=Christina Aguilera: Album Guide|work=Rolling Stone|archivedate=July 7, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1043616/hits-set-tees-up-next-christina-aguilera-album |title=Hits Set Tees Up Next Christina Aguilera Album |work=Billboard|date=October 31, 2008| first=Mariel|last=Conception |accessdate=May 24, 2011}}</ref> Aguilera revealed that the newly-recorded tracks featured "a very futurisic, robotic sound" that served as a preview for her follow-up studio album.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1043491/christina-aguilera-better-and-better|title=Christina Aguilera: Better And 'Better'|first=Michael|last=Concepcion|date=November 14, 2008|accessdate=January 24, 2018|work=Billboard}}</ref> The release peaked at number nine on the ''Billboard'' 200, while its titular single "[[Keeps Gettin' Better]]" charted at number five on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100.<ref name="AguileraBBCharts"/> In 2009, ''Billboard'' recognized Aguilera as the 20th most successful artist of the 2000s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/266420/artists-of-the-decade|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140608034041/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/266419/artists-of-the-decade-page-two|title=Artists of the Decade|work=Billboard|archivedate=June 8, 2014}}</ref>
===2010–2011: ''Bionic'', ''Burlesque'', and ''The Voice''=== [[File:Christina Aguilera (at premiere of "To John With Love", September 2010).jpg|thumb|left|upright|Aguilera in 2010]] Aguilera's sixth studio album ''[[Bionic (Christina Aguilera album)|Bionic]]'' was released in June 2010. The album drew inspirations from [[electronic music|electronic]] genres, which had influenced Aguilera during her pregnancy.<ref name="ElectronicBionic">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1641039/christina-aguilera-brings-new-songs-classic-hits-to-today-show/|title=Christina Aguilera Brings New Songs, Classic Hits To 'Today' Show|first=James|last=Dinh|publisher=MTV News|date=June 8, 2010|accessdate=July 8, 2014}}</ref> Critical response to the album was mixed, with some critics not welcoming the change in musical styles as well as the content of the lyrics for being "cringeworthy".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/bionic/christina-aguilera/critic-reviews|title=Critic Reviews for Bionic|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=January 24, 2018}}</ref> ''Bionic'' struggled to match the chart impact and sales of her previous albums, peaking at number three on the ''Billboard'' 200 and has sold 315,000 copies in the United States.<ref name="AguileraBBCharts"/><ref name="AskBillboardCareer"/> "[[Not Myself Tonight]]" and "[[You Lost Me]]" were released as singles internationally, while "[[Woohoo (Christina Aguilera song)|Woohoo]]" featuring rapper [[Nicki Minaj]] was released as a single in the United States and several European countries,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fmqb.com/Article.asp?id=69239 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QujmdbEt?url=http://www.fmqb.com/Article.asp?id=69239 |title=Airplay Archive |work=FMQB |archivedate=July 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/be/album/woohoo-feat-nicki-minaj-single/id374246489 |title=Woohoo – Single |publisher=iTunes Store |accessdate=July 8, 2014}}</ref> and "[[I Hate Boys]]" was released exclusively to Australian airplay services.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themusicnetwork.com/music-releases/singles/2010/06/28/issue-793/Christina-Aguilera--i-Hate-Boys/|title=Christina Aguilera – I Hate Boys – Issue 793|work=[[The Music Network]]|date=June 28, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406144504/http://www.themusicnetwork.com/music-releases/singles/2010/06/28/issue-793/Christina-Aguilera--i-Hate-Boys/|archivedate=April 6, 2012}}</ref>
In November 2010, Aguilera starred alongside [[Cher]] in the film ''[[Burlesque (2010 American film)|Burlesque]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/dec/11/cher-christina-aguilera-burlesque|title=Cher could teach Christina Aguilera a thing or two in Burlesque|work=The Guardian|first=John|last=Patterson|date=December 11, 2010|accessdate=August 29, 2013}}</ref> The film was written and directed by [[Steve Antin]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2010-11-22-burlesque24_VA_N.htm |title=Director Antin had stars in his eyes when he cast 'Burlesque' |work=USA Today |first=Susan |last=Wloszczyna |date=November 23, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qukko2iQ?url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2010-11-22-burlesque24_VA_N.htm |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no }}</ref> and grossed $90 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=burlesque.htm|title=Burlesque (2010)|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=August 25, 2013}}</ref> It was met with mixed reviews from critics, who criticized it for being "campy and [[cliché]]d", yet praised Aguilera's acting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/burlesque|title='Burlesque' Reviews|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=May 2, 2014}}</ref> ''Burlesque'' received a nomination for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy|Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy]] at the [[68th Golden Globe Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/env-2011-globes-nom-list-scorecard-html-htmlstory.html |title=2011 Golden Globes nominees & winners |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QuldUibs?url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/env-2011-globes-nom-list-scorecard-html-htmlstory.html |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Aguilera contributed eight tracks to the film's [[Burlesque: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|accompanying soundtrack]], while Cher performed the other two.<ref>{{cite AV media notes|others=Christina Aguilera, Cher|title=Burlesque: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack|year=2010|type=inlay cover|publisher=Screen Gems, Inc|page=iTunes Digital Booklet}}</ref> The soundtrack reached number 18 on the ''Billboard'' 200 and was certified gold by the RIAA.<ref name="RIAA"/>
At the [[Super Bowl XLV]] in February 2011, Aguilera omitted a few lines while performing the U.S. national anthem "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1657367/christina-aguilera-super-bowl/|title=Christina Aguilera Apologizes For Super Bowl National Anthem Flub|first=Gil|last=Kaulfman|publisher=MTV News|date=July 2, 2011|accessdate=February 23, 2015}}</ref> She later apologized, saying, "I got so caught up in the moment of the song that I lost my place. I can only hope that everyone could feel my love for this country and that the true spirit of its anthem still came through".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.torontosun.com/entertainment/music/2011/02/07/17179721-wenn-story.html|title=Aguilera sorry for Super Bowl fumble|work=[[Toronto Sun]]|date=December 12, 2010|accessdate=February 7, 2011}}</ref> She performed at the opening act of the [[53rd Annual Grammy Awards]], alongside [[Jennifer Hudson]], [[Martina McBride]], [[Yolanda Adams]], and [[Florence Welch]], paying tribute to [[Aretha Franklin]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Semigran|first=Aly|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1657852/christina-aguilera-jennifer-hudson-aretha-franklin-grammy-tribute/|title=Christina Aguilera, Jennifer Hudson Belt Out Aretha Franklin Grammy Tribute|publisher=MTV News|date=February 13, 2011|accessdate=December 4, 2012}}</ref> In April 2011, Aguilera served as a coach on the television series ''[[The Voice (U.S. TV series)|The Voice]]'' and went on for its three first seasons until December 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6281721/christina-aguilera-gwen-stefani-shakira-voice-poll|title=Christina Aguilera, Gwen Stefani or Shakira|work=Billboard|date=October 14, 2014|first= Katie|last= Atkinson|accessdate=February 23, 2015}}</ref> During the first season, Aguilera was featured on [[Maroon 5]]'s single "[[Moves like Jagger]]" upon the invitation of the group's lead vocalist and Aguilera's fellow ''The Voice'' coach [[Adam Levine]]. The single peaked atop ''Billboard'' Hot 100 and became one of the [[List of best-selling singles|best-selling digital singles worldwide]] with 7 million copies sold.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/1172581/maroon-5-and-christina-aguileras-moves-like-jagger-struts-to-no-1-on|title=Maroon 5 and Christina Aguilera's 'Moves Like Jagger' Struts To No. 1 on Billboard Hot 100|work=Billboard|date=August 31, 2011|first=Gary|last=Trust|accessdate=August 31, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicweek.com/news/read/bruno-mars-claims-2-best-selling-digital-songs-of-2011/047866|title=Bruno Mars claims 2 best-selling digital songs of 2011|work=[[Music Week]]|date=January 23, 2012|accessdate=March 8, 2012}}</ref>
===2012–2017: ''Lotus'', and television projects=== Aguilera's seventh studio album ''[[Lotus (Christina Aguilera album)|Lotus]]'' was released in November 2012. She described it as a "rebirth" of herself after the personal struggles she had overcome during the ''Bionic'' album era.<ref name="CareerBiggest">{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/list/474045/christina-aguileras-top-10-biggest-career-moments?page=0%2C2 |title=Christina Aguilera's Top 10 Biggest Career Moments |work=Billboard |date=November 21, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QmnwPM1s?url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/list/474045/christina-aguileras-top-10-biggest-career-moments?page=0,2 |archivedate=July 3, 2014 |first=Jason |last=Lipshutz |deadurl=no }}</ref> It peaked at number seven on the ''Billboard'' 200 and has sold 290,000 copies in the United States.<ref name="AskBillboardCareer"/> The album has become her least commercially successful album so far.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/thesound/a439874/what-happened-to-christina-aguilera.html|title=What happened to Christina Aguilera?|publisher=Digital Spy|first=Nick|last=Levine|accessdate=November 21, 2012}}</ref> The album was preceded by two singles, "[[Your Body (Christina Aguilera song)|Your Body]]" and "[[Just a Fool]]". During the promotion of ''Lotus'' in December 2012, Aguilera was temporarily replaced by [[Shakira]] for the [[The Voice (U.S. season 4)|fourth season of ''The Voice'']] and returned for [[The Voice (U.S. season 5)|the fifth season]] in September 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/474926/the-voice-locks-in-fourth-fifth-seasons-on-nbc|first=David|last=Greenwald|title='The Voice' Locks In Fourth, Fifth Seasons on NBC|work=Billboard|date=September 25, 2012|accessdate=June 20, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/462458/the-voice-season-5-premiere-coaches-christina-aguilera-and-cee-lo-green-make-a-triumphant-return|title=The Voice Season 5 Premiere: Coaches Christina Aguilera and Cee Lo Green Make a Triumphant Return|first=Leanne|last=Aguilera|publisher=E! Online|date=September 23, 2013|accessdate=June 20, 2014}}</ref>
[[File:Christina Aguilera at the Breakthrough Prize Scientists, 2014.jpg|thumb|upright|Aguilera performing at the [[Breakthrough Prize]] in 2014]] While Aguilera's seventh studio album ''Lotus'' was commercially unsuccessful, she subsequently found her revitalized success through collaborations with other artists. She was featured on [[Pitbull (rapper)|Pitbull]]'s single "[[Feel This Moment]]" in January 2013, which peaked at number eight on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 and was certified double platinum by the RIAA.<ref name="AguileraBBCharts"/> She subsequently appeared on Mexican singer [[Alejandro Fernández]]'s cover of "[[Hoy Tengo Ganas de Ti#Alejandro Fernández version|Hoy Tengo Ganas de Ti]]", which earned a diamond certification in Mexico.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amprofon.com.mx/certificaciones-amprofon.php?key=Alejandro+Fern%C3%A1ndez&action=Buscar&anio=&disquera=&tipoAlbum=&tipoCertificacion=|title=Certificaciones Amprofon|language=es|publisher=[[Asociación Mexicana de Productores de Fonogramas y Videogramas]]|accessdate=February 6, 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141022235531/http://www.amprofon.com.mx/certificaciones-amprofon.php?key=Alejandro+Fern%C3%A1ndez&action=Buscar&anio=&disquera=&tipoAlbum=&tipoCertificacion=|archivedate=October 22, 2014}}</ref> Aguilera's duet of "[[Say Something (A Great Big World song)|Say Something]]" with [[A Great Big World]], released in November 2013, was met with critical acclaim and commercial success, earning a six-time platinum certification from the RIAA and winning a [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Duo/Group Performance]].<ref name="RIAA"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/awards/57th-annual-grammy-awards|title=57th Annual Grammy Awards|publisher=[[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]]|accessdate=February 6, 2018}}</ref>
For the [[The Voice (U.S. season 6)|sixth]] and [[The Voice (U.S. season 7)|seventh]] seasons of ''The Voice'', Aguilera was respectively replaced by Shakira and [[Gwen Stefani]], clarifying that she wanted to devote her time to her family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/shakira-usher-return-voice-season-6-article-1.1551737|title=Shakira, Usher returning to 'The Voice' for Season 6|first=Zayda|last=Rivera|work=New York Daily News|date=December 18, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140906051505/http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/shakira-usher-return-voice-season-6-article-1.1551737|archivedate=September 6, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/christina-aguilera-gwen-stefani-the-voice-confirms-coach-2014294|title=Christina Aguilera Welcomes Gwen Stefani to The Voice, Confirms Singer's Role as Season 7 Coach|work=Us Weekly|date=April 29, 2014|accessdate=February 23, 2015}}</ref> She subsequently returned as a coach for the eighth and tenth seasons; for the latter she won with her contestant [[Alisan Porter]] and became the first female coach to win the show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/6281700/christina-aguilera-returning-the-voice-season-8|title=Goodbye, Gwen: Christina Aguilera Returning to 'The Voice'|date=October 14, 2014|work=Billboard|first=Joe|last=Lynch|accessdate=January 3, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/alisan-porter-makes-christina-aguilera-first-winning-female-voice-coach/|title=Alisan Porter makes Christina Aguilera first winning female "Voice" coach|work=CBS News|last=Park|first=Andrea|date=May 25, 2016|accessdate=May 28, 2016}}</ref>
In April 2015, Aguilera played a recurring role as singer Jade St. John on the third season of [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s musical drama series ''[[Nashville (season 3)|Nashville]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Berman|first1=Eliza|title=Watch Christina Aguilera Vamp It Up on a Sneak Peak From Nashville|work=Time|date=April 9, 2015|url=http://time.com/3816030/christina-aguilera-nashville/|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}</ref> In March 2016, Aguilera and Rutler were announced as executive producers for a new music-based game show, ''Tracks'', to air on [[Spike TV]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wagmeister|first1=Elizabeth|title=Christina Aguilera Producing Music Game Show for Spike TV|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/tracks-game-show-christina-aguilera-spike-tv-1201730419/|accessdate=March 16, 2016|work=Variety|date=March 15, 2016}}</ref> Aguilera recorded a song titled "[[Change (Christina Aguilera song)|Change]]", which was dedicated to the victims of the [[2016 Orlando nightclub shooting]] as well as [[Christina Grimmie]], who was fatally shot in Orlando the day before the nightclub shooting, in June 2016. The proceedings were donated to the National Compassion Fund to benefit the victims' families.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/watch-christina-aguilera-belt-orlando-tribute-change-on-kimmel-20160624|title=Watch Christina Aguilera Belt Orlando Tribute 'Change' on 'Kimmel'|work=Rolling Stone|first=Ryan|last=Reed|date=June 24, 2016|accessdate=February 6, 2018}}</ref> She further recorded a disco song titled "[[Telepathy (Christina Aguilera song)|Telepathy]]" featuring [[Nile Rodgers]] for the soundtrack of [[Netflix]] original series ''[[The Get Down]]'' in August 2016,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/08/11/christina-aguilera-telepathy/|title=Christina Aguilera's Telepathy: Xtina returns to the dance floor|first=Joey|last=Nolfl|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=August 11, 2016|accessdate=February 6, 2018}}</ref> contributed as a voice actress for ''[[The Emoji Movie]]'',<ref>{{cite news|last1=French|first1=Megan|last2=Blynn|first2=Jamie|title=Meet Christina Aguilera's 'Emoji Movie' Character Akiko Glitter: First Pic!|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/meet-christina-aguileras-emoji-movie-character-first-pic-w482253|accessdate=May 15, 2017|work=Us Weekly|date=May 15, 2017}}</ref> and was announced to had been cast for the film ''[[Zoe (film)|Zoe]]'' in May 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McNary|first1=Dave|title=Christina Aguilera, Theo James, Rashida Jones Join Sci-Fi Romance 'Zoe'|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/christina-aguilera-theo-james-rashida-jones-romance-zoe-1202404532/|accessdate=May 2, 2017|work=Variety|date=May 1, 2017}}</ref>
===2018: ''Liberation''=== Aguilera released her eighth studio album, titled ''[[Liberation (Christina Aguilera album)|Liberation]]'', on June 15.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://directlyrics.com/christina-aguilera-teases-new-album-liberation-first-single-accelerate-out-may-4-news.html|title=Christina Aguilera Teases New Album "Liberation", First Single "Accelerate" Out May 4? – Directlyrics|work=DirectLyrics|last=Apaza|first=Kevin|date=April 29, 2018|accessdate=April 30, 2018}}</ref> The album debuted at #6 on the ''Billboard'' 200, becoming her seventh US Top 10 album.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Caulfield |first1=Keith |title=5 Seconds of Summer Earn Third No. 1 Album on Billboard 200 Chart With 'Youngblood' |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8462423/5-seconds-of-summer-third-no-1-album-billboard-200-chart |accessdate=July 13, 2018 |work=Billboard |date=June 24, 2018}}</ref> Its lead promo single, "[[Accelerate (Christina Aguilera song)|Accelerate]]", was released on May 3, while second single "[[Fall In Line]]", featuring [[Demi Lovato]], was released on May 20, one day after they performed it together on the [[2018 Billboard Music Awards|2018 ''Billboard'' Music Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://people.com/music/billboard-music-awards-2018-christina-aguilera-demi-lovato-perform-fall-in-line/|title=Christina Aguilera and Demi Lovato to Perform New Song 'Fall in Line' at Billboard Music Awards|date=May 8, 2018|accessdate=May 8, 2018|first=Melody|last=Chiu|work=People}}</ref> She also embarked on the [[Liberation Tour]], her first concert tour in over a decade.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/8455203/christina-aguilera-liberation-tour-dates|title=Christina Aguilera Announces Liberation Tour, First Outing Since 2008|date=May 9, 2018|accessdate=May 9, 2018|first=Kaufman|last=Gil|work=Billboard}}</ref>
==Artistry== ===Voice=== Aguilera is a [[soprano]],<ref name="GuardianSexual">{{cite news|first=Hermione|last=Hoby|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/jun/13/christina-aguilera-interview-bionic|title=Christina Aguilera: 'I'm a very sexual person by nature'|work=The Guardian|date=June 13, 2010|accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref><ref name="EverythingSinging">{{Cite book|title= The Everything Singing Book with CD: From Mastering Breathing Techniques to Performing Live—all You Need to Hit the Right Notes|last= Sheppard|first= Bettina|authorlink= |year= 2008|publisher= Everything Books|location= |isbn= |page= 100|url= https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=FQ4ItFJXHEwC&pg=PA100&lpg=PA100&dq=Christina+Aguilera+AND+soprano#v=onepage&q=Christina%20Aguilera%20AND%20soprano|access-date= November 18, 2017|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180612142344/https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=FQ4ItFJXHEwC&pg=PA100&lpg=PA100&dq=Christina+Aguilera+AND+soprano#v=onepage&q=Christina%20Aguilera%20AND%20soprano|archive-date= June 12, 2018|dead-url= yes|df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url = http://articles.latimes.com/2011/aug/26/home/la-hm-hotprop-christina-aguilera-20110826| title = Christina Aguilera sells Sunset Strip-area home| work=[[Los Angeles Times]]| date=August 26, 2011| accessdate=February 21, 2018| first=Lauren| last=Beale}}</ref> having a [[vocal range]] spanning four octaves (from [[B (musical note)|B♭<sub>2</sub>]] to [[C♯ (musical note)|C♯<sub>7</sub>]]), four notes, a [[semitone]] and the [[whistle register]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/105319/compare-vocal-ranges-of-worlds-greatest-singers/|title=This Interactive Chart Compares the Vocal Ranges of the World's Greatest Singers|first=Samantha|last=Grossman|date=May 20, 2014|accessdate=July 21, 2014|work=Time}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Gayles|first=Contessa|title=10 Things You Didn't Know About 'The Voice' Coach and 'Dirrty' Pop Star Christina Aguilera|url=http://blog.music.aol.com/2011/05/24/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-the-voice-christina-aguilera/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110601042700/http://blog.music.aol.com/2011/05/24/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-the-voice-christina-aguilera|archivedate=June 1, 2011|date=May 24, 2011|publisher=[[AOL]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9Tps19W_vgg|title=Christina Aguilera Vocal Range: G2 - G#5 - Eb7|first=|last=Ruan Fourie|date=May 2, 2017|accessdate=June 21, 2018|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lZOtoek93os|title=Christina Aguilera's live whistle register}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PgpROcvdu-Q|title=Christina Aguilera Soar|first=|last=Juan Mejia|date=May 12, 2012|accessdate=June 21, 2018|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref> Since the start of her career Aguilera's voice has been compared to that of [[Mariah Carey]] and [[Whitney Houston]].<ref name="NYTimesVoice"/> [[David Browne (journalist)|David Browne]] writing for ''The New York Times'' noted that Aguilera's vocal performance was highly influenced by Carey and Houston, sharing that "Aguilera has been one of the foremost practitioners of the overpowering, Category 5 vocal style known as [[melisma]]", and "Ms. Carey, Ms. Houston and Ms. Aguilera, to name its three main champions, are most associated with the period from the late '80s through the late '90s".<ref name="NYTimesVoice">{{cite news|last=Browne|first=David|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 24, 2010|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/26/arts/music/26browne.html|title=Trilling Songbirds Clip Their Wings|accessdate=January 4, 2010}}</ref> A journal by Ann Powers for the ''Los Angeles Times'' said there are influences of [[Barbra Streisand]], [[Gladys Knight]] and [[Aretha Franklin]] on Aguilera's vocal style, opining that the "Aguilera's Streisand-esque tendencies" "[help Aguilera] figure out how to become the 'great singer' she's been dubbed since she released her first single, the wise-beyond-its-years 'Genie in a Bottle', at 18".<ref>{{cite web|last=Powers|first=Ann|work=Los Angeles Times|date=August 15, 2006|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/aug/15/entertainment/et-christina15|title=Old-school? Her?|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130301065054/http://articles.latimes.com/2006/aug/15/entertainment/et-christina15|archivedate=March 1, 2013}}</ref> [[Sasha Frere-Jones]] wrote in ''[[The New Yorker]]'', "Aguilera doesn't need to reincarnate [[Sarah Vaughan]] to be a serious singer. She already is one, in the tradition of nineteen-nineties pop and R&B, skillfully deploying [[melisma]] for razzle-dazzle".<ref name="NewYorker">{{cite news|last=Frere-Jones|first=Sasha|title=Sex Symbols|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2006/09/04/sex-symbols|accessdate=August 12, 2013|work=[[The New Yorker]]|date=September 4, 2006}}</ref> In 2003, Aguilera was placed 5th on MTV's "Best Voices in Music Ever" list,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ranker.com/list/mtv_s-best-voices-in-music-ever-v1/music-lover|title= MTV's Best Voices in Music Ever|work=[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]|date=March 1, 2003|accessdate=July 31, 2015}}</ref> while ranking atop both COVE and Latina magazine's best Pop and Latina vocalist of all time in 2004 and 2013 respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://popdirt.com/christina-aguilera-named-best-vocalist-by-cove/33315/ |title= Christina Aguilera Named Best Vocalist By Cove| publisher=Popdirt|date=October 5, 2004|accessdate=July 31, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latina.com/entertainment/music/best-latin-singers-pop-stars-all-time|title= THE 50 BEST LATINO SINGERS OF ALL TIME!| publisher=Latina Magazine|date=February 8, 2013|accessdate=July 31, 2015}}</ref> In a review for ''[[Liberation (Christina Aguilera album)|Liberation]]'', [[Jon Pareles]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' describes Aguilera's vocal versatility, stating; "Nothing less than high drama suits Christina Aguilera's voice. She can be brassy, tearful, sultry, gritty, breathy, sweet or furious. She can belt and she can tease; she can aim a note as directly as a missile or turn its trajectory into an aerobatic spiral of leaping, quivering, scalloping melismas. Her voice is not an instrument for making modest statements; it's about peaks of self-affirmation, indescribable sensual pleasures, steely counterattacks and abysses of sorrow".<ref name="liberationreview">{{cite news| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/13/arts/music/christina-aguilera-liberation-review.html| title = Christina Aguilera Exults in Her Voice on 'Liberation'| work=[[The New York Times]] |date=June 13, 2018|accessdate=June 14, 2018| first=Jon| last=Parales}}</ref>
Aguilera has, however, been criticized for her excessive use of melisma and [[oversinging]] on songs and in concerts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-17039208|title=Whitney Houston and the art of melisma|first=Lauren|last=Everitt|publisher=BBC News|date=February 15, 2012|accessdate=July 11, 2014}}</ref><ref name="EWOver">{{cite web|last=William|first=Chris|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=December 11, 2001|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,91277,00.html|title=Genie at Full Throttle|accessdate=July 11, 2014}}</ref><ref name="MTVOver">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1523040/the-scourge-of-american-idol-oversingers/|title=The Scourge Of 'American Idol': Oversingers|first=Corey|last=Moss|publisher=MTV News|date=February 2, 2006|accessdate=July 11, 2014}}</ref><ref name="SeattleOver">{{cite web|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/entertainment/2003633250_oversinging26.html |title=Wo-o-o, whoa: Stop oversinging! |first=Preston |last=Jones |work=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]] |date=March 26, 2007 |accessdate=July 11, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fseattletimes.com%2Fhtml%2Fentertainment%2F2003633250_oversinging26.html&date=2013-02-02 |archivedate=February 2, 2013 }}</ref> John Eskow of ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' named Aguilera a main proponent for "oversouling", described as the "gratuitous and confected melisma".<ref>{{cite news|last=Eskow|first=John|title=Christina Aguilera and the Hideous Cult of Oversouling|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/john-eskow/christina-aguilera-and-th_b_819979.html|accessdate=December 5, 2012|work=The Huffington Post|date=February 8, 2011}}</ref> Lucy Davies, a writer for [[BBC Music]], opined that although Aguilera had "a stunning voice", she "could be more varied, simply by cutting out some of the 'y-e-e-eeeh, woah yeh's'".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Davies|first1=Lucy|title=Christina Aguilera Back to Basics Review|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/4g25|publisher=[[BBC Music]]|accessdate=June 15, 2014|date=August 14, 2006}}</ref> Longtime producer [[Linda Perry]], who wrote the song "Beautiful", revealed about the recording sessions with Aguilera, "I tried to keep it straight. I told her to get rid of the finger waves. Every time she'd start going into 'hoo-ha', I'd stop the tape. I'm like, 'You're doing it again'". Perry ended up using the song's first take adding, "She had a hard time accepting that as the final track. She's a perfectionist. She knows her voice really well, and she knows what's going on. She can hear things that nobody else would catch."<ref>{{cite web|last=Hiatt |first=Brian |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=October 29, 2002 |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,385297_2,00.html |title='Dirrty' Work (page 2) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070619120647/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C385297_2%2C00.html |archivedate=June 19, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> An editor from ''Entertainment Weekly'', Chris Willman, stated that the oversinging on Aguilera's albums was inspired by Carey, writing that "the Mariah venerators don't get away with it so easily. Aguilera, for one thing, has a slightly nasal tone that really only becomes obvious when she's overselling a song".<ref name="EWOver"/>
===Influences=== [[File:Etta James 2006.jpg|thumb|upright|Aguilera cites [[Etta James]] ''(pictured)'' as her main influence]] Aguilera has credited blues singer [[Etta James]] as her main influence and inspiration, elaborating, "Etta is my all-time favorite singer. I've said it for the last seven years – since I had my first debut record out – in every interview".<ref name="EttaJames">{{cite news|last=Vineyard|first=Jennifer|date=June 28, 2006|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1535359/christina-aguilera-can-die-happy-shes-bonded-with-bad-girl-idol-etta-james/|title=Christina Aguilera Can Die Happy – She's Bonded With 'Bad Girl' Idol Etta James|publisher=MTV News|accessdate=June 12, 2014}}</ref> Following James' death in 2012, Aguilera was asked to perform "[[At Last]]" at James' funeral.<ref>{{cite news|last=Martinez|first=Michael|title=Etta James remembered as an authentic voice at funeral|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/01/28/showbiz/etta-james-funeral/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=January 29, 2012|date=January 28, 2012}}</ref> Prior to the performance, Aguilera revealed, "There's a line in this song that says 'I found a dream that I could speak to.' And for me that dream, all my life, has been Etta James".<ref>{{cite web|last=Farley|first=Christopher|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=January 29, 2012|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2012/01/29/christina-aguilera-sings-at-last-at-etta-james-funeral/|title=Christina Aguilera Sings 'At Last' at Etta James Funeral|accessdate=June 12, 2014}}</ref> Other classic artists, including [[Billie Holiday]], [[Otis Redding]], [[Aretha Franklin]], [[Nina Simone]], and [[Ella Fitzgerald]], are also Aguilera's major influences; her fifth studio album ''Back to Basics'' is inspired by vintage jazz, blues and soul music records by them.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Moss|first1=Corey|title=Christina's New Split-Personality Album Is Mature And 'Dirrty'|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1529698/christinas-new-split-personality-album-is-mature-and-dirrty/|accessdate=June 15, 2014|publisher=MTV News|date=April 27, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Vineyard|first1=Jennifer|last2=Norris|first2=John|last3=Edwards|first3=Luc|title=Christina Aguilera's Old Soul|url=http://www.mtv.com/bands/a/aguilera_christina/news_feature_080906/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140805022136/http://www.mtv.com/bands/a/aguilera_christina/news_feature_080906/|archivedate=August 5, 2014|accessdate=June 15, 2014|publisher=MTV News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1531567/for-the-record-quick-news-on-christina-aguilera-jennifer-lopez-snoop-dogg-jessica-simpson-bjork-more/|title=For The Record: Quick News On Christina Aguilera, Jennifer Lopez, Snoop Dogg, Jessica Simpson, Bjork & More|publisher=MTV News|date=May 11, 2006|accessdate=February 23, 2015}}</ref>
Aguilera mentions [[Whitney Houston]] as another influence,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stylist.co.uk/home/whitney-houston-singers-she-inspired|work=[[Stylist (magazine)|Stylist]]|title=Whitney Houston's protégées: Christina Aguilera|accessdate=June 18, 2014|first=Anna|last=Pollitt|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714185522/http://www.stylist.co.uk/home/whitney-houston-singers-she-inspired|archivedate=July 14, 2014}}</ref> having performed many of her songs in her early years during talent shows.<ref name="WashingtonPost"/> She also cites [[Mariah Carey]] and [[Celine Dion]] as an inspiration, and covered the latter's songs: "These Are the Special Times" on ''[[My Kind of Christmas]]'', and "[[The Prayer (Celine Dion and Andrea Bocelli song)|The Prayer]]" on the NBC reality singing competition ''[[The Voice (U.S. season 2)|The Voice]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=A Matter of Time Christina Aguilera Says She'll Leave The Pack, Including Britney Spears in the Dust|work=[[Hartford Courant]]|last=Catlin|first=Roger|page=10|date=August 31, 2000}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UoINJdqVsdw |title=Christina Aguilera talks about Celine Dion |publisher=YouTube |date=April 26, 2013 |accessdate=April 18, 2014}}</ref> Aguilera's debut album producer Ron Harris revealed that Aguilera during her recording sessions for ''[[Christina Aguilera (album)|Christina Aguilera]]'' would constantly listen [[Brandy Norwood|Brandy]]'s music, studying and trying to replicate her adlibs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bS2ncjBBC2k|title=Film & Music Industry Forum - Ron Harris 3-7-16|first=|last=Loyola University Film and Music Industry Studies|date=May 3, 2016|accessdate=June 21, 2018|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref> According to author Pier Dominguez of the book ''Christina Aguilera: A Star is Made'', Aguilera stated that Carey and her debut single, "[[Vision of Love]]" (1990), had the biggest influence on her vocal style.<ref>{{harvnb|Dominguez|2003|page=134}}</ref> Aguilera points out the musical film ''[[The Sound of Music (film)|The Sound of Music]]'' and its lead actress, [[Julie Andrews]], as her first inspiration for singing and performing.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rosen|first=Craig|url=http://music.yahoo.com/read/story/12058962|title=Christina Aguilera Climbs Every Mountain For 'My Kind Of Christmas'|publisher=Yahoo! Music|date=September 29, 2000|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110524205307/http://music.yahoo.com/read/story/12058962|archivedate=May 24, 2011 }}</ref> At the age of six, the film helped Aguilera cope with her violent childhood, "Bad things happened in my home; there was violence. ''The Sound of Music'' looked like a form of release."<ref name="WMagazine"/> Aguilera credits [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] and [[Janet Jackson]] as two biggest inspirations for her image, "for being re-inventive and being brave as strong females, to explore whatever, even if they do get bad press. It's just like they were fearless."<ref>{{Cite news|last=Sculley|first=Alan|title=What Christina wants|newspaper=[[The Patriot Ledger]]|page=17|date=September 8, 2000}}</ref> During the promotion of ''Back to Basics'', her image was also inspired by the "Golden age of Hollywood" actresses including [[Marlene Dietrich]], [[Marilyn Monroe]], [[Carole Lombard]], [[Greta Garbo]] and [[Veronica Lake]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Moss|first1=Corey|title=Christina Channels Marilyn Monroe For Intimate Album Cover|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1535431/christina-channels-marilyn-monroe-for-intimate-album-cover/|accessdate=June 15, 2014|publisher=MTV News|date=June 29, 2006}}</ref> Aguilera is also inspired by her ''Burlesque'' co-star, [[Cher]]: "I have always had tremendous respect for her. She is a woman who did everything before anyone else did it. She is an icon and she inspired me through some of my career. We've had similar costumes too!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/offbeat/articles/2010/02/08/20100208christina-aguilera.html|title=Christina Aguilera inspired by Cher|work=[[The Arizona Republic]]|date=February 8, 2010|accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref>
===Musical style and themes=== [[File:Understand - Christina Aguilera.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Aguilera performing during her [[Back to Basics Tour]] in 2006]] Aguilera frequently blends elements of pop, [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[dance-pop]] and [[soul music|soul]] music into her projects,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/07/arts/music/07choice.html|title=New CDs|first=Jon|last=Pareles|authorlink=Jon Pareles|newspaper=The New York Times|date=June 6, 2010|accessdate=June 7, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/2004-03-04/music/ladies-night-out-tour/|title=Ladies Night Out Tour|work=[[Dallas Observer]]|quote=With all the attention lavished on female R&B stars like [...] Christina Aguilera|date=March 4, 2004|first=Mikael|last=Wood|accessdate=February 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Genie out of a bottle|first=Peter|last=Holder|first2=Jo|last2=Casamento|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)]]|location=Australia|page=16|date=March 10, 2000}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qN6fAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA164&lpg=PA164&dq=christina+aguilera+electropop+artist+singer#v=onepage&q=christina+aguilera+electropop+artist+singer|title=Pitbull - Mr. Worldwide|first=C.|last=Duthel|publisher=Lulu.com|accessdate=June 21, 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref> her records typically include a combination of ballads and uptempo tracks.<ref name="NYTimesShrunk">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/17/arts/music/17sann.html|title=Honey They've Shrunk the Pop Stars (but Christina Aguilera Fights On)|first=Kelefa|last=Sanneh|work=The New York Times|date=August 17, 2006|accessdate=July 9, 2014}}</ref> ''Christina Aguilera'' (1999) prominently displayed [[teen pop]] and dance-pop music,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/christina-aguilera-mw0000244313|title=Christina Aguilera – Christina Aguilera|first=Stephen Thomas|last=Erlewine|publisher=AllMusic|accessdate=July 9, 2014}}</ref> while ''Mi Reflejo'' (2000) takes inspiration from [[Latin music (genre)|Latin music]].<ref name="MiReflejoNYPost">{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2000/09/12/christinas-a-winner-in-spanish-too/|title=Christina's a winner in Spanish, too|last=Aquilante|first=Dan|newspaper=New York Post|date=September 12, 2000|accessdate=May 31, 2013}}</ref> Her first Christmas album, ''My Kind of Christmas'', combines covers of Christmas standards and several original dance-pop tracks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/my-kind-of-christmas-mw0000100386 |title=My Kind of Christmas by Christina Aguilera on AllMusic |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AeKy4Z9e?url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/my-kind-of-christmas-mw0000100386 |archivedate=September 13, 2012 |accessdate=September 13, 2012 |publisher=AllMusic |first=Stephen |last=Erlewine |deadurl=no }}</ref> Aiming for musical diversity and artistic growth, Aguilera worked with R&B, rock, [[hip hop music|hip hop]], and Latin music for ''Stripped'' (2002).<ref name="NotYourPuppet"/><ref name="Stripped">{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,384149~4~0~stripped,00.html |title=Stripped Review |author=David Browne |work=Entertainment Weekly |publisher=Time Inc. |date=November 1, 2002 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012121321/http://ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C384149~4~0~stripped%2C00.html |archivedate=October 12, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> David Browne from ''Entertainment Weekly'' credited the release with distancing Aguilera from her pop contemporaries.<ref name="Stripped"/> Aguilera leaned towards R&B, [[blues]], jazz, and [[Soul music|soul]] on ''Back to Basics'' (2006).<ref name="B2BMusic"/><ref name="LATimes">{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/mar/07/entertainment/et-aguilera7|title=Props mistress|last=Powers|first=Ann|work=Los Angeles Times|date=March 7, 2007|accessdate=May 28, 2013}}</ref><ref name="TheObserver">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2006/aug/13/shopping.christinaaguilera|title=Christina Aguilera, Back to Basics|first=Paul|last=Flynn|newspaper=[[The Observer]]|date=August 12, 2006|accessdate=May 3, 2013}}</ref>
In contrast, ''Bionic'' (2010) sees significant use from futuristic [[electronic music]], described as an [[electropop]] album.<ref name="ElectronicBionic"/><ref name="AllMusic">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/bionic-mw0001989957|title=Bionic – Christina Aguilera {{!}} Overview|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|first=Thomas|last=Stephen Erlewine|authorlink=Stephen Thomas Erlewine|accessdate=August 8, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120711102448/http://www.allmusic.com/album/bionic-mw0001989957|archivedate=July 11, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D05E6D71230F934A35752C1A9669D8B63|title=For Gays, New Songs of Survival (page 2)|work=[[The New York Times]]|first=Alex|last=Hagwood|date=November 7, 2010|accessdate=August 16, 2014}}</ref> The soundtrack for her 2010 feature film ''[[Burlesque (2010 American film)|Burlesque]]'' (2010) was influenced by ''Cabaret'', and featured several established songs that were redone as dance numbers in a fashion similar to ''Moulin Rouge!'' (2001).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2007/film/news/screen-gems-enlists-antin-for-burlesque-1117974104/|title=Screen Gems enlists Antin for 'Burlesque'|work=Variety|date=October 15, 2007|first=Michael|last= Fleming|accessdate=February 23, 2015}}</ref> Aguilera partnered with mainstream producers including [[Shellback (producer)|Shellback]] and [[Max Martin]] during production of ''Lotus'' (2012); when discussing her interactions with the latter, she commented that "He's known about me but we haven't crossed paths," adding "Those records were the kind I wanted to stray apart from. If you look at what I did in the past (after my debut), I always try to do things that will challenge me and challenge the listener, too."<ref name="Billboard Cover">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/474983/christina-aguilera-billboard-cover-story|title=Christina Aguilera: Billboard Cover Story|last=Hampp|first=Andrew|work=Billboard|date=September 21, 2012|accessdate=July 29, 2014}}</ref>
Aguilera has commented that she feels a sense of responsibility to reference portions of her personal life so that "people that can relate might not feel as alone in the circumstance." Many of her works consequently discuss love; she has also co-written two tracks which dealt with the domestic abuse throughout her childhood.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/57547/basic-instinct|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114034718/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/57547/basic-instinct|title='Basic' Instinct|work=Billboard|date=August 13, 2006|archivedate=January 14, 2009 }}</ref> Aguilera has frequently mentioned [[feminism]] in her music; she has expressed her belief that sexuality is "very empowering", and has commented that "If I want to be sexual, it's for my own appreciation and enjoyment! That's why I like to talk about the fact that sometimes I am attracted to women. I appreciate their femininity and beauty."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20393540,00.html|title=Christina Aguilera: Why I'm Sometimes Attracted to Women|last=Oh|first=Eunice|work=People|date=June 11, 2010|accessdate=May 11, 2013}}</ref> She has alluded to her physical attractions to women in other interviews as well.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stein|first1=Joshua David|title=Christina Aguilera Reclaims The Fame|url=https://www.out.com/entertainment/music/2010/05/16/christina-aguilera-reclaims-fame|work=Out Magazine|publisher=Here Publishing Inc.|date=May 16, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Bendix|first1=Trish|title=Christina Aguilera: What she's said about her sexuality|url=http://www.afterellen.com/people/80238-christina-aguilera-what-shes-said-about-her-sexuality|work=After Ellen|publisher=Evolve Media LLC|date=October 15, 2010|quote=Two women are way sexier than two men in bed. We have a better feel for our bodies. I love experimenting with my sexuality. [...] If that means girls then so be it. It would be wrong to hide this side of my personality. [...] I don't get to kiss all the girls and the boys, but my husband knows that I get into girls. I think it's fun to be open and play. ... I definitely love women. I think they're more attractive to the naked eye.}}</ref> Her "Can't Hold Us Down" from ''Stripped'' denounces gender-related [[double standard]]s, in which men are applauded for their sexual behaviors, while women who behave in a similar fashion are disdained.<ref>{{harvnb|Railton|Watson|2011|page=88}}</ref> The main theme of ''Bionic'' was also about woman empowerment; Hermione Hoby from ''[[The Guardian]]'' opined that "she incites more of a sisterly spirit of collaboration, including riot grrrl feminists [[Le Tigre]]. Aguilera's not shy of the odd feministic declaration herself."<ref name="GuardianSexual"/> In regards to production, Aguilera has often verbalized her preference of working with more "obscure" collaborators, and noted that she is not necessarily inclined to contact "the No.1 chart-toppers in music" because of their popular demand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/58465/new-aguilera-album-set-for-august|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114030752/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/58465/new-aguilera-album-set-for-august|title=New Aguilera Album Set For August|last=Cohen|first=Jonathan|work=Billboard|date=June 11, 2006|archivedate=January 14, 2009 }}</ref> ''The New York Times''{{'}} Kelefa Sanneh described her decision to work with [[DJ Premier]] on ''Back to Basics'' as "a decision to snub some of the big-name producers on whom pop stars often rely."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/17/arts/music/17sann.html|title=Honey They've Shrunk the Pop Stars|last=Sanneh|first=Kelefa|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 17, 2006|accessdate=July 8, 2009}}</ref>
==Image== Aguilera has reinvented her public image on numerous occasions throughout her career.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.chron.com//handstamp/2007/02/christina-aguilera-claims-her-pop-throne/ |title=Christina Aguilera claims her pop throne |work=[[Houston Chronicle]] |first=Joey |last=Guerra |date=February 20, 2007 |accessdate=July 17, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6WEW0UaKu?url=http://blog.chron.com//newswatch/2011/04/ktru-station-off-air-but-still-broadcasting-online/ |archivedate=February 10, 2015 }}</ref> In the later 1990s, her then-manager Steve Kurtz marketed her as a bubblegum pop entertainer to capitalize on the genre's financial lure,<ref name="USAToday"/> which earned her recognition as a [[teen idol]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/shows/the_greatest/episode.jhtml?episodeID=67297 |title=50 Greatest Teen Idols |publisher=VH1 |accessdate=July 19, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209143618/http://www.vh1.com/shows/the_greatest/episode.jhtml?episodeID=67297 |archivedate=February 9, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Aguilera introduced her [[alter ego]] "Xtina" during 2002 and 2003, which presented an increasingly provocative persona.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2002/10/29/1035683410806.html|title=Aguilera sheds teen pop image, alongside clothes|date=October 30, 2002|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=July 17, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.virginmedia.com/music/features/alter-egos.php?page=6 |title=Christina Aguilera = Xtina |publisher=[[Virgin Media]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6WYKGhfBU?url=http://www.virginmedia.com/music/features/alter-egos.php?page=6 |archivedate=February 23, 2015 |deadurl=no }}</ref> During this time, she dyed her hair black, debuted several piercings, and participated in several nude pictorials for publications.<ref name="CareerBiggest"/> In 2004, Aguilera embraced a more "mature" image with retro-styled hair and makeup, which was inspired by classic movie stars including Marilyn Monroe, [[Marlene Dietrich]] and [[Mary Pickford]].<ref name="HelloMag"/> This reinvention was named "Baby Jane" in 2006, an alter ego which was taken from the 1962 film ''[[What Ever Happened to Baby Jane? (1962 film)|What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1539161/christina-clip-got-a-boost-from-outkast-role-playing-dancers-vmas-behind-the-camera/|title=Christina Clip Got A Boost From Outkast, Role-Playing Dancers|publisher=MTV News|first=Jennifer|last=Vineyard|date=August 23, 2006|accessdate=June 23, 2013}}</ref> Aguilera received widespread criticism over her curvy figure from gaining weight in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/christina-aguilera-fat-girl-article-1.1171905|title=Christina Aguilera on her curvy, controversial figure: 'I got tired of being a skinny, white girl'|first=Joyce|last=Chen|work=New York Daily News|date=October 1, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141014134839/http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/christina-aguilera-fat-girl-article-1.1171905|archivedate=October 14, 2014}}</ref> She later received favorable media attention after a significant weight loss in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/christina-aguilera-weight-loss-how-did-she-do-it-1411294|title=Christina Aguilera Weight Loss: How Did She Do It?|publisher=[[International Business Times]]|first=Amethyst|last=Tate|date=September 26, 2013|accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> In 2018 Aguilera appeared bare-faced without makeup and [[photo manipulation|retouching]] on the cover of [[Paper magazine]] and received widespread praise.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thisisinsider.com/christina-aguilera-no-makeup-paper-magazine-cover-shaming-2018-3|title=People are praising Christina Aguilera for her makeup-free photoshoots|date= March 27, 2018 |work=INSIDER}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/26/entertainment/christina-aguilera-no-makeup-paper-magazine/index.html|title=Christina Aguilera goes makeup free for Paper|date= March 27, 2018 |work=[[CNN]]}}</ref>
[[File:Aguilera Madame Tussauds.jpg|thumb|upright|Wax figure of Aguilera at [[Madame Tussauds]] in London]] Aguilera is considered a pop icon,<ref name="Reuters">{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/02/idUS169214+02-Apr-2012+PRN20120402 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6NCNMPoOJ?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/02/idUS169214+02-Apr-2012+PRN20120402 |title=Superstar Songstress Britney Spears Will Battle Fellow Pop Princess Christina Aguilera This Week in the Championship Round of the Celebrity Bowling Hall of Fame Tournament |publisher=Reuters |date=April 2, 2012 |archivedate=February 7, 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> and has frequently garnered comparisons to Britney Spears.<ref name="VirginMedia">{{cite web|url=http://www.virginmedia.com/music/features/christina-aguilera-v-britney-spears.php|title=Christina Aguilera v Britney Spears: Who's the best popstar?|first=Matthew|last=Horton|publisher=[[Virgin Media]]|date=August 11, 2012|accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref><ref name="EWCompare">{{cite web|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2011/08/16/britney-spears-christina-aguilera-showdown/|title=Britney Spears vs. Christina Aguilera: Who's the greater turn-of-the-millennium pop diva?|first=Melissa|last=Maerz|date=August 16, 2013|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> David Browne of ''Entertainment Weekly'' said that Aguilera is "too eager not to offend" in her mild-mannered music, making her a "good girl pretending to be bad", and also said that Spears' "artificial-sweetener voice" was a welcome change of pace from Aguilera's "numbing vocal gymnastics".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,64697,00.html|title=Oops!... I Did It Again Review|first=David|last=Browne|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=July 17, 2009|date=May 19, 2000}}</ref> Matthew Horton from [[Virgin Media]] suggested that Aguilera was a more impressive performer than Spears despite her lower sales figures.<ref name="VirginMedia"/> Aguilera has also been regarded as a [[sex symbol]].<ref name="NewYorker"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Sanneh|first=Kelefa|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/08/arts/the-new-season-music-idol-returns-her-image-remade.html|title=The New Season/Music Idol Returns|work=The New York Times|date=February 13, 2012|accessdate=May 13, 2013}}</ref> A 2003 issue of ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]'' magazine that she covered became its best-selling issue;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maxim.com/girls-of-maxim/christina-aguilera|title=Christina Aguilera|work=Maxim|date=April 24, 2007|accessdate=July 19, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301161931/http://www.maxim.com/girls-of-maxim/christina-aguilera|archivedate=March 1, 2012}}</ref> Aguilera was named "Sexiest Woman of the Year" by its subscribers later that year,<ref name="Maxim">{{cite web|url=http://www.maxim.com/hot-100/2003-hot-100|title=2003 Hot 100 – Christina Aguilera {{!}} Maxim|work=[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]|date=May 1, 2003|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301161931/http://www.maxim.com/girls-of-maxim/christina-aguilera|archivedate=March 1, 2012}}</ref> and also earned the magazine its best-selling issue after posing on the cover that year.<ref>{{cite news|title=MAXIM Magazine Unveils the 'Hot 100' for 2003|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/maxim-magazine-unveils-the-hot-100-for-2003-55695342.html|accessdate=February 3, 2017|publisher=PR Newswire|date=May 16, 2003}}</ref> Additionally recognized as a gay icon,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1458472/christina-gwen-stefani-dita-von-teese-help-bring-back-burlesque/|title=Christina, Gwen Stefani, Dita Von Teese Help Bring Back Burlesque|author=Edwards, Tanya|publisher=MTV News|date=November 4, 2004|accessdate=October 20, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/arts-entertainment/music/2012/11/28/christina-aguilera-says-lgbt-fans-held-her-when-she-could-not|title=Christina Aguilera Says LGBT Fans Held Her Up When She Couldn't Stand|first=Diane|last=Anderson-Minshall|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|date=November 28, 2012|accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> she was the first honoree on [[The Abbey (club)|The Abbey]]'s Gay Walk of Fame for her contributions to the [[LGBT]] community.<ref name="Abbey">{{cite web|author=Bain, Becky|url=http://idolator.com/5832331/christina-aguilera-the-abbey-gay-walk-of-fame|title=Christina Aguilera Immortalized On Gay Walk Of Fame|publisher=[[Idolator (website)|Idolator]]|accessdate=May 13, 2013}}</ref> The music video for "Beautiful" earned Aguilera a [[14th GLAAD Media Awards|GLAAD Media Award]] for its positive portrayal of the LGBT community.<ref name="GLAAD">{{cite web|url=http://www.glaad.org/media/release_detail.php?id=3359|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050418084316/http://www.glaad.org/media/release_detail.php?id=3359|title=Eric McCormack, Todd Haynes, Christina Aguilera, The Hours, Six Feet Under Honored at 14th Annual GLAAD Media Awards Presented by Absolut Vodka in Los Angeles|publisher=GLAAD|date=April 26, 2003|archivedate=April 18, 2005}}</ref>
Fashion has also been a part of Aguilera's music career and image.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/photos/426310/christina-aguileras-fashion-evolution?i=43845|title=Christina Aguilera's Fashion Evolution|work=Billboard|accessdate=July 25, 2014}}</ref> She has frequently worn clothes designed by [[Roberto Cavalli]], [[John Galliano]], [[Marc Jacobs]], and [[Alexander McQueen]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Alexander, Hilary |date=July 7, 2005 |work=The Daily Telegraph |url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/article/TMG3342005/Galliano-celebrates-100-years-of-Dior-with-his-own-new-look.html |title=Galliano celebrates 100 years of Dior with his own 'new look' |accessdate=November 20, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140108212736/http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/article/TMG3342005/Galliano-celebrates-100-years-of-Dior-with-his-own-new-look.html |archivedate=January 8, 2014 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Morley-Cartner, Jess|date=June 4, 2004|newspaper=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2004/jun/04/jesscartnermorleyonfashion.arts|title=The old black McQueen in London for charity|accessdate=November 20, 2009}}</ref> During the Back to Basics Tour in 2006, Aguilera performed in a stole made of fur designed by Roberto Cavalli, unaware that it was made from real fur of a white fox. After receiving a video about the treatment of foxes from [[PETA]] vice president [[Dan Mathews]], Aguilera replaced it with a faux-fur stole, further stating that she was "very upset" because she "only ever wears fake fur".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peta.org/blog/christina-aguileras-costume-change/|title=Christina Aguilera Costume Change|publisher=[[PETA]]|date=December 12, 2006|accessdate=July 25, 2014}}</ref> Aguilera's costumes from ''Burlesque'' were featured in the [[Fashion Institute of Design & Merchandising]]'s Art of Motion Picture Costume Design exhibition.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://travel.usatoday.com/destinations/story/2011/02/Oscar-nominated-fashions-on-display-at-LA-museum/43906488/1|title=Oscar-nominated fashions on display at L.A. museum|last=Cohen|first=Sandy|newspaper=USA Today|date=February 20, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140906051939/http://travel.usatoday.com/destinations/story/2011/02/Oscar-nominated-fashions-on-display-at-LA-museum/43906488/1|archivedate=September 6, 2014}}</ref> Wax figures of Aguilera are located at [[Madame Tussauds]] wax museum in London and New York City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.madametussaudswaxmuseum.com/branches/madame-tussauds-london.htm
