{{orphan|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Elizabeth Vianna | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_place = [[Sao Paulo]], [[Brazil]] | residence = [[Sonoma, California]] | education = [[Masters degree Science|B.A]] in Biology
M.Sc. in Fermentation Science, 1999 | alma_mater = [[Vassar College]]
[[University of California, Davis]] | occupation = Winemaker | years_active = 1999 - present | employer = Chimney Rock | spouse = }} '''Elizabeth Vianna''' is a female [[Winemaking|winemaker]] and businesswoman who has been responsible for some of California's most notable [[Cabernet Sauvignon|Cabernet]] wines.{{Cite news|url=https://inthemix.on-premise.com/2015/01/take-5-interview-elizabeth-vianna/|title=Take 5: Interview with Elizabeth Vianna - in the Mix Magazine|date=2015-01-21|work=in the Mix Magazine|access-date=2017-12-11}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n5b_qpeCvG8C&pg=PA194&dq=elizabeth+vianna&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi8l5fe3YDYAhUkSN8KHaQwB3UQ6AEIYDAJ#v=onepage&q=elizabeth%20vianna&f=false|title=The New Connoisseurs' Guidebook to California Wine and Wineries|last=Olken|first=Charles E.|last2=Furstenthal|first2=Joseph|date=2010-10-28|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520253131}} She is one of America's few [[Latino|Latina]] winemakers,{{Cite news|url=http://napavalleyregister.com/star/wine/rhythm-and-texture-the-music-of-wine/article_947b6785-3353-5c76-b2f6-7be825cb34cc.html|title=Rhythm and texture — the music of wine|last=CARL|first=TIM|work=Napa Valley Register|access-date=2017-12-11}} known for Bordeaux-style wines at Chimney Rock, a part of Terlato Wine Group.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HOGLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PR5&dq=elizabeth+vianna&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi8l5fe3YDYAhUkSN8KHaQwB3UQ6AEIWjAI#v=onepage&q=elizabeth%20vianna&f=false|title=The Winemakers: A Novel of Wine and Secrets|last=Moran|first=Jan|date=2016-04-05|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=9781466850033}} == Career == Vianna came to the wine world by happenstance. She studied Biology in undergrad at Vassar College in New York and worked as a clinical toxicologist after completing her undergraduate education.{{Cite web|url=http://winetable.com/blog/winemaker-in-the-spotlight-elizabeth-vianna/|title=Winemaker in the Spotlight: Elizabeth Vianna - WineTable.com|last=Wines|first=Brian|date=2012-11-16|website=WineTable.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-11}} While living in New York City an working in [[New York Hospital]]-[[Weill Cornell Medicine|Cornell Medical Center]], she tasted a glass of 1985 Sociando Mallet while at an auction at [[Christie's|Chrisie's Auction House]].{{Cite web|url=https://webpages.scu.edu/womenwinemakers/view.php?id=271|title=Women Winemakers of California {{!}}Elizabeth Vianna|website=webpages.scu.edu|access-date=2017-12-11}} This newfound appreciation for wine led her to apply to the [[University of California, Davis]] for a masters program in [[winemaking]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.chimneyrock.com/Philosophy/WinemakingTeam|title=Chimney Rock - Winemaking Team|last=Solutions|first=eWinery|website=www.chimneyrock.com|access-date=2017-12-11}} While in school, Vianna began an internship at Chimney Rock. When she graduated in 1999, Vianna became an enologist at that Napa company, and was named assistant winemaker there in 2002. She then advanced to the position of winemaker in 2005. In 2011, Vianna was promoted to General Manager of the winery, while continuing in her role as head winemaker of this Stags Leap District estate enterprise.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LDAtAQAAMAAJ&q=Elizabeth+Vianna&dq=Elizabeth+Vianna&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi68bL45oDYAhXHRt8KHaX9DBM4FBDoAQgvMAE|title=Bon Appétit|date=January 2010|publisher=Bon Appétit Publishing Corporation}} Over time, Vianna worked with California's top winemakers, including [[Heidi Barrett]], Erin Green, Pam Starr, and Celia Welch. In 2009, Vianna was honored by the [[UC Davis Graduate Studies|UC, Davis School of Graduate Studies]] when she was invited to deliver the commencement speech to the class of 2009.{{Cite news|url=https://www.palatexposure.com/wednesdays-with-winemakers/elizabeth-vianna/|title=Wednesdays with Winemakers - Elizabeth Vianna {{!}} PalateXposure|last=|first=Ilona|date=2016-01-13|work=PalateXposure|access-date=2017-12-11|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} She is frequently selected for tasting panels and judging wine competitions. In 2012, [[PBS]] filmed Vianna's work at Chimney Rock for a six-part [[Television show|TV series]] titled ''Vintage.''{{Cite news|url=http://napavalleyregister.com/wine/pbs-looks-through-winemakers-eyes/article_25472970-849a-11e3-89f7-0019bb2963f4.html|title=PBS looks through winemakers’ eyes|last=|first=|date=|work=Napa Valley Register|access-date=2017-12-11|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.theprimlanikitchen.com/experience-2012-vintage-with-women-winemakers-of-napa-terlatomedia-on-pbs-wine/|title=Experience 2012 Vintage with Women Winemakers of Napa & @terlatomedia on @PBS #wine|date=2015-02-03|work=The Primlani Kitchen|access-date=2017-12-11}} The show took viewers behind-the-scenes at three Napa Valley wineries during the 2012 harvest season.{{Citation|title=Vintage: Napa Valley 2012 {{!}} WTTW Promos and Previews {{!}} PBS|url=http://www.pbs.org/video/wttw-specials-vintage-napa-valley-2012/|language=en-US|accessdate=2017-12-11}} In 2017, Vianna's vines were almost affected by the [[October 2017 Northern California wildfires|October northern California wildfires]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.winespectator.com/webfeature/show/id/Massive-Wildfires-Devastate-Parts-of-Napa-and-Sonoma+County|title=Massive Wildfires Devastate Parts of Napa and Sonoma County, Burning Wineries and Vineyards {{!}} News {{!}} News & Features {{!}} Wine Spectator|last=Romano|first=Aaron|date=2017-10-09|work=WineSpectator.com|access-date=2017-12-11|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} == See also == * [[List of wine personalities]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Vianna, Elizabeth}} [[Category:American winemakers]] [[Category:American female winemakers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Viticulturists]] [[Category:Wine merchants]] [[Category:University of California, Davis alumni]] [[Category:People from Napa County, California]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2017}}
'''Exposed.su''' was a website focused on the listing of personal information of celebrities and other high-profile figures.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Berman |first1=Taylor |title=Obama, Clinton, Biden, Jay-Z Doxxed: 'Hackers' Snag Financial Records, Socials, Credit Reports |url=http://gawker.com/5990063/obama-clinton-biden-jay-z-doxxed-hackers-snag-financial-records-socials-credit-reports |accessdate=31 August 2015 |date=12 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151019065719/http://gawker.com/5990063/obama-clinton-biden-jay-z-doxxed-hackers-snag-financial-records-socials-credit-reports |archivedate=19 October 2015 |df= }}</ref>
The credit history information appears to have been obtained through the [[Hacker (computer security)|hacking]] of 3 US credit history databases, [[Equifax]], [[Experian]] and [[TransUnion]], possibly by hackers based in a former Soviet Union country.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Adams Otis|first1=Ginger|title=Hackers shut down celebrity site that revealed financial account details of Jay-Z, Beyonce, Ashton Kutcher and more|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/hackers-cash-find-laughs-celebrity-accounts-article-1.1290945|accessdate=31 August 2015|date=16 March 2013}}</ref>
In April 2013 [[Brian Krebs]] linked his [[swatting]] incident to the coverage of this site.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Krebs|first1=Brian|title=SWATting Incidents Tied to ID Theft Sites?|url=http://krebsonsecurity.com/2013/04/swatting-incidents-tied-to-id-theft-sites/#more-19738|accessdate=31 August 2015|date=17 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Krebs|first1=Brian|title=Credit Reports Sold for Cheap in the Underweb|url=http://krebsonsecurity.com/2013/03/credit-reports-sold-for-cheap-in-the-underweb/|accessdate=31 August 2015|date=13 March 2013}}</ref>
The site was shut down on March 2013 before jumping to other domains<ref>{{cite news|last1=J. Schwartz|first1=Mathew|title=Exposed Website Reboots, Reveals Celeb Credit Reports|url=http://www.darkreading.com/risk-management/exposed-website-reboots-reveals-celeb-credit-reports/d/d-id/1109386?|accessdate=31 August 2015|date=4 April 2013}}</ref> and has since been mirrored on the [[Dark Web]].
== References == {{reflist}}

Underwood
Catherine Underwood | alma_mater = The Sentinel
Harvard Law School | office4 = Member of the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] from South Carolina's 5th district | termstart4 = 1991 | termend4 = 2013 | office5 = Member of the [[South Carolina State Senate]] | termstart5 = 1984 | termend5 = 1991 | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] }} '''Francis J. Underwood''' is a fictional character and the protagonist of the American adaptation of ''[[House of Cards (U.S. TV series)|House of Cards]]'', portrayed by [[Kevin Spacey]]. He is depicted as a ruthless politician who rises from [[House Majority Whip]] to [[President of the United States]] through treachery, deception and murder. He is based on [[Francis Urquhart]], the protagonist of the British novel and television series ''[[House of Cards (UK TV series)|House of Cards]]'', from which the American [[Netflix]] series is drawn. He is married to [[Claire Underwood]] ([[Robin Wright]]), but also had a sexual relationship with Zoe Barnes ([[Kate Mara]]) in [[House of Cards (season 1)|season 1]]. He made his first appearance in the series' [[pilot episode]], "[[Chapter 1 (House of Cards)|Chapter 1]]". Underwood is from [[Gaffney, South Carolina]]. He graduated from The Sentinel (a fictionalized version of [[The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina]]) in 1981 and, subsequently, [[Harvard Law School]] in 1984. Some of Underwood's dialogue throughout the series is presented in a direct address to the audience, a narrative technique that breaks the [[fourth wall]]. The character speaks with a [[Southern American English|Southern accent]]. During season 1, he is the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[House Majority Whip|Majority Whip]] in the [[United States House of Representatives]]. In [[House of Cards (season 2)|season 2]], he is the newly appointed [[Vice President of the United States]], before becoming [[President of the United States]] in the season finale. Underwood has been described as conniving, [[Machiavellianism|Machiavellian]], [[antisocial personality disorder|sociopathic]], and a symbol of political corruption. Throughout the series, he manipulates and destroys several people, including those he calls friends, for his own ends. Among other crimes, he personally commits murder twice, signs off on another murder committed by a subordinate, orders the deaths of two former employees, critically injures a member of his cabinet to prevent her testifying against him, and [[False flag|indirectly allows the murder of a civilian for political ends]]. Spacey has received positive reviews for his portrayal of Frank Underwood, but the character itself has been criticized for its repetitive nature{{cite web|first=Rachel|last=Handler|title='House Of Cards' Has Been Renewed For A Fifth Season, But Not Everybody Is Coming Back|url=http://uproxx.com/tv/house-of-cards-beau-willimon-exit/|publisher=uproxx.com|date=January 29, 2016|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}{{cite web|first=Margaret|last=Lyons|title=House of Cards Has a Frank-and-Claire Problem|url=http://www.vulture.com/2015/03/house-of-cards-frank-claire.html|website=[[Vulture.com]]|publisher=[[New York Media]]|location=New York City|date=March 3, 2015|accessdate=July 6, 2016}} and one-dimensionality.{{cite web|first=Aaron|last=Bady|title='House of Cards' Should Stop Trying to Be 'The West Wing'|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/121214/house-cards-should-stop-trying-be-west-wing|work=[[The New Republic]]|date=March 4, 2015|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}{{cite web|first=Alan|last=Sepinwall|title='House of Cards' season 2 in review: It gets weaker the more you watch |url=http://www.hitfix.com/whats-alan-watching/house-of-cards-season-2-in-review-it-gets-weaker-the-more-you-watch|website=hitfix.com|date=April 30, 2014|accessdate=July 6, 2016}} Spacey was one of the first three actors playing leading roles in web-television series to be nominated for [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s at the [[65th Primetime Emmy Awards]]. Spacey has also been nominated for two [[Golden Globe Award]]s, winning one, and five [[Screen Actors Guild Award]]s, including two cast nominations and including two wins, for his performance. On November 3, 2017, following [[sexual assault]] claims made against Spacey, Netflix cut ties with the actor, putting the character's fate in question.{{cite magazine |first=Kate|last=Stanhope|title=Netflix Severs Ties With Kevin Spacey|url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/netflix-officially-severs-ties-kevin-spacey-1054981 |magazine=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date= November 3, 2017 |accessdate= November 4, 2017}} In a teaser trailer for the [[House of Cards (season 6)|sixth season of ''House of Cards'']], it is shown that Underwood died in 2017 and is now buried next to his father in South Carolina.{{Cite web |first=Denise|last=Petski|url=https://deadline.com/2018/09/house-of-cards-frank-underwood-fate-revealed-season-6-teaser-kevin-spacey-robin-wright-1202457517/ |title=‘House Of Cards’: Frank Underwood’s Fate Revealed In Season 6 Teaser |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=September 5, 2018|access-date=September 5, 2018}} ==Background and description== ===Early life=== Francis J. Underwood was born on November 5, 1959, to Catherine and Calvin T. Underwood in [[Gaffney, South Carolina]]. He is an only child. He was raised in impoverished circumstances, with the threat of bank foreclosure on the farm they lived on. He entered The Sentinel, a military school in [[Charleston, South Carolina]], loosely based on [[The Citadel, The Military College of South Carolina]], in the fall of 1976. He graduated in 1981 and, despite having made poor grades, gained admittance into [[Harvard Law School]]. He received his [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] degree from there in 1984.{{cite web|first=Alex|last=Abad-Santos|url=https://www.vox.com/2015/2/27/8119829/house-of-cards-spacey-southern-accent|title=What linguists say about Kevin Spacey's bizarre Southern accent on House of Cards|work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]]|location=New York City|date=February 27, 2015|accessdate=March 1, 2015}} While at the Sentinel, he had a [[homosexual]] relationship with his roommate, Tim Corbet ([[David Andrews (actor)|David Andrews]]), which lasted until his first year of law school. Underwood was raised Christian, but holds God in complete contempt.{{cite web|first=Stuart|last=Jeffries|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2015/feb/27/house-of-cards-recap-episodes-two-three-and-four-frank-speaks-to-god|title=House of Cards recap: episodes two, three and four= Frank speaks to God|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|location=London, England|date=February 27, 2015|accessdate=April 5, 2016}} ===Family=== Underwood's great-great-great-grandfather, Corporal Augustus Elijah Underwood, was a [[Confederate States Army|Confederate]] soldier who served in the 12th [[South Carolina]] [[Infantry]] [[Regiment]] of McGowan's Brigade at the [[Battle of Spotsylvania Court House|Battle of Spotsylvania]]. He served at the Bloody Angle on May 12, 1864, during the [[American Civil War|Civil War]] and was killed by a bludgeon to the back of the head from his own regiment during the middle of the night. Underwood is fascinated by his ancestry. When Underwood falls into a coma following an assassination attempt, Augustus appears in several of his hallucinations. However, he dismisses the Confederacy as weak and calls their cause of preserving the institution of slavery "asinine". His great-great grandfather was two when Augustus was killed.{{cite AV media | people = | year =2014 | title =House of Cards (U.S. TV series) |trans-title=House of Cards (season 2) | medium =Streaming video | language = | accessdate =February 15, 2014 | format = | time = | location =Chapter 18, 29:10 remaining | publisher =[[Netflix]] | id = | isbn = | oclc = | quote = | ref =}} His father, Calvin T. Underwood, was a peach farmer in his home town of Gaffney who died at the age of 43 of a heart attack. The Underwoods lived in poverty, and nearly lost the farm when Frank was a child; to get a bank loan and avoid foreclosure, his father attended a meeting of the [[Ku Klux Klan]], of which the bank manager was a member. Underwood speaks fondly of his father in public,{{cite AV media | people = | year =2013 | title =House of Cards (U.S. TV series) |trans-title=House of Cards (season 1) | medium =Streaming video | language = | url =http://movies.netflix.com/WiPlayer?movieid=70178217&trkid=222336&strkid=1298074483_0_0&strackid=1c708963a16703dd_0_srl&fdvd=true#MovieId=70178217&EpisodeMovieId=70248291 | accessdate =March 16, 2014 | format = | time = | location =Chapter 3, 20:05 remaining | publisher =[[Netflix]] | id = | isbn = | oclc = | quote = | ref =}}{{dead link|date=August 2017|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} but this is a political ploy; in his asides to the audience, Underwood describes his father as a weak man who accomplished nothing with his life.{{cite magazine|first=Aaron|last=Couch|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/house-cards-frank-underwoods-10-680304|title='House of Cards': Frank Underwood's 10 Most Ruthless Moments (Poll)|magazine=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=February 13, 2014|accessdate=March 16, 2014}} He even urinates on his father's grave in season 3. Despite disliking his father, however, Underwood was influenced by him.{{cite magazine|first=Hillary|last=Busis|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2014/02/18/house-of-cards-season-2/|title='House of Cards': Let's talk all of season 2|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=February 18, 2014|accessdate=March 16, 2014}} Calvin was an abusive [[alcoholic]] and caused his wife and son years of misery. Underwood has said that when he was 13, he walked in on his father putting a shotgun in his mouth. Calvin asked him to pull the trigger, which he refused to do. He has stated that his biggest regret is not killing his father when he had the chance.{{cite web|first=Stuart|last=Jeffries|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2014/mar/05/house-of-cards-recap-season-two-episode-13|title=House of Cards recap, series two, episode 13 – 'Cut out his heart and put it in his hands'|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|location=New York City|date=March 5, 2014|accessdate=March 16, 2014}} ===Political career=== ====South Carolina Legislature==== Underwood was elected at the age of 25 to the [[South Carolina Senate|South Carolina State Senate]] as one of the youngest members in the state's legislative history after graduating from [[Harvard University|Harvard]] in 1984. He was re-elected to the state senate at 29 in 1988 for his second, and last, term as a State [[Senate|Senator]]. ====Congressional Election==== Underwood was elected to the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] in 1990 as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] representative for the [[South Carolina's 5th congressional district|5th Congressional District of South Carolina]], being sworn in during January 1991. He won another 11 consecutive elections, winning his final term in 2012. He was elected [[Whip (politics)|Whip]] for the Democratic Party in 2005, serving as [[Party leaders of the United States House of Representatives|House Majority Whip]] between 2005 and 2013. ===Personal life=== ====Personality==== Underwood is utterly ruthless and [[Machiavellian]], and is willing to commit any crime, including murder, to further his goal of attaining power. Many critics have described him as a [[antisocial personality disorder|sociopath]]{{cite magazine|first=Shaili|last=Jain|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-aftermath-trauma/201503/the-case-francis-underwood|title=The Case of Francis Underwood|magazine=[[Psychology Today]]|publisher=Sussex Publishers|location=New York City|date=March 11, 2015|accessdate=November 29, 2015}} and as "pure evil".{{cite magazine|first=Stephen|last=Daw|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2016-03-04/11-despicable-crimes-frank-underwood-has-committed-in-house-of-cards/|title=11 despicable crimes Frank Underwood has committed in House of Cards|magazine=[[Radio Times]]|publisher=[[Immediate Media Company]]|location=London, England|date=March 4, 2016|accessdate=November 29, 2017}} Often, Underwood's thoughts throughout the series are presented in a direct address to the audience, a narrative technique known as breaking the [[fourth wall]].{{cite web|first=Roth|last=Cornet|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/02/01/netflixs-original-series-house-of-cards-from-david-fincher-and-kevin-spacey-may-be-the-new-face-of-television|title=Netflix's Original Series House of Cards -- From David Fincher and Kevin Spacey -- May be the New Face of Television|website=[[IGN]]|publisher=[[j2 Global]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=January 31, 2013|accessdate=July 20, 2013}} Immediately prior to starring in ''House of Cards'', Spacey had starred in a production of [[William Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Richard III (play)|Richard III]]'' as [[Richard III of England]], a character that serves as a partial basis for both Urquhart and Underwood. His last name is derived from [[Oscar Underwood]], who served as the first Democratic [[House Minority Whip]] from about 1900 to 1901.{{cite web|first=Kirsty|last=McCormack|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/showbiz/459786/Kate-Mara-joins-Kevin-Spacey-at-the-premiere-of-House-of-Cards-season-two|title=Kate Mara steals the show at 'House of Cards' season premiere in sexy cut-out dress|work=[[Daily Express]]|publisher=[[Northern and Shell Media]]|location=London, England|date=February 14, 2014|accessdate=December 26, 2014}} His few vices include smoking cigarettes and playing [[video games]];{{cite magazine|first=James|last=Poniewozik|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2014/02/12/review-house-of-cards-returns-for-season-two/|title=Review: House of Cards Returns for Season Two: Kevin Spacey's D.C. power play still has cynical bite, but some old problems remain.|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|publisher=[[meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=February 12, 2014|accessdate=February 13, 2014}} when the Secret Service cuts off his online gaming service after he becomes Vice President, he takes up creating model figurines. Spacey viewed portraying Underwood for a second season as a continuing learning process. "There is so much I don't know about Francis, so much that I'm learning... I've always thought that the profession closest to that of an actor is being a detective... We are given clues by writers... Then you lay them all out and try to make them come alive as a character who's complex and surprising, maybe even to yourself."{{cite web|first=Frazier|last=Moore|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/tv/2014/02/12/kevin-spacey-dealing-season-house-cards/tnmxGYqDuEe4DMekzXBOfO/story.html|title=Kevin Spacey dealing Season 2 of 'House of Cards'|website=[[Boston.com]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=February 12, 2014|accessdate=February 13, 2014}} According to ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' television critic [[James Poniewozik]], by the end of the first episode, it becomes clear that Underwood both literally and figuratively uses meat as his metaphor of choice. He may begin a day with a celebratory rack of ribs, because "I'm feelin' hungry today!", and he depicts his life with meat metaphors. For example, he describes the White House Chief of Staff with grudging admiration: "She's as tough as a two-dollar steak" and plans to destroy an enemy the way "you devour a whale. One bite at a time". He also endures a tedious weekly meeting with House leaders, as he tells the audience, by "[imagining] their lightly salted faces frying in a skillet."{{cite magazine|first=James|last=Poniewozik|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2013/01/31/review-house-of-cards-sinks-its-sharp-teeth-into-washington/|title=Review: House of Cards Sinks Its Sharp Teeth into Washington|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=January 31, 2013|accessdate=September 10, 2013}} Tim Goodman of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' notes that, in Season 2, with Underwood's new position as Vice President, "He's got more power now and that means he instills more fear in his enemies". At one point during the season, he states "The road to power is paved with hypocrisy and casualties. I need to prove what the vice president is capable of."{{cite magazine|first=Hilary|last=Lewis|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/house-cards-season-2-trailer-665556|title='House of Cards' Season 2 Trailer: The Threats and Power Grabs Mount (Video)|magazine=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=December 13, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}} Underwood and Claire "continue their ruthless rise to power as threats mount on all fronts."{{cite newspaper|first=Meredith|last=Blake|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-netflix-house-of-cards-season-2-premiere-date-20131204,0,5149324.story#axzz2mXxl1lI2|title=Netflix sets premiere date for 'House of Cards' Season 2|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tronc]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=December 4, 2013|accessdate=December 4, 2013}} ====Sexuality==== Underwood's sexuality is ambiguous throughout much of the first two seasons; he has sexual liaisons with both men and women, but he is never explicitly identified by any sexual label. Before Season 2, various sources speculated about his homosexuality. It is revealed in "Chapter 8" he had an experience with homosexuality in college.{{cite news|first1=David|last1=Carr|first2=Ashley|last2=Parker|url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/03/21/house-of-cards-recap-episode-8-you-can-go-home-again-it-just-might-get-complicated/|title='House of Cards' Recap, Episode 8: You Can Go Home Again, It Just Might Get Complicated|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=New York Times Company|location=New York City|date=March 21, 2013|accessdate=November 26, 2017}} Underwood and Claire are never depicted having sex in season 1. ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' journalist [[Hanna Rosin]] noted: if Frank and Claire Underwood were a real-life Washington couple and they were found each to be having an affair, he would be accused of being "secretly gay, turned on by women only when he can use them for a pure power play".{{cite web|first=Hanna|last=Rosin|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/double_x/doublex/2013/03/house_of_cards_do_frank_and_claire_underwood_have_an_ideal_marriage.html|title="More Than Sharks Love Blood": Do Frank and Claire Underwood have the ideal marriage?|website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|publisher=[[The Slate Group]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=March 18, 2013|accessdate=January 25, 2014}} Other sources make no definite stance on Underwood's sexuality, but hypothesize that he is not sexually attracted to Claire.{{cite web|first=Ryan|last=McGee|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/house-of-cards-the-complete-first-season-93614|title=House Of Cards: "Chapter 8"|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|publisher=Onion, Inc.|location=Chicago, Illinois|date=March 22, 2013|accessdate=January 25, 2014}} In season 2, Underwood is involved in a [[threesome]] with Claire and Secret Service agent Edward Meechum ([[Nathan Darrow]]),{{cite web|first=Eliana|last=Dockterman|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2014/02/17/house-of-cards-season-2-most-shocking-moments/|title=The 9 Most Shocking Moments from House of Cards Season 2|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=February 17, 2014|accessdate=February 18, 2014}} while in season 3, there is a moment of sexual tension between Underwood and his biographer, Tom Yates ([[Paul Sparks]]). The same season, however, also features the only scene in the series in which Underwood and Claire have sex exclusively with each other. In season five, he has sex with Eric Rawlings (Malcolm Madera), his male personal trainer. === Relationships === ====Relationship with Claire Underwood==== Stelter described Frank and Claire Underwood as a "scheming" couple. [[Michael Dobbs]], the author of the trilogy of novels upon which the British miniseries is based, compares the compelling nature of their relationship favorably to the characters in the original miniseries, and likens them to [[Macbeth (character)|Macbeth]] and [[Lady Macbeth]]. Underwood says, "I love that woman. I love her more than sharks love blood." While Underwood is Machiavellian, Claire, like Lady Macbeth, encourages her husband to do whatever is necessary to seize power.{{cite news|first=Joanne|last=Ostrow|url=http://www.denverpost.com/television/ci_22483448/kevin-spacey-shines-house-cards-political-drama-netflix|title=Ostrow: Kevin Spacey shines in "House of Cards" political drama on Netflix|newspaper=[[The Denver Post]]|publisher=[[Digital First Media]]|location=Denver, Colorado|date=January 30, 2013|accessdate=February 11, 2013}} [[Hank Stuever]] of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' describes her as an ice-queen wife.{{cite news|first=Hank|last=Stuever|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/tv/house-of-cards-power-corrupts-plus-other-non-breaking-news/2013/01/31/b72c54b6-6bd0-11e2-8740-9b58f43c191a_story.html|title='House of Cards': Power corrupts (plus other non-breaking news)|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=Nash Holdings LLC|location=Washington DC|date=January 31, 2013|accessdate=September 10, 2013}} She encourages his vices while noting her disapproval of his weakness, saying, "My husband doesn't apologize... even to me."{{cite news|first=Alessandra|last=Stanley|url=http://tv.nytimes.com/2013/02/01/arts/television/house-of-cards-on-netflix-stars-kevin-spacey.html|title=Political Animals That Slither: 'House of Cards' on Netflix Stars Kevin Spacey|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=New York Times Company|location=New York City|date=January 31, 2013|accessdate=September 10, 2013}} Her overt encouragement gives a credibility to their symbiosis. Smith says "The Underwoods have proven themselves almost robotic in their pursuit of power." Upon viewing a four-episode preview of season 2, Goodman says the series "...sells husband and wife power-at-all-costs couple...as a little too oily and reptilian for anyone's good."{{cite magazine|first=Tim|last=Goodman|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/house-cards-tv-review-676602|title=House Of Cards: TV Review|magazine=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=February 3, 2014|accessdate=February 10, 2014}} Willimon notes that "What's extraordinary about Frank and Claire is there is deep love and mutual respect, but the way they achieve this is by operating on a completely different set of rules than the rest of us typically do."{{cite news|first=Ann|last=Oldenburg|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2014/02/12/house-of-cards-season-2-kevin-spacey-more-plotting-scheming/5420181/|title='House of Cards' promises more 'plotting and scheming'|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|location=Mclean, Virginia|date=February 13, 2014|accessdate=February 13, 2014}} ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' critic Mary McNamara makes the case that ''House of Cards'' is a love story on many levels, but most importantly between Underwood and Claire. It is a story about a man who will commit any crime imaginable while in pursuit of power and a political wife who gives him the encouragement to pursue that power.{{cite web|first=Mary|last=McNamara|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-house-of-cards-review-20140214,0,3657138.story#axzz2tK1ANdYr|title=Review: 'House of Cards' plays new hand with brutal, clear resolve|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tronc]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=February 14, 2014|accessdate=February 28, 2014}} Underwood and Claire engage in a threesome with their Secret Service bodyguard Edward Meechum at one point in season 2, but have otherwise largely given up intramarital and extramarital sex in favor of their pursuit of power. ''[[International Business Times]]'' critic Ellen Killoran notes that this may relate back to Underwood's quotation of [[Oscar Wilde]] to Zoe Barnes in Season 1: "A great man once said, 'everything is about sex ''except'' sex. Sex is about ''power''.'" Avoiding sex may retain the balance of power in their relationship.{{cite web|first=Ellen|last=Killoran|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/house-cards-season-2-review-burning-questions-remain-after-netflix-binge-1556355|title='House of Cards' Season 2 Review: Burning Questions Remain After Netflix Binge|work=[[International Business Times]]|publisher=[[Newsweek Media Group]]|location=New York City|date=February 18, 2014|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} His relationship with Claire is the epicenter of season 2.{{cite web|first=Baynard|last=Woods|url=http://citypaper.com/film/review-house-of-cards-season-2-1.1640752|title=Review: House of Cards Season 2: Francis Underwood gives liberals their own Dick Cheney: a vice president able to push through his agenda.|newspaper=[[Baltimore City Paper|City Paper]]|publisher=[[Tronc]]|location=Baltimore, Maryland|date=February 26, 2014|accessdate=March 18, 2014|dead-url=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140319025543/http://citypaper.com/film/review-house-of-cards-season-2-1.1640752|archivedate=March 19, 2014}} ====Relationship with Zoe Barnes==== Underwood develops an intimate relationship with ''Washington Herald'' and ''Slugline'' reporter Zoe Barnes ([[Kate Mara]]), with Claire's knowledge. As the show begins, Barnes is desperate to rise from covering the Fairfax County Council beat to covering what's going on "behind the veil of power in the Capitol hallways." By the end of the first episode, Barnes is among the cadre of Underwood's accomplices. They begin a relationship, with Barnes promising to earn his trust and not "ask any questions" in return for his supplying her with sensitive political information. Toward the end of Season 1, she ends their personal relationship and begins investigating his connection to Congressman Peter Russo's apparent suicide (Underwood had in fact killed him by flooding his car with [[carbon monoxide]] while the Congressman was passed out drunk). Underwood ultimately kills Barnes in the season 2 premiere, by pushing her in front of an oncoming [[Washington Metro]] train after she begins to follow clues related to the murder.{{cite web|first=Daniel|last=D'Addario|url=http://www.salon.com/2014/02/15/yes_that_really_just_happened_on_house_of_cards/|title=Yes, that really just happened on "House of Cards"|website=[[Salon (magazine)|Salon]]|publisher=[[Salon Media Group]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=February 15, 2014|accessdate=February 18, 2014}} ====Relationship with Edward Meechum==== Underwood is fond of the head of his Secret Service detail, Edward Meechum ([[Nathan Darrow]]), and it is hinted several times that they harbor unacknowledged sexual feelings for each other. When Meechum stumbles upon Underwood watching pornography, Underwood and Claire joke about there being sexual chemistry between the two men. Shortly after Underwood becomes vice president, he, Claire and Meechum have a [[threesome]]. Meechum remains Underwood's bodyguard once he becomes the president, and there does not appear to be any continuing sexual relationship. Meechum remains fiercely loyal, however; he warns Underwood's biographer Tom Yates ([[Paul Sparks]]) not to write anything that would damage Underwood's reputation. In season 4, Underwood traces Meechum's hand with a marker on one of the walls of the White House when he wants to replace a Confederate painting; Meechum suggests he put up something he likes instead. When Lucas Goodwin shoots Underwood during a campaign event, Meechum trades fire with the would-be assassin, and both die at the scene. Meechum's death is one of the tragedies Claire mentions in a press briefing for a gun control bill she is sponsoring, and Underwood has him buried in [[Arlington National Cemetery]], a rare privilege for a Secret Service agent. When Underwood recovers and finds that Meechum's hand tracing has been painted over, he expresses grief and regret at the loss to Claire, who says that Meechum was one of the few people who truly understood them. ===Underwood-Urquhart comparisons=== Underwood is an Americanized version of the original BBC series lead character [[Francis Urquhart]], a [[Machiavellianism|Machiavellian]] post-[[Margaret Thatcher]] [[Chief Whip of the Conservative Party]]. Urquhart employs deceit, cunning, murder, and blackmail to influence and pursue the office of [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]]. According to series producer [[Beau Willimon]], the change in last name stemmed from the "[[Dickensian]]" feeling and "more legitimately American" sounding resonance of the name 'Underwood'. Whereas Urquhart is an aristocrat by birth, Underwood is a [[self-made man]], having been born into a poor Southern family with an alcoholic father. Urquhart was one of television's first [[antihero]]es, whereas Underwood follows the more recent rash of antiheroes that includes [[Tony Soprano]] of ''[[The Sopranos]]'', [[Walter White (Breaking Bad)|Walter White]] of ''[[Breaking Bad]]'', and [[Dexter Morgan]] of ''[[Dexter (TV series)|Dexter]]''. However, unlike most other antiheroes, Underwood is not forced into immorality either by circumstance (White), birth (Soprano) or upbringing (Morgan). In his review of Season 2, ''[[Slant Magazine]]''{{'}}s Alan Jones writes that Underwood is evil by choice.{{cite web|first=Alan|last=Jones|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/tv/review/house-of-cards-season-two|title=House of Cards: Season Two|work=[[Slant Magazine]]|publisher=Slant Magazine LLC|location=Brooklyn, New York|date=February 18, 2014|accessdate=March 14, 2014}} Although the character is based on the BBC show's lead character, in interviews during the writing and filming of [[House of Cards (season 2)|season 2]], creator and showrunner Willimon said that he used [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] as a source of themes and issues addressed in ''House of Cards''.{{cite web|first=Todd|last=Leopold|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/08/28/showbiz/tv/beau-willimon-house-of-cards-q-and-a/index.html|title='House of Cards' creator Beau Willimon plays a solid hand|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=August 28, 2013|accessdate=October 2, 2013}} Unlike the [[center-right]] Urquhart, who leads the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]], the [[center-left]] Underwood is a member of the Democratic Party, but cares little for ideology in favor of "ruthless pragmatism" in furthering his own political influence and power.{{cite web|first=David|last=Sirota|url=http://www.salon.com/2013/03/12/why_is_francis_underwood_a_democrat/|title=Why was Francis Underwood a Democrat?|website=[[Salon (magazine)|Salon]]|publisher=[[Salon Media Group]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=March 12, 2013|accessdate=January 17, 2014}} ===Breaking the fourth wall=== Spacey summed up Underwood's relationship with the viewer - i.e. whenever he breaks [[Meta-reference|the fourth wall]] - as being like that of a "best friend" and "the person [he trusts] more than anyone."{{cite web|first=Tanya|last=Gharemani|url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/14708-house-of-cards-kevin-spacey-isnt-talking-to-you-when-he-speaks-into-camera|title='House of Cards' Kevin Spacey Isn't Talking To You When He Speaks Into Camera|website=[[Bustle.com]]|publisher=Bustle Digital Group|location=New York City|date=February 5, 2014|accessdate=November 29, 2017}} Because of this, his asides to the viewer serves as an indication of Underwood's true feelings and intentions - typically when he is feigning politeness and courtesy to people whom he despises. In the season 2 premiere, after having gone the whole episode without doing so, Underwood addresses the viewer directly, saying, "Did you think I had forgotten you? Perhaps you hoped I had." In addition, in season 3, after an argument with Claire that ends with her storming out on him, a seething Underwood vents his anger by lashing out at the viewer; looking directly into the camera, he snaps "What're you lookin' at?!" For the first four seasons, Underwood was the only character to break the fourth wall until the very end of the fourth season, during which Claire - though silent - addresses the camera directly with him. In the fifth season, Claire also addresses the camera directly, on one occasion explaining that she had always known they were there, but didn't know if she could trust them. At the end, after usurping the Presidency from Underwood and deciding not to grant him a pardon, she looks into the camera again and states "My turn."{{cite news|first=Jackie|last=Strause|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/house-cards-season-5-finale-claire-breaks-fourth-wall-showrunners-q-a-1010414|title='House of Cards' Bosses Break Down Those Final Two Words of Season 5|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=June 7, 2017|accessdate=June 7, 2017}} ==Biography== ===Season 1=== {{Main|House of Cards (season 1)}} {{Quote box | quote = Power is a lot like real estate. It's all about location, location, location. The closer you are to the source, the higher your property value. | source = — Underwood{{cite web|first=Brian|last=Stelter|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/20/arts/television/house-of-cards-arrives-as-a-netflix-series.html|title=A Drama's Streaming Premiere|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=New York Times Company|location=New York City|date=January 18, 2013|accessdate=July 21, 2013}} | width = 24em |bgcolor= | align =right }} At the start of the show, Underwood is a Democratic Majority Whip in the House of Representatives, where he has represented [[South Carolina's 5th congressional district]] since 1990.{{cite news|first=Aaron|last=Blake|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2013/12/17/obama-wishes-d-c-worked-more-like-it-does-in-house-of-cards/|title=Obama wishes D.C. worked more like it does in 'House of Cards'|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=Nash Holdings LLC|location=Washington DC|date=December 17, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014}}{{cite web|first=Terry|last=Plumb|url=http://www.heraldonline.com/2013/09/29/5244416/humble-pie-on-the-menu.html |title=Humble pie on the menu |work=[[The Herald (Rock Hill)|The Herald]] |publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]]|location=Rock Hill, South Carolina|date=September 29, 2013|accessdate=January 18, 2014 |dead-url=yes| archive-url=https://archive.is/20140118022043/http://www.heraldonline.com/2013/09/29/5244416/humble-pie-on-the-menu.html |archive-date=January 18, 2014}} Underwood is passed over for an appointment as [[United States Secretary of State]] even though he had been promised the position after ensuring the election of [[Governor of Colorado|Colorado Governor]] Garrett Walker ([[Michel Gill]]) as President. Walker's Chief of Staff Linda Vasquez ([[Sakina Jaffrey]]) gives him this news prior to the January 2013 [[United States presidential inauguration]]. With the aid of Claire, and his fiercely loyal Chief of Staff Doug Stamper ([[Michael Kelly (American actor)|Michael Kelly]]), Underwood uses his position as House Whip to seek retribution. He quickly allies with ''Washington Herald'' reporter Zoe Barnes ([[Kate Mara]]), whom he uses to undermine his rivals via the press.{{cite web|first=Ryan|last=McGee|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/house-of-cards-the-complete-first-season-93105 |title=House Of Cards: "Chapter 5"|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|publisher=Onion, Inc.|location=Chicago, Illinois|date=March 1, 2013|accessdate=March 5, 2016}} The viciousness of Underwood's manipulations escalates over the course of the season.{{cite magazine|first=Laura|last=Bennett|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/112330/house-cards-kevin-spacey-reviewed-laura-bennett#|title=Kevin Spacey's Leading-Man Problem The star of the 13-hour "House of Cards" is as impenetrable as ever |magazine=[[The New Republic|New Republic]]|date=February 5, 2013|accessdate=July 22, 2013}} He befriends Pennsylvania Rep. Peter Russo ([[Corey Stoll]]), encouraging him to quit drinking and run for Governor of Pennsylvania; then his underlings create enough pressure in the race to push Russo into publicly falling off the wagon and ruining his career. Underwood finally murders him and makes it look like suicide. He persuades Vice President Jim Matthews ([[Dan Ziskie]]) to resign so he can run for the office he previously held, Governor of Pennsylvania, the race being wide open following Russo's death. In the season finale, "Chapter 13", Underwood is appointed Vice President to replace Matthews.{{cite web|first=Chris|last=Jancelewicz|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/chris-jancelewicz/house-of-cards-season-1-episode-13-finale-recap_b_3214841.html|title=House Of Cards Season 1, Episode 13 Recap: All's Well That Ends Well (Or Not)|website=[[Huffington Post]]|publisher=[[Huffington Post Media Group]]|location=New York City|date=May 4, 2013|accessdate=March 5, 2016}} ===Season 2=== {{Main|House of Cards (season 2)}} {{Quote box | quote = There are two types of vice presidents: doormats and Matadors. Which do you think I intend to be? | source = — Underwood | align =right | width = 26em |bgcolor= }} Underwood assumes the position of [[Vice President of the United States]]. Over the course of the season, he "faces challenges from similarly ambitious businessmen, the Chinese government and Congress itself" as he continues to pursue his political aspirations.{{cite magazine|first=Tom|last=Welshman|url=http://www.impactnottingham.com/2014/03/tv-review-house-of-cards-season-2/|title=TV Review – House of Cards, Season 2|magazine=[[Impact (student magazine)|Impact]]|publisher=[[University of Nottingham Students' Union]]|location=Nottingham, England|date=March 18, 2014|accessdate=March 19, 2014}} His plotline revolves around battles with billionaire Raymond Tusk ([[Gerald McRaney]]), involving Chinese [[money laundering]]. Over the course of the season his biggest challenges are the institutional power of the Office of the President and Tusk's power as a billionaire industrialist.{{cite web|first=Tess|last=VandenDolder|url=http://inthecapital.streetwise.co/2014/02/17/house-of-cards-season-2-review/|title='House of Cards' Season 2 Review: Shocking and Messy, But Just as Addictive as Ever|work=[[In The Capital]]|publisher=[[Streetwise Media]]|location=Washington DC|date=February 17, 2014|accessdate=May 19, 2014}} He finds new rivals in Tusk, who seeks to maintain his position as Walker's right-hand adviser against Underwood's intrusion, and his former communications director, Remy Danton ([[Mahershala Ali]]), who is now a lobbyist working with Tusk.{{cite news |url=http://www.kansascity.com/2014/02/07/4803248/second-season-of-house-of-cards.html |title=Second season of 'House of Cards' is a vote for vice |last=Smith |first=Sara |date=February 7, 2014 |work=[[The Kansas City Star]] |access-date=February 9, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140208204216/http://www.kansascity.com/2014/02/07/4803248/second-season-of-house-of-cards.html |archive-date=February 8, 2014 |publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]] |location=Kansas City, Missouri}} At the beginning of the season, Underwood is trying to erase all links to Russo's death.{{cite news|first=David|last=Zurawik|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/tv/z-on-tv-blog/bal-the-plays-the-thing-in-season-2-house-of-cards-20140208,0,1234605.story|title=Season 2 of 'House of Cards' packs theatrical power|newspaper=[[Baltimore Sun]]|publisher=[[Tronc]]|location=Baltimore, Maryland|date=February 8, 2014|accessdate=February 9, 2014}} Thus, he kills Barnes by shoving her in front of an oncoming [[Washington Metro]] train,{{cite web|first=Christopher|last=Hooton|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/house-of-cards-season-2-shock-twist-was-planned-from-day-one-says-showrunner-9136819.html|title=House of Cards season 2 shock twist was planned from day one, says showrunner|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|publisher=Independent Print Ltd.|location=London, England|date=February 18, 2014|accessdate=March 18, 2014}} and frames her colleague and lover Lucas Goodwin ([[Sebastian Arcelus]]) for [[cyberterrorism]]. Another early task for newly promoted Underwood is finding his own replacement as House Majority Whip. He supports Jacqueline Sharp ([[Molly Parker]]), a military veteran and third-term Representative from California, although he refrains from offering public backing.{{cite news|first=Sara|last=Smith|url=http://www.kansascity.com/2014/02/07/4803307/new-season-brings-a-formidable.html|title=New season brings a formidable female player to 'House of Cards'|newspaper=[[The Kansas City Star]]|publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]]|location=Kansas City, Missouri|date=February 7, 2014|accessdate=July 22, 2018}} Toward the end of the season, Underwood orchestrates Walker's downfall. He secretly leaks the details of the money laundering, for which Walker is blamed. While publicly supporting Walker, Underwood works behind the scenes to have him [[articles of impeachment|impeached]], with Sharp's help. In the season finale, "Chapter 26", Walker resigns, and Underwood succeeds him as President of the United States. ===Season 3=== {{Main|House of Cards (season 3)}} {{Quote box | quote = When they bury me, it won't be in my backyard, and when they come to pay their respects, they'll have to wait in line. | source = — Underwood{{cite web|first=Eric|last=Deggans|url=https://www.npr.org/2015/02/27/388509802/this-season-on-house-of-cards-its-tough-to-be-the-boss|title=This Season On 'House Of Cards,' It's Tough To Be The Boss|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=February 27, 2015|accessdate=April 5, 2016}} | width = 26em |bgcolor= | align =right }} Season 3 begins with Underwood's presidency off to a rocky start: six months into his term, he is unpopular with the public, and Congress is blocking his attempts to move legislation forward. He plans to secure his legacy with an ambitious jobs bill, America Works, but the Democratic Congressional leadership refuses to support it; they also tell him that they will not support him if he seeks the presidential nomination in the next election. He nominates Claire for [[United States Ambassador to the United Nations]], but her nomination is defeated after she makes a gaffe during a Senate nomination hearing. Underwood announces that he will not run for reelection, and advocates for America Works, which he intends to pay for by stripping entitlement programs. He fails to get the bill through Congress and uses that as a reason to renege on his promise to not run in 2016. Solicitor General Heather Dunbar ([[Elizabeth Marvel]]) announces that she will seek the presidential nomination, and actually gives Underwood a battle. Underwood convinces Sharp to get married so she can announce her candidacy, for the sole reason of sapping women's votes from Dunbar, at which point she will withdraw and accept the nomination for VP. After the presidential debate, in which Underwood publicly humiliates Sharp in order to go after Dunbar, Sharp retaliates by backing Dunbar's campaign. Ultimately, however, Underwood wins the [[Iowa caucuses]].{{cite magazine|first=Richard|last=Lawson|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/03/house-of-cards-season-3-recap|title=Where Does Frank Underwood Go From Here, and Other House of Cards Season 3 Questions|magazine=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|publisher=[[Condé Nast]]|location=New York City|date=March 23, 2016|accessdate=April 5, 2016}} Meanwhile, the Underwoods' marriage is faltering. Underwood gives Claire the ambassador job in a [[recess appointment]], but she is forced to resign in order to solve a diplomatic crisis. Claire begins to question whether she still loves her husband, and they get into an ugly fight in which he tells her that she is nothing without him. Season 3 ends with Claire leaving Underwood as he prepares for the [[New Hampshire primary]].{{Cite episode|title=Chapter 39|series=House of Cards|network=Netflix|airdate=February 27, 2015|season=3|number=13}}{{cite web|first=Warlow|last=Stern|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/03/16/the-explosive-house-of-cards-finale-creator-beau-willimon-on-the-state-of-the-underwoods.html|title=The Explosive 'House of Cards' Finale: Creator Beau Willimon on the State of the Underwoods|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|publisher=[[IAC (company)|IAC]]|location=New York City|date=March 16, 2015|accessdate=July 22, 2018}} ===Season 4=== {{Main|House of Cards (season 4)}} {{Quote box | quote = That's right, we don't submit to terror. We ''make'' the terror. | source = — Underwood{{cite web|first=Eric|last=Fowle|url=http://www.ew.com/recap/house-of-cards-season-4-finale|title=House of Cards recap: Chapter 52|publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=March 8, 2016|accessdate=April 13, 2016}} | width = 26em |bgcolor= | align =right }} Underwood trails Dunbar in the polls, eventually losing the New Hampshire primary. Realizing that he needs Claire to win, he persuades her to come back by promising to support her run for a congressional district in Texas. However, he sandbags her prospective candidacy by endorsing a political ally's daughter, in order to keep Claire focused on his campaign. On the day of the [[South Carolina primary]], Claire retaliates by arranging for two compromising photos to be leaked: one of Underwood's father with a [[Ku Klux Klan|Klansman]], and one of Underwood posing with a Confederate Civil War re-enactor. Underwood deduces that Claire was behind the leaks, and confronts her. Claire calmly admits what she did, and puts forth a proposition: that she run as his vice president. He angrily rejects the idea. Lucas Goodwin is released from prison and, seeking revenge for Barnes' death, shoots Underwood at a campaign rally, hitting him in the liver. He also mortally wounds Meechum, who manages to kill him before succumbing to his injuries. Underwood is rushed to the hospital for immediate surgery, and falls into a coma. It is soon discovered that he needs a liver transplant. Stamper manages to bump him to the top of the transplant list, and he survives. Once he recovers, he agrees to let Claire run as his vice president. Dunbar drops out of the race due to the discovery of a meeting she'd had with Goodwin a few days before the attempt on Underwood's life. Underwood begins planning to maneuver Claire into the VP spot and to use the [[National Security Agency|NSA]] to illegally obtain voter information and spy on the Republican nominee, Will Conway ([[Joel Kinnaman]]). This happens while Underwood and Claire advocate for a controversial gun control bill for the sole purpose of creating an atmosphere divisive enough to weed out potential running mates. During the resulting [[brokered convention|open convention]], Underwood intimidates the front-runner, Secretary of State Catherine Durant ([[Jayne Atkinson]]), into surrendering her delegates, and uses the public sympathy from Claire's mother's death to ensure that he and Claire are nominated.{{cite web|first=Brian|last=Lowery|url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/columns/house-of-cards-review-kevin-spacey-robin-wright-complete-fourth-season-binge-viewers-spoilers-1201725921/|title=Review: 'House of Cards,' The Complete Fourth Season for Binge Viewers (SPOILERS)|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=March 10, 2016|accessdate=April 7, 2016}} When American extremists loyal to the [[terrorist]] group Islamic Caliphate Organization (ICO) kidnap a suburban family, Underwood allows Conway to negotiate with them, making his opponent look like a hero - and then releases NSA data that proves Conway illegally influenced Congress. Soon afterward, however, Underwood is hit with two crises at once: ICO's leader orders his followers to kill one of the hostages, while journalist Tom Hammerschmidt ([[Boris McGiver]]) exposes Underwood's crimes in the ''Washington Herald''. Facing disgrace and possible [[impeachment]], Underwood decides to declare war on ICO and allow the public to see the hostage die in order to distract from the scandal and create an atmosphere of widespread fear that he and Claire can exploit in the weeks before the election.{{Cite episode|title=Chapter 52|series=House of Cards|network=Netflix|airdate=March 4, 2016|season=4|number=13}} ===Season 5=== {{see also|House of Cards (season 5)}} {{Quote box | quote = One nation, Underwood. | source = — Underwood{{cite web|first=Kyle|last=Fowle|url=http://ew.com/recap/house-of-cards-season-5-finale/|title=House of Cards recap: Chapter 65|publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=June 7, 2017|accessdate=July 21, 2017}} | width = 26em |bgcolor= | align =right }} In the days before the election, Underwood pushes Congress to formally declare war on ICO, and orders the CIA to kill one of the terrorists and make it look like he had died fleeing capture. Underwood still lags in the polls, however, and on election night it appears he is going to lose to Conway. With help from Stamper and campaign strategist LeAnn Harvey ([[Neve Campbell]]), Underwood has NSA contractor Aidan Macallan ([[Damian Young]]) stage a [[cyberattack]] on several election stations. He also uses the fear of a possible terrorist attack to pressure the governors of Tennessee and Ohio to halt voting. The tactics work; the two states refuse to declare a winner, and the election drags on unresolved for several weeks. The presidency is finally set to be decided by a [[contingent election]] in the House. Neither Underwood nor Conway receive enough votes, however, so Underwood appoints Claire Acting President until the House votes again. Underwood tries to convince Arizona Congressman Alex Romero ([[James Martinez (actor)|James Martinez]]) to vote in his favor, but when Underwood refuses to help him with his own agenda, Romero forms a committee to impeach him. The Underwoods blackmail Conway's influential campaign manager Mark Usher ([[Campbell Scott]]) into joining their side by threatening to release recordings of Conway berating a pilot and his running mate Ted Brockhart ([[Colm Feore]]) threatening to kill Frank. Once Usher begins working for them, they release the tapes anyway, which costs Conway the election. Underwood is now [[President-elect]], but his past once again comes back to haunt him when Hammerschmidt writes a story linking him to Barnes' death. When Romero's committee intensifies its investigation, Underwood tries to divert public attention by ordering troops into [[Syria]] under the pretense of preventing a terrorist attack. This provokes Durant to testify against him; before she can take the stand, however, Underwood pushes her down a flight of stairs, incapacitating her. When Walker testifies about Underwood's role in the Chinese money laundering, Underwood takes the stand in his own defense and stuns the committee by resigning the presidency. When Claire demands an explanation, Underwood reveals that his resignation is part of a plan to ensure that they control the country for years to come: Claire from the White House, he from the private sector. To tie up loose ends, he has Macallan and Harvey killed, and persuades Stamper to "confess" to murdering Barnes. For Underwood's plan to work, however, Claire has to [[presidential pardon|pardon]] him and Stamper, which would damage her credibility with the public. Claire promises him that she will grant the pardons, but makes no mention of them during her first address to the nation as president. Angered, Underwood calls her several times, but each time he gets her [[voicemail]], causing him to worry that she has abandoned him. He breaks the fourth wall and says, "If she doesn't pardon me, I'll kill her." ==Critical response== ===Season 1=== ''[[The New York Times]]''' [[David Itzkoff]] called Underwood a "scheming politician" who does "some of the most evil and underhanded things imaginable".{{cite web|first=David|last=Itzkoff|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/07/18/emmy-nominees-kevin-spacey-of-house-of-cards/|title=Emmy Nominees: Kevin Spacey of 'House of Cards'|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=New York Times Company|location=New York City|date=July 18, 2013|accessdate=July 21, 2013}} [[Brian Stelter]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' said Underwood "…is on a quest for power that's just as suspenseful as anything on television." ''[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]'' critic Don Kaplan says "…conniving Congressman Frank Underwood, is easily one of the most complex antiheroes on TV — except he's not on TV".{{cite news|first=Don|last=Kaplan|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/internet-new-player-world-high-quality-tv-article-1.1402932|title=Kevin Spacey and Netflix's 'House of Cards' receive Emmy nominations, signaling a new order in TV|newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]|publisher=[[Tronc]]|location=New York City|date=July 21, 2013|accessdate=July 21, 2013}} [[David Wiegand]] of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' describes the character as one who "all but salivates over the chance to use his considerable power to gain more power, especially if it involves pulling the rug out from under some colleagues and the wool over the eyes of others."{{cite news|first=David|last=Wiegand|url=http://www.sfgate.com/tv/article/House-of-Cards-review-Sexy-political-revenge-4236277.php|title='House of Cards' review: Sexy political revenge|newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|location=San Francisco, California|date=January 30, 2013|accessdate=September 10, 2013}} [[Andrew Davies (writer)|Andrew Davies]], the producer of the original UK TV series, feels that Underwood lacks the "charm" of the original character, [[Francis Urquhart]].{{cite web|first=Jacob|last=Lace|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/01/30/david-fincher-beau-willimon-kate-mara-on-netflix-s-house-of-cards.html|title=David Fincher, Beau Willimon & Kate Mara On Netflix's 'House of Cards'|website=[[The Daily Beast]]|publisher=[[IAC (company)|IAC]]|location=New York City|date=January 30, 2013|accessdate=July 21, 2013}} ''[[The Independent]]'' praised Spacey's portrayal as a more "menacing" character, "hiding his rage behind Southern charm and old-fashioned courtesy,"{{cite news|first=Sara|last=Hughes|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/features/urquhart-is-deliciously-diabolical-kevin-spacey-is-back-in-a-remake-of-house-of-cards-8473834.html|title='Urquhart is deliciously diabolical': Kevin Spacey is back in a remake of House of Cards|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|publisher=Independent Print Ltd.|location=London, England|date=January 30, 2013|accessdate=July 21, 2013}} while ''[[The New Republic]]'' noted that "When Urquhart addressed the audience, it was partly in the spirit of conspiratorial fun. His [[asides]] sparked with wit. He wasn't just ruthlessly striving, he was amusing himself, mocking the ridiculousness of his milieu. There is no impishness about Spacey's Frank Underwood, just numb, machine-like ambition. Even his affection for his wife is a calculation." Poniewozik praises Underwood's accent, saying "Spacey gives Underwood a silky Southern accent you could pour over crushed ice and sip with a sprig of mint on Derby Day." [[Nancy deWolf Smith]] of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' describes the accent as a "mild but sometimes missing Carolina accent".{{cite news|first=Nancy|last=deWolf Smith|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323701904578275630824939470|title=Fantasies About Evil, Redux|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|publisher=[[Dow Jones & Company]]|location=New York City|date=January 31, 2013|accessdate=September 10, 2013}} ''Time'' listed Frank Underwood among the 11 most influential fictional characters in 2013.{{cite magazine|first1=Charlotte|last1=Alter|first2=Eliana|last2=Dockterman|url=http://poy.time.com/2013/12/09/the-11-most-influential-fictional-characters-of-2013/slide/frank-underwood/|title=The 11 Most Influential Fictional Characters of 2013: These are the on-screen figures who got our attention: 6. Frank Underwood|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=New York City|date=December 9, 2013|accessdate=December 11, 2013}} ===Season 2=== According to ''[[The Kansas City Star]]''{{'s}} Smith, "Frank hasn't changed, and neither has his brand of Machiavellian political theater" and "Spacey has lost none of his smarmy magnetism as the cartoon-ish villain". According to ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''{{'s}} Brian Lowry, "Kevin Spacey's showy performance as an unscrupulous politician" is foremost among the show's strengths, but the show's weakness is the "failure to present its scheming protagonist with equally matched foes".{{cite magazine|first=Brian|last=Lowry|url=https://variety.com/2014/digital/reviews/review-house-of-cards-1201076822/|title=TV Review: 'House of Cards' – Season Two|magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=January 31, 2014|accessdate=February 9, 2014}} Lowry feels that as conniving as Underwood is, it is unfathomable that "nobody else in a town built on power seems particularly adept at recognizing this or combating him". Goodman says "Spacey is nothing if not constantly magnetic". The delayed use of the fourth wall is perceived as clever. Alison Willmore of [[Indiewire]] says that "Unlike [[Walter White (Breaking Bad)|Walter White]] or [[Tony Soprano]], Frank feels at peace with his ruthless pragmatism and what he does in pursuit of power, and reminds us of the fact in his asides to the camera...he may be a ruthless [[antisocial personality disorder|sociopath]], but there's something to admire there".{{cite magazine|first=Alison|last=Willmore|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/television/house-of-cards-season-two-review-netflix|title=In Its Second Season, 'House of Cards' Brings Its D.C. Machinations to the Next Level|magazine=[[Indiewire]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=February 5, 2014|accessdate=February 11, 2014}} However, Willmore noted that Frank became lighter in season 2, noting that the season was "...delivered with more of a wink by Frank than before." Poniewozik notes that "It also remains a delight to watch Spacey pump the humid breath of life into House of Cards' arid Capitol chill. If only his character weren't so dominant of his surroundings as well. One reason the series' movements can feel so mechanical is that, so far, no one seems nearly in Underwood's league: not the adversaries he battles directly, nor the sad sacks that he gulls without their even knowing it." Chuck Barney of the ''[[San Jose Mercury News]]'' notes that the preview episodes show that "Frank's "[[Survivor (US TV series)|Survivor]]"-like back-stabbing is beginning to feel a bit repetitive." and that his lack of an adversarial foil has become an issue: "...things always seem to fall neatly into place for him. Even his showdowns with the president ([[Michel Gill]]) come off as one-sided..."{{cite web|first=Chuck|last=Barney|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/entertainment/ci_25088916/review-house-cards-returns-more-political-dirty-deeds|title=Review: 'House of Cards' returns for more political dirty deeds|newspaper=[[San Jose Mercury News]]|publisher=Bay Area News Group|location=San Jose, California|date=February 11, 2014|accessdate=February 11, 2014}} Verne Gay of ''[[Newsday]]'' notes that "Frank Underwood has no remorse, no superannuated sense of Washington tradition or decorum, and certainly no second thoughts. He is TV's perfect monster of the moment - a compleat malefactor, with a pleasing honey-toned drawl."{{cite web|first=Verne|last=Gay|url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/tv-zone-1.811968/house-of-cards-season-2-review-a-joyride-1.7059399|title='House of Cards' Season 2 review: A joyride|newspaper=[[Newsday]]|publisher=[[Tribune Media]]|location=New York City|date=February 13, 2014|accessdate=February 13, 2014|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140214094533/http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/tv-zone-1.811968/house-of-cards-season-2-review-a-joyride-1.7059399|archive-date=February 14, 2014}} [[Alessandra Stanley]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' says "By positing a Johnsonesque power broker and master schemer who wields cabalistic influence behind the scenes, ''House of Cards'' assigns order and purpose to what, in real life, is too often just an endless, baffling tick-tack-toe stalemate."{{cite web|first=Alessandra|last=Stanley|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/14/arts/television/house-of-cards-returns-with-more-dark-scheming.html|title=How Absolute Power Can Delight Absolutely: 'House of Cards' Returns, With More Dark Scheming|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=New York Times Company|location=New York City|date=February 13, 2013|accessdate=February 14, 2014}} [[NPR]]'s Eric Deggans says that Underwood "blends velvety charm and mesmerizing menace like no other character on television".{{cite web|first=Eric|last=Deggans|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/02/14/276444024/antihero-or-villain-in-house-of-cards-its-hard-to-tell|title=Antihero Or Villain? In 'House Of Cards,' It's Hard To Tell|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=February 14, 2014|accessdate=February 28, 2014}} ''[[New York Observer]]'' critic Drew Grant notes that although the series aired during the golden age of dramatic antiheroes, Underwood's villainy has become trite: "House of Cards is a good reminder, however, that there is a reason [[Iago]] wasn't the center of ''[[Othello]]''. Unrelenting, unexplained cruelty can be as pedantic as constant kindness."{{cite news|first=Drew|last=Grant|url=http://observer.com/2014/02/the-anhedonia-of-antiheroes-why-house-of-cardss-second-season-isnt-as-fun-as-it-should-be/|title=The Anhedonia of Antiheroes: Why House of Cards' Second Season Isn't as Fun as It Should Be|newspaper=[[The New York Observer]]|publisher=Observer Media|location=New York City|date=February 17, 2014|accessdate=February 28, 2014}} Spacey's portrayal was not without detractors: ''[[Hitfix]]'' reviewer [[Alan Sepinwall]] accused him of "hamming it up" and "phoning it in on a not very good show to begin with".{{cite web|last1=Sepinwall|first1=Alan|website=Ask Alan|title=Best movie star on TV, 'Constantine' and best-cast TV show ever|url=http://www.hitfix.com/videos/ask-alan-best-movie-star-on-tv-constantine-and-best-cast-tv-show-ever|accessdate=May 1, 2016|format=movie|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160531155424/http://www.hitfix.com/videos/ask-alan-best-movie-star-on-tv-constantine-and-best-cast-tv-show-ever|archivedate=May 31, 2016|df=mdy-all}} ===Season 3=== Reviews for season 3 of ''House of Cards'' were mostly positive. However, a few critics found the Underwood character was becoming repetitive: the critical consensus on the review aggregation site [[Rotten Tomatoes]] held that, "Season three introduces intriguing new political and personal elements to Frank Underwood's character, even if it feels like more of the same for some."http://www.rottentomatoes.com/tv/house-of-cards/s03/ Ed Power of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' wrote, "Everyone in House of Cards has an agenda - a secret twitching in the attic. The thrill, and the horror, may lie in the degree to which we catch reflections of real life in its dark, cool contours." {{cite web|first=Ed|last=Power|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/tv-and-radio-reviews/11438369/House-of-Cards-season-3-episode-1-review.html|title=House of Cards, season 3, episode 1, review: 'an underwhelming return'|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media]]|location=London, England|date=February 27, 2015|accessdate=April 14, 2016}} Some critics opined that the Underwood character is less interesting once he achieves his goal of becoming president and actually has to govern. "You could take the show seriously just as long as you didn't have to take it seriously, as long as it only took place in the dream world of imaginary fantasy politics," wrote Aaron Bady of ''[[The New Republic]]'', who compared Underwood unfavorably with [[Josiah Bartlett]] of ''[[The West Wing]]''. "But when a cartoon becomes president, it starts to look too fake to be real, but too real to be a cartoon. Frank plays the role of President Bartlett, a cartoon president doing things that would actually, in reality, be kind of great. But Bartlett was too good to be true, and the old Frank was too evil to be true. President Underwood is just too dull to be a fantasy, and so the props take center stage." Critics continued to praise Spacey's performance, however. Don Kaplan of ''[[The New York Daily News]]'' wrote, "Underwood's bottomless appetite for dark dealing keeps Spacey so deliciously detestable you can't help but keep rooting for the bad guy to win." {{cite news|first=Don|last=Kaplan|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/house-cards-tv-review-article-1.2129365|title='House of Cards' TV review: Season 3 is worth your weekend|newspaper=[[The New York Daily News]]|publisher=[[Tronc]]|location=New York City|date=February 25, 2015|accessdate=April 14, 2016}} ===Season 4=== In season 4, Jacob Solworthy wrote in his review of the first six episodes of season four: "Until now, 'House of Cards' has centred on the character's outward expression of power -- not to mention his hunger for it -- but the writers have shrewdly stripped that back, instead focusing on the character's internal fears in a way not dissimilar from [[Tony Soprano|Tony]]'s dream sequences in '[[The Sopranos]]'," he later added, "You'll never root for Frank more than you do by the end of these six episodes."{{cite news|first=Jacob|last=Stolworthy|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/features/house-of-cards-season-4-spoiler-free-thoughts-on-first-six-episodes-a6907091.html|title=House of Cards season 4: Spoiler-free thoughts on the first six episodes|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|publisher=Independent Print Ltd.|location=London, England|date=March 2, 2016|accessdate=April 14, 2016}} On the other hand, Daniel Fienberg from ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' was critical of Spacey's performance, writing: " Spacey's performance, which at least had an appealingly theatrical extravagance when the series began, has grown less enjoyable. Having reached a pinnacle, there's no way to root for Frank's striving anymore, if you ever were, but House of Cards has yet to commit to urging us to root for Frank's downfall."{{cite magazine|first=Daniel|last=Fienberg|title='House of Cards' Season 4: TV Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/house-cards-season-4-tv-872024|magazine=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Eldridge Industries]]|location=Los Angeles, California|date=March 1, 2016|accessdate=July 18, 2016}} There was also considerable mention of the evolution of Underwood's relationship with Claire. "[T]heir partnership has morphed into an entirely professional exercise, with a shared lust for power having supplanted more conventional matrimonial bonds," wrote Brian Lowry of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''. ''[[The Atlantic (magazine)|The Atlantic]]''{{'}}s Spencer Kornhaber remarked, however, that the utter ruthlessness displayed by Underwoods in the season finale may have represented a "[[jump the shark]]" moment for the series:
The Underwoods have murdered a politician and a journalist, and some innocents have also been collateral damage to their activities. Now, though, they've set out to maintain their power at the cost of mass casualties. Netflix hasn't said how many seasons are to come, but it's hard to imagine the show being watchable for all that much longer now that this rubicon of despicability has been crossed.{{cite web|first=Spencer|last=Kornhaber|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/03/house-of-cards-season-4-episode-13-the-live-binge-review-chapter-52-season-finale/472518/ |title=House of Cards season 4, Episode 13: The Live-Binge Review|magazine=[[The Atlantic (magazine)|The Atlantic]]|publisher=[[Emerson Collective]]|location=Boston, Massachusetts|date=March 7, 2016|accessdate=April 14, 2016}}
Some compared Underwood's story line in season 4 to the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 U.S. presidential election]].{{cite web|first=Brandon|last=Griggs|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/04/entertainment/house-of-cards-season-4-reviews-feat/index.html|title=House of Cards Season 4: What's the Verdict?|publisher=[[cnn.com]]|date=March 4, 2016|accessdate=April 14, 2016}} Brian Moyland of ''[[The Guardian (newspaper)|The Guardian]]'' wrote:
''House of Cards'' has never felt like the real presidency: Frank Underwood is evil incarnate, bumping off junior Congressmen and pushing journalists in front of trains. But now that, in real life, we're in the throes of such a bizarre presidential race, his machinations are starting to look almost viable. There are several parallels between Underwood's re-election campaign and the 2016 campaigns of [[Donald Trump]], [[Ted Cruz]], [[Hillary Clinton]] and [[Bernie Sanders]].{{cite web|first=Brian|last=Moyland|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/mar/04/house-of-cards-kkk-connection-frank-underwood-donald-trump-share |title=House of Cards: A KKK connection isn't all Frank Underwood and Donald Trump share|newspaper=[[The Guardian (newspaper)|The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|location=London, England|date=March 4, 2016|accessdate=April 14, 2016}}
===Season 5=== Spacey's performance as Frank Underwood in Season 5 - along with the series itself - received mixed reviews.
