{{Infobox person | name = Melanie Kaye/Kantrowitz | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth year|1945}} | birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]], United States | death_date = July 9, {{Death year and age|2018|1945}} | death_place = | nationality = [[Americans|American]] | other_names = | occupation = Essayist, poet, academic, political activist | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }}
'''Melanie Kaye/Kantrowitz''' (1945 – July 9, 2018) was a Jewish-American essayist, poet, academic, and political activist against racism and for economic and social justice.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bZRH7C3YVGcC&pg=PA301|title=Encyclopedia of Feminist Literature|access-date=July 14, 2018}}</ref>
==Early life== Born Melanie Kaye in 1945 in [[Brooklyn, New York]], her parents had anglicized their last name from Kantrowitz prior to her birth.<ref name=JTA/> Her grandparents emigrated to the [[United States]] from [[Eastern Europe]].<ref name="Kantrowitz, Klepfisz 1986, p264">Kaye/Kantrowitz and Klepfisz. ''The Tribe of Dina: A Jewish Women's Anthology'', 1986, {{ISBN|0-931103-02-9}}, pg. 264.</ref>
She later added Kantrowitz to her name to honor her Jewish roots. Kaye/Kantrowitz was active in the [[Harlem]] [[Civil Rights Movement]] as a teenager. When she was 17, she worked with the [[Harlem Education Project]]. About this she said "It was my first experience with a mobilizing proud community and with the possibilities of collective action."<ref>Kaye/Kantrowitz and Klepfisz. ''The Tribe of Dina: A Jewish Women's Anthology'', 1986, {{ISBN|0-931103-02-9}}, pp. 266, 286.</ref>
Kaye/Kantrowitz associated her activism with her [[Jewish]] upbringing,<ref name="Kantrowitz, Klepfisz 1986, p324">Kaye/Kantrowitz and Klepfisz. ''The Tribe of Dina: A Jewish Women's Anthology'', 1986, {{ISBN|0-931103-02-9}}, p. 324.</ref> stating that it was related to her family's Jewish cultural and political heritage "as much as the candles we lit for [[Hanukkah]], or the [[Passover Seder|Seders]] where bread and [[matzoh]] shared the table." She wrote in her essay "To Be a Radical Jew in the Late 20th Century" that her "parents had not pushed [her] into activism, yet clearly they raised [her] to do these things".<ref name="Kantrowitz, Klepfisz 1986, p264"/>
In 1966, she left New York to attend graduate school in [[Berkeley, California]]. Later, she moved to [[Portland, Oregon]], where she remained until 1979 before spending several years in [[New Mexico]].<ref>Kaye/Kantrowitz and Klepfisz. ''The Tribe of Dina: A Jewish Women's Anthology'', 1986, {{ISBN|0-931103-02-9}}, pp. 267-68.</ref>
==Activism== Kaye/Kantrowitz described herself as a "Conscious Jew".<ref name="Kantrowitz, Klepfisz 1986, p324"/> Along with [[Irena Klepfisz]] and [[Adrienne Rich]], among others, Kaye/Kantrowitz was a member of Di Vilde Chayes (English: The Wild Beasts), a Jewish feminist group that examined and responded to political issues in the [[Middle East]], as well as to [[antisemitism]].<ref>Kaye/Kantrowitz and Klepfisz. ''The Tribe of Dina: A Jewish Women's Anthology'', 1986, {{ISBN|0-931103-02-9}}, p. 7.</ref><ref>Mankiller, Wilma Pearl. ''The Reader's Companion to U.S. Women's History'', Houghton Mifflin, 1998; {{ISBN|0-618-00182-4}}, pg. 339.</ref>
In 1990, she served as a founding director for [[Jews for Racial and Economic Justice]] (JFREJ), a progressive Jewish organization focused mostly on [[anti-racist]] work and issues of [[economic justice]].<ref>Dykewomon, Elana. "Melanie Kaye/Kantrowitz: Phone Interview from NYC, Nov. 27, 1993", ''Sinister Wisdom'', Issue 52, Allies, Spring/Summer 1994, p. 27.</ref><ref name="Jewish Women's Archive"/> Kaye/Kantrowitz served on the JFREJ board from 1995 to 2004.<ref name="Jewish Women's Archive">{{cite web|url=https://jwa.org/feminism/kaye-kantrowitz-melanie|title=Melanie Kaye/Kantrowitz|publisher=[[Jewish Women's Archive]]|accessdate=November 28, 2017 }}</ref> Of her work with JFREJ, Kaye/Kantrowitz said: "Though the content of our mission is not specifically feminist, we have modeled feminist activism and included a feminist spin on issues such as hate violence, right of workers to organize, police brutality, and [[educational equity]]."<ref name="Jewish Women's Archive"/>
Around 1990, she also co-founded ''Beyond the Pale: The Progressive Jewish Radio Hour'', a radio program that aired weekly on [[WBAI]] (99.5 FM) which "mixes local, national, and international political debate and analysis, from a progressive Jewish perspective with the voices and sounds of contemporary Jewish culture".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jfrej.org/radio.html |title=Beyond the Pale: The Progressive Jewish Radio Hour |publisher=Jews for Racial and Economic Justice |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050213035344/http://www.jfrej.org/radio.html |archivedate=February 13, 2005 |accessdate=November 28, 2017 }}</ref>
Kaye/Kantrowitz also served on the steering committee of [[New Jewish Agenda]].<ref>Barrington, Judith. ''An Intimate Wilderness: Lesbian Writers on Sexuality'', The Eighth Mountain Press, 1991, {{ISBN|0-933377-09-6}}, p. 289.</ref>
==Academia== Melanie Kaye/Kantrowitz taught the first [[women's studies]] course at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. She also taught at [[Hamilton College (New York)|Hamilton College]], [[Brooklyn College]]/[[CUNY]], [[Vermont College]].,<ref name="Kantrowitz, Klepfisz 1986, p324"/> and [[Jewish studies]], [[history]] and [[comparative literature]] at [[Queens College]].
==Death== Kaye/Kantrowitz died on July 9, 2018, of [[Parkinson's disease]], aged 73.<ref name=JTA>{{cite web|url=https://www.jta.org/2018/07/12/top-headlines/melanie-kaye-kantrowitz-jewish-activist-racial-equality-dies-73|title=Melanie Kaye/Kantrowitz, Jewish activist for racial equality, dies at 73|date=July 12, 2018|work=[[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]]|accessdate=July 13, 2018}}</ref>
==Publications==
Kaye/Kantrowitz's works include: *''We Speak in Code: Poems and Other Writings'' (1980, Motheroot Publications) *''The Tribe of Dina: A Jewish Women’s Anthology'' (1989, Beacon Press; editor, with [[Irena Klepfisz]]) *''My Jewish Face, and Other Stories'' (1990, Aunt Lute Books) *''The Issue is Power: Essays on Women, Jews, Violence and Resistance'' (1995, Aunt Lute Books) *''The Colors of Jews: Racial Politics and Radical Diasporism'' (2007, Indiana University Press)
She contributed to anthologies, including: *''[[Lesbian Poetry: An Anthology]]'' (1981) *''Fight Back: Feminist Resistance to Male Violence'' (1981) *''Nice Jewish Girls: A Lesbian Anthology'' (1984)
Kaye/Kantrowitz also edited the lesbian periodical ''[[Sinister Wisdom]]'' from 1983 to 1987.<ref>Masthead, ''Sinister Wisdom'', Issue 52, Allies, Spring/Summer 1994, interior cover page.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}

{{Infobox serial killer |name=Metod Trobec |image= |caption= |birthname=Metod Trobec |alias= |birth_date={{Birth date|1948|6|6|df=y}} |birth_place=[[Planina nad Horjulom]], [[Upper Carniola]], [[Slovenia]] |death_date={{Death date and age|2006|5|30|1948|7|6|df=y}} |death_place=Dob pri Mirni Prison, [[Slovenska Vas, Šentrupert|Slovenska Vas]], [[Slovenia]] |cause=[[Suicide]] |conviction= |sentence=[[Death]]
[[Clemency|Commuted]] to 35 years in prison |victims=5 |beginyear=1976 |endyear=1978 |country=[[Slovenia]] |states= |apprehended= }} '''Metod Trobec''' (June 6, 1948 – May 30, 2006) was a [[Slovenes|Slovene]] [[serial killer]]. == Life and death == Trobec was born as an illegitimate child in [[Planina nad Horjulom]]. At the age of 14 he is said to have burned his neighbor's hay, and to have stolen a moped at age 18. After doing his military service he worked for [[Yugoslav Railways]] and then emigrated to Germany. He returned to Slovenia in 1974 and committed several crimes, and was sentenced to 13 months in prison. Between 1976 and 1978[http://www.slovenskenovice.si/crni-scenarij/doma/dolenja-vas-kraj-nesrecnega-imena Zakrajšek, Vojko. 2012. "Dolenja vas, kraj nesrečnega imena". ''Slovenske novice'' (5 Jan.).] {{sl icon}} he raped, killed, and cremated at least five women.{{#tag:ref|Trobec was convicted of the murders of Vida Markovčič, Marjana Cankar, Urška Brečko, Ana Plevnik, and Zorka Nikolić. After his sentencing, the identity papers of Olga Pajić were also found in his house in [[Dolenja Vas pri Polhovem Gradcu]] and he is believed to have killed her.|group=Note}} He was sentenced to death (the last death sentence in Slovenia), but this was commuted to 20 years in prison. During his imprisonment he tried to kill fellow prisoners twice, and 15 years were added to his sentence. He committed suicide at Dob pri Mirni Prison in [[Slovenska Vas, Šentrupert|Slovenska Vas]] on 30 May 2006. He was buried at state expense in an anonymous grave in [[Šentrupert]].[http://www.casnik.si/index.php/2011/05/30/serijski-morilec-metod-trobec/ Koncilja, Franci. 2011. "Serijski morilec Metod Trobec" ''Časnik'' (30 May).] {{sl icon}}[http://web.sc-celje.si/tomi/seminarske2007/SerijskiMorilci/slovenija.htm Serijski morilci v Sloveniji] {{sl icon}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mladina.si/tednik/200623/clanek/nar--zlocin-marcel_stefancic_jr/|title=Metod - portret slovenske povprečnosti (Metod: A portrait of Slovenian mediocrity)|last=Štefančič, Jr.|first=Marcel |publisher=Mladina|language=Slovenian|accessdate=2009-03-02}}{{cite web|url=http://skcentral.com/news.php?readmore=1409|title=Most Famous Serial Killer in Former SFRY Commits Suicide in Slovenian Prison|work=Posted by Joe on May 30, 2006|publisher=skcentral.com|accessdate=2009-03-02}} At the time of his death he had [[prostate cancer]] and spent 27 years in prison, which is a Slovenian record.[http://svet24.si/clanek/538616e49b6fa/si-je-metod-trobec-res-sodil-sam Svet24.si - Metod Trobec na svobodi ...] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529103434/http://svet24.si/clanek/538616e49b6fa/si-je-metod-trobec-res-sodil-sam |date=2014-05-29 }} ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=Note}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Trobec, Metod}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:Slovenian rapists]] [[Category:Slovenian serial killers]] [[Category:Male serial killers]] [[Category:Serial killers who committed suicide in prison custody]] [[Category:Slovenian people who died in prison custody]] [[Category:Prisoners who died in Slovenian detention]] [[Category:Suicides in Slovenia]] [[Category:Criminals who committed suicide]] [[Category:Slovenian people convicted of murder]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Slovenia]] [[Category:People from the Municipality of Dobrova-Polhov Gradec]] [[Category:Male suicides]] {{crime-bio-stub}} {{Slovenia-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} On 6 October 1998, [[Prime Minister of Pakistan]] [[Nawaz Sharif]] relieved the [[Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee|Chairman]] of the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee]] and the [[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Army Staff]] of Pakistan, General '''[[Jehangir Karamat]]''', from the command of the [[Pakistan Armed Forces]] for making public statements regarding and contradicting the policies of public administration.<ref name="The New York Times">{{cite news|last=CELIA W. DUGGER|title=Pakistani Premier Prevails in Clash With General|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/20/world/pakistani-premier-prevails-in-clash-with-general.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|accessdate=12 March 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=20 October 1998}}</ref> At a public and political science circles, General Karamat had a popular support and occupied a prestigious image in the country for his role to promote [[Democracy in Pakistan|democratic]] process in the country. His dismissal remains a controversial topic in the field of [[civil-military relations]], and the move remains still questionable at the political science circles of Pakistan.<ref name="STory of Pakistan"/>
A war veteran of [[Indo-Pakistani wars]] and former professor of [[political science]] at the [[National Defence University, Pakistan|National Defence University]] (NDU), General Karamat was an apolitical and professional military leader, but confrontation involving the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan|Fourteenth Amendment]] and matters of principle of [[civilian control of the military]] was ingrained, which eventually led the relieving of General Jehangir Karamat from his command of the military by Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif on October 1998.<ref name="STory of Pakistan"/>
==Background==
===Nawaz Sharif===
As scheduled, the [[Pakistani general elections, 1997|general elections]] were held on 3 February 1997, which marked the return of [[Nawaz Sharif]] with an exclusive, [[Majority government|two-third majority]] in the [[Parliament of Pakistan|Parliament]].<ref name="STory of Pakistan"/> Just after days of re-electing for his second term, Prime Minister Sharif faced serious constitutional crises with the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan|Supreme Court]] and the [[President of Pakistan|Presidency]] on the other side. Nawaz Sharif made very important Constitutional Amendments that inserted in the [[Constitution of Pakistan|Constitution]] which introduced termination of the [[Eighth Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan|Eighth Amendment]] and passing of the [[Thirteenth Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan|Thirteenth Amendment]], with the enaction of the anti-corruption bill in 1997.<ref name="STory of Pakistan"/>
Sharif's constitutional moves were challenged by the [[Chief Justice of Pakistan|Chief Justice]] [[Syed Sajjad Ali Shah|Sajjad Ali Shah]] and President [[Farooq Leghari]]; both were forced to reign by Nawaz Sharif on 2 December 1997.<ref name="STory of Pakistan"/> After Sharif ordering the [[nuclear tests]] in 1998 and his unsuccessful attempt to pass the [[Fifteenth Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan|Fifteenth Amendment]], a number of military officers publicly disagreed with the administration's policy over administration.<ref name="STory of Pakistan"/> This confrontation led to the resignation of General Jehangir Karamat on 7 October 1998. General Karamat was replaced by General [[Pervez Musharraf]].<ref name="STory of Pakistan">{{cite news|last=Staff|title=Nawaz Sharif becomes Prime Minister|url=http://storyofpakistan.com/nawaz-sharif-becomes-prime-minister-2/|accessdate=12 March 2013|newspaper=STory of Pakistan|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115220428/http://storyofpakistan.com/nawaz-sharif-becomes-prime-minister-2/|archive-date=2012-11-15}}</ref>
===Jehangir Karamat=== In stature and seniority, General Karamat was a foremost army generals in the [[Pakistan Military]].<ref name="Routledge">{{cite book|last=Aziz|first=Mazhar|title=Military control in Pakistan : the parallel state|year=2008|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-0-415-43743-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wCm2DFZblOYC&pg=PA83&dq=Dismissal+of+General+Jehangir+Karamat&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ecc-UZaSNMqQyAHz44Bo&ved=0CEsQuwUwBA#v=onepage&q=Dismissal%20of%20General%20Jehangir%20Karamat&f=true}}</ref> A son of civil servant and a highly decorated war veteran of [[Indo-Pakistani wars]], Karamat was an academic who graduated with a top of his [[Pakistan Military Academy|PMA Kakul]] class of 1961 and later fully tenured as professor of [[political science]] at the [[National Defence University, Pakistan|National Defence University]] (NDU) during most of the 1970s and 1980s.<ref name="Routledge"/>
Karamat was a recipient of Pakistan's highest military and civilian honours as well as occupied a good image in country's public circles.<ref name="Routledge"/> He had a distinguish combat career, and many of his students at NDU would ascended in prestigious combat assignments in the country's military science circles.<ref name="Routledge"/> In 1995, Karamat gained national publicity after thwarting the [[1995 Pakistani coup d'état attempt|conspiracy]] against Prime minister [[Benazir Bhutto]], and his credentials would lead to him to be appointed simultaneously to four-star assignments, [[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Army Staff]] and [[Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee]] by Benazir Bhutto.<ref name="Routledge"/>
==Events leading up to the relief==
===Problems with Supreme Court and Presidency=== {{Main|Supreme Court of Pakistan#The attack on the Supreme Court in 1997|l1=1997 Pakistan Supreme Court incident|Farooq Leghari}}
The conservative mass led by Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif had come to the power with a two-majority as a result of [[Pakistani general elections, 1997|1997 general elections]]. Sharif established the [[Anti Terrorism Court of Pakistan|Anti Terrorism Courts]] (ATC), [[National Accountability Bureau|Anti-Corruption Bill]] and passed the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan|Fourteenth Amendment]] to the constitution, all in 1997.<ref name=PublicAffairs>{{cite book|last=Lieven|first=Anatol|title=Pakistan : a hard country|publisher=PublicAffairs|location=New York|isbn=978-1-61039-021-7|page=114|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ztr4xfSjH_4C&pg=PA114&dq=Nawaz+Sharif+attack+on+supreme+court&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ftI_UY6lMsblyQGB54GIAQ&ved=0CDgQuwUwAQ#v=onepage&q=Nawaz%20Sharif%20attack%20on%20supreme%20court&f=true|edition=1st}}</ref> After criticising the [[Chief Justice of Pakistan|Chief Justice]], the supreme court summoned Nawaz Sharif of [[Contempt of court]] and appeared in supreme court with party workers, members, chief ministers, and constituents to hear the proceedings.<ref name="Brookings Institution Press"/> Unruly party workers stormed into the Supreme Court, forcing Chief Justice [[Sajjad Ali Shah]] to remove the finding of contempt against Prime minister Sharif.<ref name=PublicAffairs/> Hundreds of PML-N supporters and members of its youth wing, the Muslim Students Front (MSF), breached the police barrier around the courthouse when defence lawyer [[S.M. Zafar]] was arguing Sharif's case.<ref name="Brookings Institution Press">{{cite book|last=Cohen|first=Stephen P.|title=The idea of Pakistan|year=2004|publisher=Brookings Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|isbn=0-8157-1502-1|pages=219–220|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-78yjVybQfkC&pg=PA150&dq=1997+attack+on+supreme+court+pakistan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Hs8_UYfvA8G8yAGGwIF4&ved=0CDAQuwUwAA#v=onepage&q=1997%20attack%20on%20supreme%20court%20pakistan&f=true|edition=1. paperback}}</ref> The partisans invaded the supreme court premises and intimated the [[List of Justices of Supreme Court of Pakistan|senior judges]] at the supreme court; all of this actions were recorded in security cameras and television channels broadcast the event nationwide.<ref name="Routledge"/><ref name="Brookings Institution Press"/>
Chief Justice Shah wrote a letter to President [[Farooq Leghari]] to call for armed forces actions against Sharif.<ref name="Brookings Institution Press"/> However, the constant pressure of Farooq Leghari deteriorated his health and resigned from the presidency.<ref name="Brookings Institution Press"/> Chief Justice Shah's tenured was cut short when Sharif appointed Justice [[Saeeduzzaman Siddiqui]] in his place, and his appointment was approved by the new president; Shah also resigned from the supreme court after hearing the news on television channels.<ref name="Brookings Institution Press"/>
===Public statements and relief===
After ordering the [[nuclear tests]] in 1998, Prime minister Sharif chaired the [[Defence Committee of the Cabinet (Pakistan)|Defence Committee of the Cabinet (DCC)]] session with the chairman and chiefs of armed forces to overview the situation with India.<ref name="Yale University Press"/> Although both [[Nawaz Sharif]] and general [[General Jehangir Karamat|Jehangir Karamat]] were educated and hold common beliefs concerning the national security, but problems arose with chairman joint chiefs and chief of army staff general Karamat on October 1998.<ref name="Yale University Press"/>
While addressing the naval officers and cadets at the [[Pakistan Naval War College|Naval War College]], general Karamat stressed the re-creation of [[National Security Council of Pakistan|National Security Council]] (instead of DCC)<ref name="nytsoldier">Crossette, Barbara. [https://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/13/world/coup-pakistan-man-soldier-s-soldier-not-political-general-pervez-musharraf.html "Coup in Pakistan – Man in the News; A Soldier's Soldier, Not a Political General."] New York Times (13 October 1999).</ref> which would be backed by a "team of civil-military experts"<ref name="Yale University Press"/> for devising policies to seek resolution ongoing problems relating the civil-military issues; also recommended a "neutral but competent [[Civil Service of Pakistan|bureaucracy]] and administration of at federal level and the establishment of [[Local government in Pakistan|Local governments]] in [[Provinces of Pakistan|four provinces]].<ref name="Yale University Press"/>
This proposal was met with hostility, and it succeeded all in accomplishing was pricking the Prime minister's highly inflated altered ego.<ref name="Yale University Press"/> Nawaz Sharif's dismissal of general Karamat,<ref name="nytsoldier"/> plummeted his mandate in the public circles and criticism he received from [[Leader of the Opposition (Pakistan)|Leader of the Opposition]] [[Benazir Bhutto]] was rogue.<ref name="Yale University Press">{{cite book|last=Abbas|first=Hassan|title=Pakistan's Drift to Extremism|year=2002|publisher=Yale University Press|location=United States|isbn=9780765614964|page=66|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GiKm-ahTpS8C&pg=PA166&dq=lieutenant+general+ali+kuli+khan&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UpG4T9WYAYmJiAKktvH1Bg&ved=0CGQQuwUwCA#v=onepage&q=lieutenant%20general%20ali%20kuli%20khan&f=true}}</ref>
Sharif summoned the chairman joint chiefs and notified him of his relieving from the service.<ref name="Dawn Archives">{{cite news|last=Staff|title=Karamat retired, Musharraf takes over as COAS|url=http://www.lib.virginia.edu/area-studies/SouthAsia/SAserials/Dawn/1998/10Oct98.html#kara|accessdate=13 March 2013|newspaper=Dawn Archives|date=10 October 1998}}</ref> On 6 October 1998, Nawaz Sharif dismissed and signed the relieving papers which went on effect immediately.<ref name="Public Affairs, Kathy"/> Many in Pakistan became surprised of Sharif's moved since the dismissal of four-star general was never happened before in country's [[History of Pakistan|short history]].<ref name="Public Affairs, Kathy">{{cite book|last=Gannon|first=Kathy|title=I is for infidel : from holy war to holy terror in Afghanistan|year=2005|publisher=Public Affairs, Kathy|location=New York|isbn=978-1-58648-312-8|pages=145–146|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h64BZjkwN68C&pg=PA145&dq=Dismissal+of+General+Jehangir+Karamat&hl=en&sa=X&ei=g9E_UbzGDYWWyAGp7YDICQ&ved=0CEEQuwUwAzgK#v=onepage&q=Dismissal%20of%20General%20Jehangir%20Karamat&f=true|edition=1.}}</ref>
==Aftermath==
===Response and fallout=== With Karamat's dismissal, it was widely felt in the armed forces that Sharif had ruthlessly established his control all over the country, including the military.<ref name="Rosen Publications">{{cite book|last=Daniel E. Harmon|title=Pervez Musharraf: President of Pakistan|year=2008|publisher=Rosen Publications|location=United Kingdom|isbn=978-1-4270-9208-3|pages=65–66|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jisbSz2h9zYC&pg=PA65}}</ref> The dismissal of General Karamat was least popular decision in Sharif's prime ministerial ship, and his approval ratings plummeted.<ref name="Rosen Publications"/> Media Minister [[Syed Mushahid Hussain]] and later Prime minister himself justified his actions on national and international media:
{{quote|text=In a democratic society, would a Chief of Army Staff and chairman Joint Chiefs talk about the Government like that? What happened to [[Douglas MacArthur|General MacArthur?]] Mr. [[Harry S. Truman|Harry Truman]] did not [[Relief of General Douglas MacArthur|waste much time]]. Pakistan is finally becoming a normal democratic society.|sign=Mushahid Hussain, Media Minister in Nawaz Government|source=<ref name="The New York Times"/>}}
The relieve of General Karamat was a heated issue discussed even by his senior government ministers.<ref name=OUP>{{cite book|last=Aziz|first=Sartaj|title=Between Dreams and Realities: Some Milestones in Pakistan’s History|year=2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Karachi, Pakistan|isbn=978-0-19-547718-4|page=408|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2009\08\09\story_9-8-2009_pg3_5}}</ref> The most-senior and the former Treasury minister [[Sartaj Aziz]] gave vehement criticism and showed opposition to the Prime minister for making this move.<ref name=OUP/>
Writing a thesis in his book, ''Between Dreams and Realities: Some Milestones in Pakistan’s History'', Aziz maintained: "Blunder of firing of General Karamatt; others will blame Nawaz Sharif for many mistakes he made. But in my view, the most serious of these mistakes was Nawaz Sharif’s decision to remove General Jehangir Karamat as chief of army staff in October 1998". Aziz was extremely confident and certain that [[Chief of General Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of General Staff]] [[Lieutenant-General]] [[Ali Kuli Khan]] would be appointed as the Chief of Army Staff based on his seniority, merit, among a very competent officer, and next in seniority to General Karamat.<ref name=OUP/> {{quote|text=It came to the conclusion that in relieving General Jehangir Karamat, Prime minister Sharif had committed a "blunder". He also failed to recognize that despite his heavy mandate, it was not advisable for him to dismiss two army chiefs in less than a year. In doing so he had overplayed his hands and effectively derailed the democratic process for nine long year...|sign=Sartaj Aziz, 2009|source<ref name=OUP/>}}
In 1999, Nawaz Sharif later dismissed [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|Chief of Naval Staff]] Admiral [[Admiral Fasih Bokhari|Fasih Bokhari]] to promote General Musharraf to chairman joint chiefs.<ref name="Yale University Press"/> The following month, a failed attempt to dismiss Musharraf led to a [[1999 Pakistani coup d'état|military coup d'état]] against Prime minister Nawaz Sharif in 1999.<ref name="Yale University Press"/>
==Citations and references== {{reflist}}
==Readings and books== * {{cite book|last=Aziz|first=Mazhar|title=Military control in Pakistan : the parallel state|year=2008|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=978-0-415-43743-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wCm2DFZblOYC&pg=PA83&dq=Dismissal+of+General+Jehangir+Karamat&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ecc-UZaSNMqQyAHz44Bo&ved=0CEsQuwUwBA#v=onepage&q=Dismissal%20of%20General%20Jehangir%20Karamat&f=true}} * {{cite book|last=Riedel|first=Bruce|title=Deadly embrace : Pakistan, America, and the future of the global jihad|year=2010|publisher=Brookings Institution Press|location=Washington, D.C.|isbn=978-0-8157-0557-4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X3RPdFmqxwAC&pg=PA45&lpg=PA45&dq=Dismissal+of+General+Jehangir+Karamat&source=bl&ots=NFPoF6fjnh&sig=jfHem4aztKtHH5Okiv8eqpqC0_8&hl=en&sa=X&ei=f8c-Ua78HoSJywGU04DADA&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=Dismissal%20of%20General%20Jehangir%20Karamat&f=true}}

United Kingdom | language = English
French | budget = | gross = }} '''''Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired''''' is a 2008 [[documentary film]] directed by [[Marina Zenovich]].DiMare, Phillip C. Movies in American History: An Encyclopedia ABC Clio Publishing Santa Barbara California 2011 pages 780-781 It concerns film director [[Roman Polanski]] and [[Roman Polanski sexual abuse case|his sexual abuse case]]. It examines the events that led to Polanski [[Roman_Polanski_sexual_abuse_case#Conviction_and_flight|fleeing]] the United States after being embroiled in a controversial trial, and his unstable reunion with his adopted country. A follow-up to the film, also directed by Zenovich, titled ''Roman Polanski: Odd Man Out'' was released on 26 March 2013, detailing Polanski's successful legal battle to avoid [[Extradition_law_in_the_United_States#Extradition_to_the_United_States|extradition to the US]], a battle that took place after ''Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired'' came out.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/roman-polanski-odd-man-out-and-the-seagull-secure-financing-through-new-investment-hub-slated#.UAQZh3VPfQc |title='Roman Polanski: Odd Man Out' and 'The Seagull' First Projects to Secure Financing Through New Investment Hub Slated|Filmmakers,FilmIndustry,FilmFestivals, Awards & Movie Reviews |publisher=Indiewire |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}}[http://www.filmsdistribution.com/fd_film.php?id_film=409 FILMS DISTRIBUTION] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217075405/http://www.filmsdistribution.com/fd_film.php?id_film=409 |date=17 February 2012 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/roman-polanski-odd-man-out/trailers/3513929 |title=Roman Polanski: Odd Man Out |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=2014-02-01}} ==Reception== [[Metacritic]] rates ''Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired'' a score of 78/100 based on 16 reviews ("generally favorable").{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/roman-polanski-wanted-and-desired |title=Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |date=2008-07-11 |accessdate=2014-07-19}} [[Rotten Tomatoes]] scores the film at 89% positive reviews based on 46 reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/roman_polanski_wanted_and_desired/ |title=Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}} Cathleen McGuigan, reviewing the film for [[Newsweek]], referred to the film as "deft and subtle" and particularly noted "an enigmatic little scene near the end [where] [y]ou see a fierce old whale of a man in a chair, banging a drum while an elfin youth jumps and hops to the beats, like a puppet on a string. The hopping boy finally escapes his tormentor by scurrying and tumbling across a field, running toward the Eiffel Tower in the distance. The tyrannized, barefoot kid is [[Roman Polanski|Polanski]] himself, and the footage is from a 16-minute short called '[[The Fat and the Lean]]' that he made in 1961, on the brink of his fame as a brilliant new European director. The wordless scene may last less than a minute in [[Marina Zenovich]]'s documentary, but it sticks with you, and it echoes another clip in her film. This one is from a television interview Polanski did decades later where he says he felt like 'a mouse with which an abominable cat was making sport.' The cat in question was Los Angeles Judge [[Laurence J. Rittenband]], who'd presided over the director's 1977 criminal case for having sex with a 13-year-old girl."{{cite web |first=Cathleen |last=McGuigan |title=Hollywood’s Most Beloved Fugitive |url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/138382 |publisher=[[Newsweek]] |date=2 June 2008 |accessdate=2009-09-30 }} One negative review by Bill Wyman, writing for [[Salon (website)|Salon]], stated: "The film, which has inexplicably gotten all sorts of praise, whitewashes what Polanski did in blatant and subtle fashion[.] The tone is set early on, when a friend of Polanski's tells of being woken up and informed that the director had to call his attorney. The moment is actually played for laughs, with interspersed shots of a worried [[Mia Farrow]] using the phone in a scene from '[[Rosemary's Baby (film)|Rosemary's Baby]]' — that, too, about a horrifically abused woman. But the scene isn't used to illustrate the victim's story -- it's about poor Roman. He's the person making the desperate phone call. It's an odd juxtaposition when you think about it."{{cite web |first=Bill |last=Wyman |title=Whitewashing Roman Polanski |url=http://www.salon.com/2009/02/19/roman_polanski_documentary/ |publisher=[[Salon.com]] |date=2 February 2009 |accessdate=2009-09-29 }} Nathan Southern of [[Allmovie]] writes that, "filmmaker [[Marina Zenovich]] revisits this difficult case via extensive interviews with Geimer [the underage victim], defense attorney Douglas Dalton, Assistant DA Roger Gunson, and others. In the process, she raises pivotal questions about the U.S. legal system and the fairness of the judge, Laurence J. Rittenband (who was reportedly extremely vocal about his desire to topple Polanski) and encounters many recollections of judicial malfeasance from those who were involved."{{cite web |first=Nathan |last=Southern |title=Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired |url=http://www.allmovie.com/work/426678 |publisher=[[Allmovie]] |accessdate=2009-09-30 }} ==Awards== ''Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired'' was nominated for five primetime [[Emmy Award]]s and won two: "Outstanding Directing For Nonfiction Programming" and "Outstanding Writing for Nonfiction Programming".[http://www.emmys.com/shows/roman-polanski-wanted-and-desired Roman Polanski: Wanted And Desired] Emmys.com The [[National Board of Review of Motion Pictures]] awarded it the title of one of the top 5 documentaries of 2008.[http://www.nbrmp.org/awards/past.cfm?year=2008 National Board of Review of Motion Pictures Awards] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120516165456/http://www.nbrmp.org/awards/past.cfm?year=2008 |date=16 May 2012 }} It won the "Editing Award Documentary" at the [[Sundance Film Festival]][http://history.sundance.org/events/43 2008 Sundance Film Festival] sundance.org It was also listed as one of ten films in the "Hall of Shame" of the 2008 [[Women Film Critics Circle]] Awards.{{cite web|url=http://wfcc.wordpress.com/women-film-critics-circle-awards-2008/ |title=WOMEN FILM CRITICS CIRCLE AWARDS 2008 |publisher=Wfcc.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}} ==Retraction by David Wells== After the arrest of Roman Polanski in Switzerland in 2009, David Wells, now a retired deputy district attorney, recanted the interview he gave the director about advising the judge in the case in ''[[ex parte]]'' communication. According to Marcia Clarke of ''[[The Daily Beast]]'': :''"I lied,' Wells told me yesterday, referring to his comments in the movie that he told the judge how he could renege on a plea-bargain agreement and send Polanski back to jail after he had been released from a 42-day psychiatric evaluation—the heart of Polanski’s claims of prosecutorial and judicial misconduct. 'I know I shouldn’t have done it, but I did. The director of the documentary told me it would never air in the States. I thought it made a better story if I said I’d told the judge what to do."''{{cite news |first=Marcia |last=Clarke |title=Polanski's Lost Alibi |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2009-09-30/polanskis-lost-alibi/ |publisher=[[The Daily Beast]] |date=30 September 2009 |accessdate=2009-10-01 }} Zenovich responded, as reported by Peter Knegt at ''[[indieWire]]'': :''"I am perplexed by the timing of David Wells’ statement to the press that he lied in his interview with me for the documentary ‘Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired,’' she said. 'Since June of 2008, the film has been quite visible on U.S. television via HBO, in theaters and on DVD, so it is odd that David Wells has not brought this issue to my attention before.'' :''Zenovich said that the day she filmed Mr. Wells at the Malibu Courthouse, he gave her a one-hour interview. 'He signed a release like all my other interviewees, giving me permission to use his interview in the documentary worldwide," she said. "At no time did I tell him that the film would not air in the United States.'' :''She went on to say she is 'astonished' that Wells has changed his story. 'Mr. Wells was always friendly and open with me,' she said. 'At no point in the four years since our interview has he ever raised any issues about its content. In fact, in a July 2008 story in The New York Times, Mr. Wells corroborated the account of events that he gave in my film… It is a sad day for documentary filmmakers when something like this happens."''{{cite news |first=Peter |last=Knegt |title="Desired" Director Zenovich Responds To Polanski Prosecutor’s "Lies" |url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/desired_director_zenovich_responds_to_polanski_prosecutors_lies/ |publisher=[[indieWire]] |date=1 October 2009 |accessdate=2009-10-01 }} Michael Ceply commented on the affair in the ''[[New York Times]]'': :''"The incident points to the power and the limitations of the documentary art.[...] Pat Aufderheide, director of the Center for Social Media at American University [...] pointed out that the documentarians’ tendency to focus on 'untold stories' has occasionally reopened a legal case or righted a perceived wrong.[...]''" :"''But even an on-camera account like that of Mr. Wells, which provoked a legal challenge that is still before the appellate courts in California, has its vulnerabilities. Ms. Zenovich acknowledged on Thursday, for instance, that she had no second person describing the contacts between Mr. Wells, who was assigned to the courthouse but had no official role in the Polanski case, and Judge Rittenband, who has since died. 'There wasn’t a witness to the conversations with Rittenband,' she said.''" :"''Since Mr. Polanski’s arrest, Ms. Zenovich said, a strong public reaction against his misdeeds in the original case seem to have overridden concerns about any misdeeds in the courts. Originally charged with seven counts, including rape and sodomy, he pleaded guilty to having sex with a minor and then fled the country before his sentencing.''" :"''People don’t seem to connect to what this is, really, because of the crime, and the schism it has caused with finding normalcy and sanity' she said of her continuing examination of the Los Angeles legal system, with its problems with celebrity justice.''" :"''Even if Dave Wells were to be lying' in the original film, she said, 'we still have a judge who was instructing the prosecutor and defense lawyer on how to behave, and doing it based on how he would look in the media,' she added, referring to other allegations in the documentary."''{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Ceply |title=2008 Film Plays Role in Polanski Case |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/02/movies/02polanski.html?_r=1&ref=todayspaper |publisher=New York Times |date=1 October 2009 |accessdate=2009-10-01 }} ==See also== * [[Charlotte Lewis#Accusations against Polanski|Charlotte Lewis]] (Accusations against Polanski) * [[The Girl: A Life in the Shadow of Roman Polanski]] a book by Samantha Geimer ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|1157705|Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired}} *{{Amg movie|426678|Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired}} * Photcopy of statement dated June 11, 2008, signed by Douglas Dalton and Roger Gunson {{cite web | title=Polanski Prosecutor and Defense Attorney Charge L.A. Court Made "False And Reprehensible Statement" | url=http://www.deadlinehollywooddaily.com/exclusive-polanski-prosecutor-and-defense-attorney-charge-la-superior-court-made-false-and-reprehensible-statement/ | publisher= Deadline Hollywood Daily | last=Finke | first=Nikki | date=2008-06-11}} * The public information office at the Los Angeles County Superior Court sends out this media advisory on Roman Polanski documentary on HBO. {{cite web | title=HBO's Polanski doc has an error | url=http://www.laobserved.com/archive/2008/06/hbos_polanski_doc_has_an_1.php | publisher=LA Observed | date=2008-06-09 | first=Kevin | last=Roderick }} * [http://www.romanpolanskiwantedanddesired.com Roman Polanski: Wanted and Desired] Official Website and Blog for film, by Director Marina Zenovich. {{Roman Polanski}} {{HBO documentaries}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Roman Polanski: Wanted And Desired}} [[Category:2008 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:Documentary films about film directors and producers]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:American independent films]] [[Category:Documentary films about child abuse]] [[Category:British independent films]] [[Category:Roman Polanski]]

{{Infobox NFL biography |name = Sam Bradford |image = Rams quarterback Sam Bradford at the coaching clinic.jpg |caption = Bradford in 2012 |currentteam = Free agent |number = |position = [[Quarterback]] |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1987|11|8|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]] |death_date = |death_place = |height_ft = 6 |height_in = 4 |weight_lbs = 224 |high_school = [[Putnam City North High School|Oklahoma City (OK) Putnam City North]] |college = [[Oklahoma Sooners football|Oklahoma]] |draftyear = 2010 |draftround = 1 |draftpick = 1 |pastteams = * [[History of the St. Louis Rams|St. Louis Rams]] ({{NFL Year|2010}}–{{NFL Year|2014}}) * [[Philadelphia Eagles]] ({{NFL Year|2015}}) * [[Minnesota Vikings]] ({{NFL Year|2016}}–{{NFL Year|2017}}) * [[Arizona Cardinals]] ({{NFL Year|2018}}) |status= |highlights = * [[NFL Offensive Rookie of the Year]] (2010) * [[Heisman Trophy]] (2008) * [[Davey O'Brien Award]] (2008) * [[Associated Press College Football Player of the Year|Associated Press Player of the Year]] (2008) * [[Sporting News College Football Player of the Year|''Sporting News'' Player of the Year]] (2008) * Consensus [[College Football All-America Team|All-American]] ([[2008 College Football All-America Team|2008]]) * First-team All-[[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]] (2008) |statweek= |statseason=2018 |statlabel1=Passing attempts |statvalue1=2,967 |statlabel2=Passing completions |statvalue2=1,855 |statlabel3=Percentage |statvalue3=62.5 |statlabel4=[[Touchdowns|TD]]–[[Interceptions|INT]] |statvalue4=103–61 |statlabel5=Passing yards |statvalue5=19,449 |statlabel6=[[Passer rating]] |statvalue6=84.5 | nflnew = sambradford/497095 }}
'''Samuel Jacob Bradford''' (born November 8, 1987) is an [[American football]] [[quarterback]] who is a free agent. He has played in the [[National Football League]] (NFL) for the [[History of the St. Louis Rams|St. Louis Rams]], [[Philadelphia Eagles]], [[Minnesota Vikings]], and [[Arizona Cardinals]]. Bradford attended [[Putnam City North High School]] in [[Oklahoma City]], where he starred in football, basketball and golf. As a senior quarterback in 2005, he threw for 2,029 yards and 17 touchdowns in 12 games. Bradford was not highly recruited coming out of high school, but he did receive a scholarship offer from the [[University of Oklahoma]], which he accepted. After a redshirt season in 2006, Bradford threw for 3,121 yards and 36 touchdowns as a redshirt freshman. In 2008, Bradford became only the second sophomore to win the [[Heisman Trophy]] as he led the highest-scoring offense in NCAA history, throwing for 4,464 yards with 48 touchdowns and just six interceptions. He again led the nation in passing and also added five rushing touchdowns as the Sooners went 12-1 and advanced to the BCS national title game.
Bradford declared for the NFL Draft following the 2009 season and was drafted by the [[St. Louis Rams]] with the [[List of first overall National Football League draft picks|first overall]] selection in the [[2010 NFL Draft]]. That year, Bradford set the record for most completions by a rookie in NFL history, which helped earn him the [[NFL Offensive Rookie of the Year]] award. Prior to the start of the 2015 season, the Rams traded Bradford along with a 2015 fifth round pick to the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] in exchange for quarterback [[Nick Foles]], a 2015 fourth-round pick, and a 2016 second-round pick. Following his 2015 campaign with the Eagles, in which he set career-highs in passing yards (3,725), completion percentage (65%) and yards per attempt (7.0), the [[Minnesota Vikings]] acquired Bradford after their starting quarterback [[Teddy Bridgewater]] was lost to a season-ending knee injury before the start of the season. {{TOClimit|limit=3}}
==Early years== Bradford was born to Kent and Martha Bradford in [[Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]].<ref name="soonersports.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/football-depth-chart.html |title=Official Site of the Oklahoma Sooners |publisher=SoonerSports.com |date=2010-09-22 |accessdate=2010-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100925221001/http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/football-depth-chart.html |archivedate=2010-09-25 |df= }}</ref> He attended [[Putnam City North High School]] in Oklahoma City, where he starred in [[high school football|football]], basketball, baseball, and golf for the Putnam City North Panthers.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.twincities.com/2016/09/24/vikings-qb-sam-bradford-was-an-all-everything-athlete-until-football-won-out/ |title=Vikings QB Sam Bradford was an all-everything athlete until football won out |date=2016-09-24 |work=Twin Cities |access-date=2018-01-25 |language=en-US}}</ref> Bradford played as a [[pitcher]] in [[baseball]], but gave up after his freshman year. He earned All-City honors as a junior [[quarterback]] in [[high school football|football]] by ''The Oklahoman''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsok.com/article/2878373|title=The Oklahoman's Big All-City Football team: Roster and player profiles|date=19 December 2004|website=newsok.com|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref> Following his senior season in which he threw for 2,029 yards and 17 touchdowns in 12 games, Bradford was named to the Oklahoma Coaches Association All-State Team and was a Second-Team All-State pick by ''[[The Oklahoman]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsok.com/article/2891825|title=BOYS ALL-STATE ROSTER|date=10 April 2005|website=newsok.com|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="SS_Bio">{{cite web | title=14 Sam Bradford | publisher=SoonerSports.com | url=http://soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/bradford_sam00.html | accessdate=2007-09-11 }}</ref>
Bradford was also a Division I-caliber [[basketball]] player. As a senior, he averaged 18.6 points and 10.5 rebounds per game and played on the same elite [[Amateur Athletic Union|AAU]] team as fellow Oklahoma City native and [[Detroit Pistons]] star [[Blake Griffin]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/columns/story?columnist=maisel_ivan&id=3134076|title=Oklahoma's rookie QB makes college game looks easy|publisher=ES-28PN|accessdate=2007-11-30|date=2007-11-30|first=Ivan|last=Maisel}}</ref> In [[golf]], Bradford defeated future [[PGA Tour|PGA]] touring pros [[Kevin Tway]] and [[Robert Streb]] during his high school career. In addition to the aforementioned sports, Bradford also played [[hockey]] in his youth. In 1999, when Bradford was 12, his travel team, the Junior Blazers, won a regional championship, beating a team from Houston. He quit the sport that same year, and according to his former hockey coach [[Mike McEwen (ice hockey)|Mike McEwen]], who played on three [[Stanley Cup]] championship teams with the [[New York Islanders]], Bradford had the talent to make it in the [[National Hockey League|NHL]]. McEwen also said that Bradford was one of the best players he ever coached.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/eagles/Sam_Bradford_Eagles_All_American_everything.html|title=Sam Bradford: All-American everything|website=philly.com|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref>
In the spring of 2005, by the end of Bradford's junior season, he garnered interest from several Division I programs, including [[Stanford Cardinal football|Stanford]], [[Michigan Wolverines football|Michigan]], [[Texas Tech Red Raiders football|Texas Tech]], and nearby Oklahoma. Following his senior season, Bradford was viewed as a two-to-three-star recruit and was not that highly ranked among the high school class of 2006, with his highest ranking being No. 12 among only pro-style quarterbacks by recruiting source ''[[Rivals.com]]''.<ref>{{cite news |first=Pete |last=Thamel |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Bradford Wins Heisman, but the Top Prize Awaits |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/14/sports/ncaafootball/14heisman.html |work=[[New York Times]] |publisher= |date=2008-12-13 |accessdate= }}</ref> Bradford was ranked behind [[Pat Devlin (American football)|Pat Devlin]], [[Isiah Williams|"Juice" Williams]] and [[Josh Freeman]], and was overshadowed by the likes of five-star recruits like [[Mitch Mustain]], [[Matthew Stafford]] and [[Tim Tebow]].<ref name="SS_Bio"/><ref>{{cite web | url=http://recruiting.scout.com/a.z?s=73&p=9&c=4&pid=10&yr=2006 | title=Football Recruiting – Quarterback | accessdate=2007-09-11 | publisher=Scout.com }}</ref>
{{College athlete recruit start|40=yes|collapse=no|year=2006}} {{College athlete recruit entry | recruit = Sam Bradford | position = [[Quarterback|QB]] | hometown = Oklahoma City, Oklahoma | highschool = [[Putnam City North High School]] | feet = 6 | inches = 4 | weight = 200 | 40 = 4.8 | commitdate = December 2, 2005 | scout stars = 3 | rivals stars = 3 | espn grade = 79 }} {{College athlete recruit end | 40 = yes | year = 2006 | rivals ref title = 2006 Oklahoma Football Commitment List | scout ref title = 2006 Oklahoma College Football Recruiting Commits | espn ref title = | rivals school = oklahoma | scout s = 146 | espn schoolid = | scout overall = 18 ([[Quarterback|QB]]) | rivals overall = 12 (QB), 1 (Oklahoma) | espn overall = 16 (QB) | accessdate = September 21, 2016 }}
==College career== Bradford received an [[athletic scholarship]] to attend the [[University of Oklahoma]], where he played for coach [[Bob Stoops]]'s [[Oklahoma Sooners football]] team from 2006 to 2009. He redshirted as a freshman in 2006 before becoming the starter in 2007 and turning in one of the best seasons ever by a quarterback, passing for 4,720 yards with 50 touchdowns and just eight interceptions.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/sam-bradford-1/gamelog/2008/ |title=Sam Bradford 2008 Game Log |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> As a result, he won the [[Heisman Trophy]], becoming the fifth Oklahoma player to win the award. After Oklahoma lost the [[2009 BCS National Championship Game]] 24-14 to [[Florida Gators|Florida]], Bradford, instead of declaring for the upcoming draft, elected to return to Oklahoma for another crack at the title.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2009-01-08-florida.html |title=BCS Championship - Oklahoma vs Florida Box Score, January 8, 2009 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> He ended up playing in just three games due to a shoulder injury, and the Sooners, ranked No. 3 to start the season, finished with a 8-5 record.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/schools/oklahoma/2009.html |title=2009 Oklahoma Sooners Stats |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref>
===Freshman season=== {{See also|2006 Oklahoma Sooners football team}} In 2006, Oklahoma's starting quarterback [[Rhett Bomar]], then a sophomore, was dismissed from the team for violating [[NCAA]] rules.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://newsok.com/article/2824545 |title=Bomar, Quinn dismissed from OU football team |date=2006-08-03 |website=NewsOK.com |language=en-US |access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref> [[Paul Thompson (American football)|Paul Thompson]], a senior quarterback-turned-wide receiver, converted back to quarterback and led the [[2006 Oklahoma Sooners football team]] to win the [[Big 12 Championship Game]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/schools/oklahoma/2006.html |title=2006 Oklahoma Sooners Stats |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/schools/oklahoma/2006-schedule.html |title=2006 Oklahoma Sooners Schedule and Results |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref> His departure left a void at the quarterback position at Oklahoma. Six players on the roster tried out for the starting position during the following off-season, including three [[Walk-on (sports)|walk-on]] quarterbacks,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cfbstats.com/2007/team/522/roster.html|title=2007 Oklahoma Sooners Roster}}</ref> [[true freshman]] Keith Nichol (a [[Rivals.com]] 4-star recruit and 6th-ranked dual-threat quarterback in the 2007 recruiting class, who later transferred to [[Michigan State University]]), junior Joey Halzle (the only one with game experience), and Bradford, a [[redshirt freshman]]. On August 21, 2007, Bradford won the starting quarterback role for the [[2007 Oklahoma Sooners football team|2007 team]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/082107aaa.html | publisher=SoonerSports.com | title=Bradford Gets Nod at Quarterback | accessdate=2007-08-21 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007165746/http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/082107aaa.html | archivedate=2007-10-07 | df= }}</ref>
[[File:OUSoonersQBs-April2007.jpg|thumb|left|Bradford (left), Joey Halzle (center), and Hays McEachern (right) during spring practice in April 2007]]
In his first game for the Sooners, against the [[University of North Texas]], Bradford completed 21 of 23 attempts for 363 yards and three touchdowns in a little over two quarters, breaking the school record for passing yards in a half, held by his quarterback coach [[Josh Heupel]], with 350.<ref name="Sooner newbies">{{cite news | title=Sooner newbies Bradford, Murray debut with monster games | first=Jenni | last=Carlson | publisher=NewsOK.com | url=http://newsok.com/article/3116419 | accessdate=2007-09-04 | date=2007-09-02 }}</ref> The very next game, Bradford broke [[Heisman Trophy]] winner [[Jason White (American football)|Jason White]]'s school record for most consecutive pass completions with 22 (18 came in the first half and four at the start of the second).<ref name="NOK1_OUUM">{{cite news | title=Sooners' Bradford proves that he belongs | publisher=NewsOK.com | first=Jake | last=Trotter | url=http://newsok.com/article/3121288 | date=2007-09-09 | accessdate=2007-09-10 }}</ref>
In the second week of the 2007 season, Bradford was named the national offensive player of the week by the [[Walter Camp Football Foundation]]<ref>{{cite web | title=Bradford Captures Camp Honor | url=http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/090907aab.html | publisher=SoonerSports.com | accessdate=2007-09-10 | date=2007-09-09 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081204060416/http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/090907aab.html | archivedate=2008-12-04 | df= }}</ref> after tying the school record for most touchdown passes in a game with five.<ref>{{cite web | title=Oklahoma Rocks Miami, 51–13 | url=http://www.soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/090807aaa.html | publisher=SoonerSports.com | accessdate=2007-09-10 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013141054/http://soonersports.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/090807aaa.html | archivedate=2007-10-13 | df= }}</ref> Having thrown 25 touchdowns through his first nine games, Bradford was on pace to break the [[NCAA]] freshman record of 29 touchdowns set by [[David Neill]] in 1998 and tied by [[Colt McCoy]] in 2006.
In the November 17, 2007 game against [[Texas Tech Red Raiders|Texas Tech]], Bradford suffered a concussion of unknown severity. He was removed from the game and replaced by back-up quarterback Joey Halzle. The Sooners lost the game, 27–34.<ref>{{cite web | title = The Sports Network I-A College Football | url = http://www.sportsnetwork.com/default.asp?c=sportsnetwork&page=/cfoot/news/AFN4113246.htm | publisher = The Sports Network | accessdate = 2007-11-18}}</ref> Bradford was able to play in the [[Bedlam Series|Bedlam]] game against [[Oklahoma State Cowboys|Oklahoma State]] on November 24.<ref>{{cite web | title = ESPN – Sooners QB Bradford to be reevaluated this week – College Football | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=3117799 | publisher = ESPN | accessdate = 2007-11-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsline.com/collegefootball/story/11118296|title=Bradford's early exit in '07 means Tech still has to size up Sam|website=sportsline.com|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref>
During the November 24, 2007 game against the [[Oklahoma State Cowboys football|Oklahoma State Cowboys]], Bradford broke the NCAA freshman record of 29 touchdowns by passing his 30th touchdown to [[Joe Jon Finley]] during the second quarter.<ref>{{cite news | title=Patrick runs for career-best 202 yards, 2 TDs as OU rolls | publisher=ESPN | accessdate=2007-11-24 | date=2007-11-24 | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=273280201 }}</ref> At the [[Missouri Tigers]] game, Bradford threw for 209 yards and 0 interceptions. He was 18–26 and threw for two touchdowns.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2007-10-13-oklahoma.html |title=Missouri at Oklahoma Box Score, October 13, 2007 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref>
The Sooners won the [[Big 12 Championship Game|Big 12 Championship]] after defeating Missouri for the second time in a season.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2007-12-01-missouri.html |title=Oklahoma vs Missouri Box Score, December 1, 2007 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref> The Sooners played the [[West Virginia Mountaineers]] in the [[Fiesta Bowl]] on January 2, 2008 and lost 48–28.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2008-01-02-oklahoma.html |title=Fiesta Bowl - West Virginia vs Oklahoma Box Score, January 2, 2008 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref> It was Bradford's first [[Bowl Championship Series]] game as a starter.
===Sophomore season=== {{See also|2008 Oklahoma Sooners football team}} [[File:OklahomaSooners-SamBradford (cropped 1).jpg|thumb|180 px|Sam Bradford during the 2008 NCAA season.]] In week 8 of the following season against [[2008 Kansas Jayhawks football team|Kansas]], Bradford surpassed quarterback coach [[Josh Heupel]]'s school record for passing yards in a single game with 468 yards.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://newsok.com/article/3313297 |title=Jenni Carlson exclusive: Bradford blossoms under Heupel's helping hand |date=2008-10-19 |website=NewsOK.com |language=en-US |access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref> Bradford led the Sooners to their third straight Big 12 Championship and defeated Missouri 62–21.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2008-12-06-missouri.html |title=Oklahoma vs Missouri Box Score, December 6, 2008 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref> In the process, the Sooners broke Hawaii's 2006 record for the most points in a single season with 702 points. Also, the Sooners were the first team in NCAA history to score 60 or more points in five straight games. Oklahoma finished the 2008 regular season with a 12–1 record, ranking #2 in the AP Poll and #1 in the BCS Standings.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/schools/oklahoma/2008.html |title=2008 Oklahoma Sooners Stats |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref> The Sooners earned a trip to play [[University of Florida|Florida]] at the [[2009 BCS National Championship Game]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2009-01-08-florida.html |title=BCS Championship - Oklahoma vs Florida Box Score, January 8, 2009 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2017-11-09}}</ref>
After the regular season, Bradford captured the [[Davey O'Brien Award]]<ref name=OBrien08>{{cite news|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/sports/article.aspx?subjectid=92&articleid=20081212_92_B1_Olhmur200895|title=Bradford is winner of O'Brien QB award}}</ref> and the [[Heisman Trophy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heisman.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/121308aaa.html|title=SAM BRADFORD OF THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA SELECTED AS THE 2008 HEISMAN WINNER|website=heisman.com|accessdate=23 May 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217034536/http://www.heisman.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/121308aaa.html|archivedate=17 December 2008|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsok.com/heisman-u-sam-bradford-is-latest-in-impressive-r-ou-q/article/3328676?custom_click=lead_story_title|title=Heisman U? Sam Bradford is latest in impressive run of OU signal-callers}}</ref> He is the second sophomore, after 2007 winner [[Tim Tebow]] of the University of Florida, to receive the Heisman; he also became the fifth University of Oklahoma player, as well as the second person of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] descent to capture the trophy after Jim Plunkett.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sportsnetwork.com/merge/tsnform.aspx?c=sportsnetwork&page=cfoot/news/news.aspx?id=4197477|title= Bradford wins 2008 Heisman Trophy}}</ref> Bradford received 1,726 total points while the other finalists, [[Colt McCoy]], of the University of Texas, and Tim Tebow, received 1,604 and 1,575, respectively. Tebow, however, collected more first-place votes, 309, while Bradford got 300. Bradford got the most points thanks to the help of his 315 second-place votes. A total of 926 voters participated in the balloting.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/sports/article.aspx?subjectid=92&articleid=20081213_297_0_NWYRut498164|title=OU's Sam Bradford wins 74th Heisman Trophy}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center; margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+2008 Heisman Trophy Finalist Voting<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/hotstories/6163533.html|title=Oklahoma QB Bradford wins Heisman Trophy}}</ref> ! Finalist ! First place votes<br />(3 pts. each) ! Second place votes<br />(2 pts. each) ! Third place votes<br />(1 pt. each) ! Total points |- | Sam Bradford | 300 | 315 | 196 | 1,726 |- | [[Colt McCoy]] | 266 | 288 | 230 | 1,604 |- | [[Tim Tebow]] | 309 | 207 | 234 | 1,575 |}
When combined with [[Blake Griffin]]'s [[Naismith College Player of the Year|Naismith Award]], [[Oklahoma Sooners|Oklahoma]] became the first school to have a winner in both top basketball and football individual awards in the same year. Bradford was also voted [[Associated Press College Football Player of the Year]]. Bradford received 27 votes, again beating McCoy (17 votes) and Tim Tebow (16 votes).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/ncaa/football/news?slug=ap-applayeroftheyear&prov=ap&type=lgns|title=NCAAF on Yahoo! Sports - News, Scores, Standings, Rumors, Fantasy Games|website=Yahoo Sports|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref> Bradford is the third Oklahoma Sooner to win the award, joining [[Josh Heupel]] (2000) and [[Jason White (American football)|Jason White]] (2003). Heupel and White were also quarterbacks, with Heupel being the current quarterbacks coach for Oklahoma.
Bradford faced [[2008 Florida Gators football team|Florida]], led by Tebow, in the [[2009 BCS National Championship Game]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/printedition/la-sp-dufresne5-2009jan05,0,6538839.column|title= Sam Bradford and Tim Tebow are Heismans apart | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Chris | last=Dufresne | date=January 5, 2009 | accessdate=May 23, 2010}}</ref> He threw 26-of-41 passes for 256 yards, two touchdowns, and two interceptions, as Florida won the game 24–14.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/boxscore?gameId=290080201|title=Florida Gators vs. Oklahoma Sooners Box Score, January 8, 2009}}</ref>
===Junior season=== {{See also|2009 Oklahoma Sooners football team}} Bradford announced that he would forgo the [[2009 NFL Draft]] to return to Oklahoma for his junior season.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/football/ncaa/01/14/bradford.ap/index.html |title=Sam Bradford Will Return to Oklahoma |publisher=SI.com |date=2009-01-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090121141013/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/football/ncaa/01/14/bradford.ap/index.html |archivedate=January 21, 2009 }}</ref> In the Sooners' first game of the season (against [[2009 BYU Cougars football team|Brigham Young]]), Bradford suffered a third-degree [[AC joint]] sprain one play after becoming Oklahoma's all-time passing leader. Playing without Bradford for the second half of the game, Oklahoma went on to lose 14–13.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=292480201|title=BYU vs. Oklahoma - Game Recap - September 5, 2009 - ESPN|website=ESPN.com|accessdate=23 May 2017}}</ref> Bradford was originally scheduled to return in about three to six weeks,<ref name="Hall's TD">{{cite news | title=Hall's TD pass with 3:03 remaining lifts Cougars over No. 3 Sooners | url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=292480201 | agency=Associated Press | publisher=ESPN.com | date=2009-09-05 | accessdate=2009-09-05}}</ref> but head coach Bob Stoops initially refused to either confirm or deny that timetable.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsok.com/ous-bob-stoops-sam-bradford-still-questionable-for-miami/article/3402852 |title=OU's Bob Stoops: Sam Bradford still questionable for Miami |newspaper=The Oklahoman |first=Mike |last=Baldwin |date=September 21, 2009 |accessdate=2010-12-19}}</ref> After missing three weeks, Bradford returned to the field during the [[2009 Baylor Bears football team|Baylor]] game, and completed 27 of 49 passes for 389 yards and one touchdown, leading the Sooners to a 33–7 victory.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.omaha.com/article/20091010/SPORTS/710109763|title=Big 12: Even with Bradford, Sooners beatable}}</ref> Bradford re-injured his right shoulder on October 17, 2009 in the [[Red River Rivalry]] against [[2009 Texas Longhorns football team|Texas]] on the second drive of the game. It was later announced that he would undergo season-ending shoulder surgery and enter the [[2010 NFL Draft]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rivals.yahoo.com/ncaa/football/news?slug=ap-t25-oklahoma-bradford&prov=ap&type=lgns |title=Archived copy |accessdate=November 4, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5l2ZsTqU9?url=http://rivals.yahoo.com/ncaa/football/news?slug=ap-t25-oklahoma-bradford&prov=ap&type=lgns |archivedate=November 4, 2009 |df= }}</ref>
